div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Americus, Georgia" and may be so cited. (Code 1986, § 1-1) State Law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. City. The term "city" means the City of Americus, Georgia. City council. The term "city council" "or council" means the city council of the city. Code. The term "Code" means The Code of the City of Americus, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. Computation of time. When a number of days are prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, only the first or last day shall be counted. If the last day shall fall on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following business day to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, an intermediate Saturday, Sunday and legal holiday shall be excluded in the computation. Conjunctions. Where a provision involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either . . . or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, provided in appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: (1) The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. (2) The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. (3) The term "either . . . or indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. County. The term "county" means Sumter County, Georgia. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring a city officer or city employee to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act. Following. The term "following" means next after. Gender. Words of one gender include all other genders. Generally. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. In all interpretations the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the city council, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. Liberal construction; minimum requirements; overlapping provisions. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. The specific controls over the general. May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. Number. Words used in the singular include the plural. Words used in the plural include the singular. Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." Officials, officers, etc. Whenever reference is made to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies by title only, the reference refers to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the city. Owner. The term "owner," as applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or of a part of the building or land. Person. The term "person" includes any association, club, society, firm, corporation, any limited liability company, partnership or body politic and corporate, as well as an individual. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. Preceding. The term "preceding" means next before. Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. Public place. The term "public place" includes any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. State. The term the "state" means the State of Georgia. Statutory references. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the "Official Code of Geogia Annotated" as now or hereafter amended. Any reference to a state act, whether by short title or year, page number and/or act number, is a reference to such act, as amended. Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, courts, alleys, lanes, circles, viaducts and all other public streets and ways in the city and shall embrace all parts thereof constituting the designated right-of-way. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or a part of a building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future, as well as the past and present. Week. The term "week" means seven days. Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals. Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. (Code 1986, § 1-2; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) State Law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections, effect of history notes, references in Code. (a) The catchlines of sections of this Code printed in boldface type, italics, or otherwise, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section or subsection, and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles thereof, or as any part thereof, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. (c) All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. (Code 1986, § 1-3) Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. (Code 1962, § 1-4; Code 1986, § 1-4) Sec. 1-5. - Supplementation of Code. (a) Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances or resolutions and parts of ordinances or resolutions included in the supplemental, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the person may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code that embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinances inserted into the Code. (d) In no case shall the person make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. (Code 1986, § 1-5) Sec. 1-6. - Amendment to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances adopted subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of these subsequent ordinances or resolutions until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending those provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "section ____________ of The Code of the City of Americus, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. (c) If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of the City of Americus, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) to be numbered ____________ , that reads as follows:…." The new material may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, subdivisions, divisions, articles or chapters desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, subdivision, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1986, § 1-6) Sec. 1-7. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. (Code 1986, § 1-7) Sec. 1-8. - General penalty. (a) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context that it is the intent to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the officer or employee. (c) Except as otherwise provided: (1) A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or compulsory labor for the city on the streets, sidewalks, squares, or other public places for a period not exceeding 30 days, or any combination thereof. (2) With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. (3) With respect to violations of this Code that are not continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. (d) The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. (e) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. (Code 1986, § 1-8) State Law reference— Limitations on penalties, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); authority to punish ordinance violations by requiring labor, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-8. Sec. 1-9. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 hereof. (Code 1986, § 1-9) Sec. 1-10. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the governing body that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, that unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since they would have been enacted without the incorporation in this Code of the unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (Code 1986, § 1-10) Sec. 1-11. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, insofar as they are the same as those of ordinances and resolutions existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-12. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: (1) Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. (2) Authorizing or approving any contract, deed, or agreement. (3) Granting any right or franchise. (4) Making or approving any appropriation or budget. (5) Providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code. (6) Adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. (7) Levying or imposing any special assessment. (8) Dedicating, establishing naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley. (9) Dedicating, accepting or approving any plat or subdivision. (10) Providing traffic regulations for specific areas, such as no parking zones, stop intersections, etc., not in conflict with this Code. (11) Levying taxes that are not codified in this Code. (12) Rezoning specific property or amending the zoning map. (13) Adopted for purposes which have been consummated. (14) That is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect. (Code 1986, § 1-11) Sec. 1-13. - Statute of limitations. All prosecutions for violations of any city ordinance shall be commenced within two years after such violation, and any offense against said ordinance for which no prosecution is begun within two years after its commission shall be barred, unless the party so offending shall have been beyond the limits of the city, in which case the time of absence from the city shall not be embraced and computed as within said two years. (Code 1962, § 19-1; Code 1986, § 8-2)

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-1 et seq.; powers relating to administration of government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; the Municipal Home Rule Act of 1965, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Regulatory fees. All regulatory fees charged by the city are hereby determined to be reasonable and reflective of the cost of regulation. Secs. 2-2—2-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-21. - Mayor. The mayor shall have the general superintendence of the affairs of the city; shall preside at all meetings of the city council, and it shall be the mayor's duty to see that all laws, ordinances, resolutions and rules of the city council are observed and enforced, and that all officers of the city shall faithfully discharge the duties required of them. (Code 1962, § 2-28; Code 1986, § 2-21) Sec. 2-22. - Mayor pro tem election. The city council shall elect from its body a mayor pro tem, who shall, during the illness, absence or disqualification of the mayor, act in the mayor's stead, and be clothed with all rights, privileges and duties of the mayor. (Code 1962, § 2-29; Code 1986, § 2-22) Secs. 2-23—2-47. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE
Sec. 2-48. - Meetings, when held. The city council shall meet regularly at least once each month, at such place and time as it may fix and prescribe. Special meetings may be called by the mayor at any time for the consideration and determination of any questions or matters requiring immediate attention, of which special meeting the city clerk shall give the members notice. (Code 1962, § 2-10; Code 1986, § 2-24) Sec. 2-49. - Speaking at meetings; decorum at meetings; notices to city council from members of the public; disturbing or interrupting meetings; violations. (a) Monthly public meetings of city council and city council committees. Unless otherwise provided by a majority vote of the city council, the mayor and city council shall meet at least two times each calendar month. The first meeting shall be an agenda setting meeting and the second meeting shall be the regular monthly meeting. Such meetings shall be at such times and dates as established by the city council from time to time. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit called meetings otherwise allowed by law; nor shall any provision of this subsection be construed to require that both meetings be held each calendar month if a majority of the city council agrees to dispense with one of such meetings; provided, however, that, unless prevented by circumstances or events beyond the control of the mayor and city council, the mayor and city council shall have at least a regular monthly meeting each calendar month. All meetings of the mayor and city council shall be held and conducted under the provisions of the Georgia Open Meetings Act. (b) Meeting agenda. At least 48 hours prior to each meeting of the mayor and city council, or any committee thereof, the city clerk, or the designee thereof, shall publish an agenda of the matters anticipated to be considered or discussed at the meeting. The fact that a particular matter is not included on the published agenda shall not prevent the matter from being considered, provided that a majority of the city council or the council committee, as the case may be, adopts a motion approving the addition of the matter to the agenda at any time during the meeting. (c) Public hearings. At each meeting of the mayor and city council, or any committee thereof, when the mayor and city council or a committee of the city council is conducting a public hearing in accord with the requirements of federal, state or local laws, regulations, or ordinances, any person desiring to address the mayor and city council or a committee of city council during such public hearing regarding the subject matter of the public hearing shall be authorized to do so. Such person must be recognized by the presiding officer prior to speaking at the public hearing. Comments by persons speaking during the public hearing shall be directed to the presiding officer, and not to individual members of the city council, and unless otherwise provided by state law or local ordinance, the comments of such person addressing a public hearing shall be limited to five minutes per person. Any person speaking during a public hearing shall limit his or her comments to the subject matter of the public hearing, and any statements or comments made by such person not related to the subject matter of the public hearing shall be immediately ruled out of order by the presiding officer. At the conclusion of the time to speak at such public hearing, each speaker shall terminate his or her remarks. (d) Agenda items. At any regular monthly meeting of the city council, members of the public desiring to address the mayor and city council regarding items that appear on the published city council agenda shall personally sign up to do so at the meeting location on the day of the meeting as long as such person signs up to speak prior to the time that the meeting is called to order by the presiding officer. A person signing up to speak on an agenda item must indicate the item on which such person desires to address the mayor and city council by reference to the meeting agenda at the time such person signs up to speak. The city clerk, or his or her designee, shall provide a sign-up sheet for such purposes at least 30 minutes prior to the scheduled starting time of the meeting. Such sign-up sheet shall be located on the lectern provided for speakers at the meeting. No more than a total of five speakers can sign up to speak at any one meeting, and each speaker shall be provided three minutes to address the mayor and city council regarding the agenda item or items to be addressed by such speaker. A speaker can sign up to address more than one agenda item, but the number of agenda items to be addressed by a speaker shall not affect the total amount of time allotted for each individual speaker. If more than a total of five speakers sign up to speak at any one meeting, the presiding officer shall only be authorized to recognize the first five persons who signed up to speak. No person shall be authorized to sign up for another person to speak and no speaker shall be authorized to yield any portion of his or her unused time to another person. In the event that there are a large number of persons who desire to speak on a particular agenda item, the presiding officer may request that the persons wishing to speak on the agenda item select a spokesperson to address the mayor and city council on behalf of such persons. A person speaking to the mayor and city council on an agenda item shall only be authorized to speak on such agenda item and any statements or comments made by such person not related to the agenda item upon which such person is authorized to speak shall be immediately ruled out of order by the presiding officer, and if a speaker continues to speak on matters not related to the agenda item upon which such person is authorized to speak after being ruled out of order by the presiding officer, then such person may be removed from the meeting and charged with violation of this section. Comments by persons speaking on an agenda item shall be directed to the presiding officer, and not to individual members of the city council. Any speaker addressing individual member of the city council shall be ruled out of order by the presiding officer, and if such speaker continues to address individual members of the city council after being ruled out of order for doing so by the presiding officer, then such person may be removed from the meeting and charged with violation of this section. At the conclusion of the time to speak on such agenda item, each speaker shall terminate his or her remarks. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require a person to sign up to speak in connection with a public hearing to be conducted by the mayor and city council under subsection (c) of this section. (e) Non-agenda items. Members of the public desiring to bring any matter concerning the city to the attention of the city council which does not appear on a meeting agenda of the mayor and city council may submit such person's comments in writing to the city manager of the city at any time during which the city council or a council committee is not in an administrative briefing, an agenda setting meeting, or in a regular monthly meeting. Copies of such written comments from a member of the public shall be submitted to the mayor and city council within ten calendar days of the date such comments are submitted to the city manager. In the event that at least three members of the city council deem it appropriate to include issues or comments submitted to the city manager under this section on the agenda of a subsequent meeting of the mayor and city council, then, at least three calendar days prior to the meeting of the city council at which such members desire that such item be placed upon the agenda, such three members shall submit a notice to the city manager, either jointly or severally, to place such item on such city council meeting agenda for consideration by the mayor and city council; provided, however, that unless such matter is tabled or otherwise postponed by action of the governing body, no such item shall be placed on an agenda of the city council more than one time every six months. (f) Meeting decorum. In order to ensure proper decorum and a businesslike atmosphere at all meetings of the city council or any committee thereof, no signs, placards, or similar displays that are larger than 17 inches by 24 inches, or that are attached to sticks, rods or poles or that are constructed of metal or wood shall be allowed within the city council chambers or in a city council meeting room during a city council or committee meeting unless the sign specifically illustrates, depicts or describes in the form of a map, plat, schematic drawing, picture, or similar depiction, a particular item that appears on the meeting agenda as an item for consideration by the city council or a committee thereof. In addition to the foregoing, any such sign, placard, or similar display that is otherwise authorized hereunder shall not be placed or displayed in a location or in a manner which blocks the view of any member of the audience, city staff, or the council. Any signs, placards, or similar displays that are prohibited hereunder, or any sign that is otherwise authorized hereunder which blocks a person's view as prohibited herein during the course of a meeting, shall be removed by the person carrying the sign upon request of the presiding officer or by an appropriate officer of the police department upon direction of the presiding officer. (g) Violations of ordinance. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this section or for any person to disturb or interrupt any meeting of the city council or a committee thereof. The use of obscene or profane language, physical violence, or the threat thereof, or loud and boisterous behavior which the presiding officer shall determine is intended as a disruption of the meeting, or any failure to comply with any lawful decision or order of the presiding officer in connection with or during the course of a meeting, shall constitute a disturbance hereunder, and shall be considered to be a violation of this section. Any person violating the provisions of this section, including a person violating this section by creating a disturbance as defined herein, or by failing or refusing to comply with a lawful order of the presiding officer during a meeting of the mayor and city council or a committee thereof, may be ordered removed or ejected from the city council chambers or other meeting room by the presiding officer for the duration of the meeting or for such lesser period as the presiding officer shall determine. In addition, any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Code 1986, § 2-24.1; Ord. No. O-04-11-23, 11-18-2004; Ord. No. O-12-03-08, 3-22-2012; Ord. No. O-2014-8, 3-20-2014; Ord. No. O-2014-17, 10-20-2014; Ord. No. O-2015-10, 6-18-2015; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting lawful meetings, gatherings, or processions, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34. Sec. 2-50. - Presiding officer. (a) The mayor shall preside at all meetings, preserve order and decorum, and shall appoint all committees, unless the council shall otherwise direct. (b) In the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tem shall preside; and in the absence of both, a chairman shall be appointed by the council, vested with all the powers of the mayor during such absence. (Code 1962, §§ 2-12, 2-13; Code 1986, § 2-26) Sec. 2-51. - Voting on questions, generally; show of hand votes; mayor's role; obligation of council members to vote on questions. (a) All questions shall be put by the presiding officer. The members shall vote by a show of hands, with a majority of the members present and voting determining all questions unless otherwise provided. The mayor, at such officer's discretion, may call upon the mayor pro tem to take the chair, to allow the mayor to address the council or make a motion. The mayor may vote on any issue before the city council, unless he is otherwise disqualified. (b) At any meeting of the governing body of the city, or any committee thereof, each council member present shall vote on each question that comes before the meeting unless a city council member is immediately and particularly interested in the question to the extent that such council member has a conflict of interest, or the appearance of a conflict of interest, with respect to such question, or unless a council member is excused from voting by a majority vote of the governing body. A motion to excuse a member from voting may be made by the council member seeking to be excused, must be made before the question is put to a vote, and shall be decided without debate, except that the council member making the motion may state briefly the reasons that the motion was made. (Code 1962, § 2-14; Code 1986, § 2-27; Ord. No. O-2012-18, 5-24-2012) Sec. 2-52. - Record of votes. Whenever it shall be required by any one or more members, the yeas and nays shall be recorded. (Code 1962, § 2-15; Code 1986, § 2-28) Sec. 2-53. - Applications, etc., to be written. Applications, petitions or other communications to the city council must be in writing; and in all cases the same must be referred to a committee before any action is taken thereon, unless the city council shall otherwise direct. (Code 1962, § 2-17; Code 1986, § 2-30) Sec. 2-54. - Reconsideration of previous business. Before the minutes of any preceding meeting of the city council are confirmed, any member may move to reconsider any question, motion, resolution, or other matter or thing in the minutes of such previous meeting contained; and if such reconsideration be voted by a majority of the members present, the subject matter of such reconsideration shall be first business in order to be disposed of. (Code 1962, § 2-19; Code 1986, § 2-32) Sec. 2-55. - Robert's Rules of Order adopted. The meetings of the city council shall be guided and governed by those parliamentary rules and regulations popularly known as "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised," the same being adopted and made a part hereof as though set out fully herein, except as otherwise provided in the Charter or this Code. (Code 1962, § 2-9; Code 1986, § 2-33) Sec. 2-56. - Council committees. The mayor and city council may provide for the appointment of such committees as they deem necessary or desirable, including any standing committees or special committees. All committees and committee chairmen shall be appointed by the mayor and serve at his pleasure. The mayor shall have the power to appoint new members to any committee at any time. (Code 1962, § 2-39; Code 1986, § 2-35; Ord. No. O-94-12-46, 12-22-1994; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-2015-14, 7-23-2015) Editor's note— Formerly entitled "Standing council committees—Enumerated", which was amended by Ord. No. O-2015-14. Sec. 2-57. - Same—Duties. It shall be the duty of the standing committees to prepare business for the action of the city council and to report upon such matters as may be referred to them. (Code 1962, § 2-40; Code 1986, § 2-36) Secs. 2-58—2-87. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Public officers and employees generally, O.C.G.A. § 45-1-1 et seq.; power to define, regulate and alter the powers, duties, qualifications, compensation and tenure of all municipal officers, agents and employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2(2).
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-88. - Personnel manual adopted. The personnel ordinance adopted November 18, 1975, and amended September 19, 1977, September 24, 1979, October 8, 1979, April 27, 1981, May 25, 1981, November 23, 1981, October 25, 1982, and December 27, 1984, is hereby further amended by adopting the personnel policies, classification plan and pay plan for the city as set out in the personnel manual, dated January 1, 1987, consisting of section A, personnel policies, sections I through XVIII; section B, classification plan, sections I through III; section C, pay plan, sections I through III and section D, definitions and as subsequently amended, at least one copy of which is filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling. (Code 1986, § 17-8; Ord. of 12-27-1984; Ord. of 11-24-1986) Sec. 2-89. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2015-15, adopted July 23, 2015, repealed § 2-89, entitled "Appointive officers, specified; voice vote, etc." which derived from: Code 1962, § 2-43; Code 1986, § 2-1; Ord. No. O-87-03-05, adopted Mar. 23, 1987; Ord. No. O-87-04-08, adopted Apr. 27, 1987; Ord. No. O-89-12-42, adopted Dec. 18, 1989; Ord. No. O-91-03-07, adopted Mar. 25, 1991; Ord. No. O-95-02-05, adopted Feb. 27, 1995; Ord. No. O-95-12-44, adopted Dec. 21, 1995; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, adopted Dec. 16, 2004; Ord. No. O-2013-25, adopted Aug. 22, 2013; and Ord. No. O-2013-29, adopted Oct. 24, 2013. Sec. 2-89.1. - Appointment of city manager. (a) The city council shall appoint the city manager who shall be in charge of running the day-to-day business and operations of the city. Such city manager shall be appointed and shall meet the qualifications as provided in section 3-101 of the City Charter. Such city manager shall be entitled to such compensation as may be established pursuant to section 3-101 of the City Charter. The city manager may be removed by the city council as provided in section 3-101 of the City Charter. (b) With respect to the duties and responsibilities of the city manager, those shall be as established pursuant to section 3-102 of the City Charter and by such ordinances supplemental to the City Charter as may be adopted by the city council from time to time. (Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 2-89.2. - City departments. (a) The city council hereby establishes the following departments within the city: (1) Finance director; (2) Police department; (3) Fire and emergency services department; (4) Community and economic development department; (5) Planning and inspections department; (6) Public works department; and (7) Natural gas department. (8) Human resources department. (b) A job description, including the duties and responsibilities of such department heads, shall be provided in the city's personnel ordinance. (c) The city manager shall be authorized to appoint, suspend, remove, or terminate such department heads in accordance with the personnel rules, regulations, policies and ordinances of the city. (Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015; Ord. No. O-2016-01, 3-24-2016) Sec. 2-89.3. - City clerk. (a) In accord with the provisions of section 3-201 of the City Charter, the city manager shall appoint a city clerk, who shall not be a council member. (b) The duties and responsibilities of the city clerk shall be established by the City Charter and by such other ordinances of the city council supplemental to such Charter as may be adopted from time to time by the city council. (c) A job description, including the duties and responsibilities of the city clerk, which is consistent with the provisions of the City Charter, shall be provided in the city's personnel ordinance. (d) The city manager shall be authorized to appoint, suspend, remove, or terminate the city clerk in accordance with the personnel rules, regulations, policies and ordinances of the city. The city clerk shall not be considered to be a department head of the city. (Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 2-89.4. - Municipal court judge. The city council shall appoint a municipal court judge from time to time to carry out such duties as Municipal Court Judge of the City of Americus as are provided in article IV, chapter 1 of the City Charter. (Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 2-90. - Salaries of appointed officers. No salary of any appointed officer shall be increased or diminished during his term of office, unless by unanimous consent of the city council. (Code 1962, § 2-44; Code 1986, § 2-2) Sec. 2-91. - Code enforcement officer; authority to issue tickets, citations or summons; exception. The code enforcement officer, during the term of his employment, shall be authorized to write tickets or citations on forms provided for such purpose preferring charges against individuals and other entities for alleged violations of this Code. The code enforcement officer shall also be authorized to issue summons to appear before the municipal court of the city to answer charges relating to alleged violations of this Code by person or other legal entities. The authority granted to the enforcement officer hereunder shall not include the authority to issue tickets or summons for violations of the traffic laws of this city unless the enforcement officer is otherwise authorized to do so by other state statute or city ordinance. (Code 1986, § 2-10.1; Ord. No. O-96-09-41, 9-19-1996; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 2-92. - City attorney. The city council shall appoint a city attorney from time to time as provided in article III, section 3-301 of the City Charter. The city attorney shall meet with the city council at all regular meetings and all called meetings as such attorney may be requested. The city attorney shall render legal opinions to the city council and/or any city officer or employee on matters concerning city business. The city attorney shall be the attorney for all commissions and agencies of the city, unless otherwise provided by proper ordinance, and shall render legal opinions and services to those agencies. The city attorney shall render such other services and perform such other acts as may be desired by the city council for the best interest, welfare, and benefit of the city. (Code 1962, § 2-38; Code 1986, § 2-12; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Secs. 2-93—2-112. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK AND FINANCE DIRECTOR
Sec. 2-113. - Duties of city clerk. The city clerk shall: (1) Attend all meetings of the city council; to record regularly and fairly all proceedings of the same in a book to be kept by such officer for that purpose, and to keep the same properly indexed. The city clerk shall also keep a book to be called the "ordinance book," in which such officer shall record all the city ordinances, and all the alterations of, and amendments to, the same hereafter enacted, and shall keep said ordinance book properly indexed. (2) Issue all executions, summonses, notices, subpoenas, and processes of any kind that may be necessary in the enforcement of the rules, regulations, and ordinances of the city council. (3) Be the keeper of the public seal of the city, and the custodian of all the records and other papers belonging to the city; shall be responsible for their safe keeping; and shall turn over all books, papers or other property of the city in such officer's hands to such officer's successor in office. (4) Affix the seal of the city to any document. (5) Furnish certified copies of records of such officer's office except such as are needed or requested by the city council per 100 words. (Code 1962, §§ 2-32, 2-33; Code 1986, §§ 2-6, 2-7; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 2-114. - Duties and fees of finance director. (a) The finance director shall: (1) Issue all licenses, badges and permits authorized or granted by the city council, and keep a record of the same. (2) Keep an execution docket, in which such officer shall enter all executions issued by such officer. (3) Receive, safely keep, and pay out all money belonging to the city, and keep regular books, showing such officer's receipts and payments of the same, and keep separate accounts of all funds arising for any general or special purposes. (4) Not pay any money to any person who is indebted to the city council, but in all such cases the amount of the claim against the city council, when properly audited, must be placed as a credit on the indebtedness or claim due by such person to the city council. (5) It shall be the duty of the finance director to make daily deposits of all revenue received by such officer each day. The finance director shall make no cash disbursements of any funds for the account of the city council, except as hereinafter provided; all disbursements, except as hereinafter provided, shall be paid by checks drawn by the finance director. The finance director shall maintain at all times and keep in such officer's vault a nominal cash balance of $500.00 to cover incidental expenses not practical to pay by check; and from this fund the finance director shall pay such small items not exceeding $50.00 of incidental expense as may be necessary from time to time, and said fund shall be replenished for any such expenditures so made from same, on presentation of voucher with supporting documents, to the city council which shall authorize the finance director to draw such officer's check against the general fund for the amount so properly expended. It shall also be the duty of the finance director to enter all cash receipts and disbursements daily in the cash records kept by such officer. All officers and employees of the city handling the revenue or funds thereof, shall turn over and deliver to the finance director each day all moneys, or funds received, taking such officer's receipt therefor. (b) The books, accounts and vouchers shall, at all times, be open to the city council for inspection, and shall make out and submit to the city council monthly reports of such officer's receipts and disbursements. (c) Fees for the following services performed by the finance director shall be as established by ordinance and shall be collected by the finance director: (1) For issuing execution in any case. (2) For filing and docketing executions in any case. (3) For canceling fi. fas. of record. (4) For drawing recognizance. (d) The finance director is hereby authorized and directed to have entered of record on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court, all executions authorized to be issued under the charter and to pay the costs thereof. (Code 1962, § 2-33; Code 1986, § 2-7; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Secs. 2-115—2-141. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-142. - Adjustments, settlements of claims against city, agents, employees. (a) Upon receipt of a claim from a person, business or other entity seeking damages for personal injury or property damage resulting from the alleged intentional or negligent misconduct of the city or its agents and employees, which is filed or submitted to the city in accord with O.C.G.A. § 36-33-5, such claim shall be immediately transmitted to the city manager of the city for investigation and consideration. Upon the completion of such investigation, in the event that the city manager determines that administrative adjustment or settlement of such claim is in the best interest of the city, he shall be authorized to administratively adjust or settle such claim with the claimant on behalf of the city, upon the following terms and conditions: (1) Neither the claim itself, nor the administrative adjustment or settlement thereof, shall exceed the sum of $1,000.00; (2) Only claims for personal injury or property damage resulting from the alleged intentional or negligent misconduct by the city or its agents or employees, while acting in the course of their employment with the city, shall be subject to settlement pursuant to this section; (3) Prior to entering into the settlement of such claim in accord with the provisions hereof, the city manager shall determine that administrative adjustment or settlement of such claim is in the best interest of the city, will not work an economic or other hardship to the city, that the claim is meritorious, and that further unnecessary delay in settling such claim would be detrimental to the city; (4) Prior to settlement, the amount claimed by the claimant shall be documented to the satisfaction of the city manager in writing, and the city manager shall not be authorized to settle such claim without such documentation in an amount at least equal to the amount of the final settlement; (5) The payment of all settlement proceeds shall be paid from funds previously appropriated by the city council of the town in the city's budget for the current fiscal year for the payment of such claims; (6) Prior to actual payment of the claim, the city manager shall require the claimant to execute a full and final release in favor of the city, its agents, employees, insurance carriers and any other person or entity who might potentially be liable to the claimant as a result of such claim. Such release shall also provide specifically that such release shall not be considered as an admission of any liability to the claimant by any of the releases named or referred to in the release documents; (7) Any and all documents required to be executed effecting such settlement shall be prepared and approved by the city attorney prior to the execution thereof and the payment of any funds pursuant thereto; (8) All such settlements shall be made within 30 days of receipt of the claim by the city, unless circumstances beyond the control of the city manager require a longer period of time, in which case, such shall be reported to the city council. (b) The city manager shall notify the city council as soon as possible, but not to exceed 15 days within the date of the completion of such administrative adjustment or settlement, of the fact of adjustment or settlement and shall further maintain complete and accurate records in his office of all such matters. (c) Nothing herein shall serve to extend or shorten any statutes of limitation which may be now or hereafter applicable to any claims or claimant herein described. In addition thereto, nothing herein shall be construed as an attempt to alter, amend, change or abrogate the general provisions of state law requiring the filing of ante litum notice (O.C.G.A. § 36-33-6) with the city prior to the filing of suit against the city. Further, the provisions hereof shall not be construed as in any manner changing the official or officials of the city upon whom such ante litum notice or any civil action wherein the city is a named defendant is to be served in accord with state law. (d) Nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit or otherwise limit the authority of the city council from settling or otherwise resolving claims filed against the city in any other manner not provided for in this section. (Code 1986, § 2-13; Ord. No. O-87-08-17, §§ 1—4, 8-24-1987; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 2-143. - Procedures for sale of personal property owned by city. (a) When the city deems it appropriate to sell personal property owned by the city, the finance officer, or his or her designee, shall proceed to sell such property using either of the following procedures: (1) The finance officer, or his or her designee, shall submit photos, asset descriptions and minimum acceptable selling price to gov.deals.com, or any similar or successor corporation that offers items for sale for government entities utilizing an internet-based auction system; where such items will be auctioned over the internet for a fee to be paid by the city, and in connection with the sale of property under this optional provision, the governing body of the city shall be authorized to enter into a contract or contracts between the city and GovDeals, Inc., or any similar or successor corporation that offers items for sale for government entities utilizing an internet-based auction system regarding such sales; or (2) The finance officer, or his or designee, shall advertise the sale of the property for public sale in the newspaper that is the official legal organ of the city not less than three times within 15 calendar days prior to the date of such public sale of such personal property. Said advertisement shall give a description of the property to be sold, the date, time and place of such public sale, that the property will be sold to the highest bidder, with the city reserving the right to reject any or all bids, that prospective purchasers may submit a written bid prior to the date and hour of sale or bid orally at the time the public sale is held, and that the sale will continue from day to day until said property is sold. (b) All sales of personal property by the city under this section shall be for cash or credit card or certified funds and shall be final. The prospective purchaser is obligated to undertake all due diligence regarding the property to be sold so as to determine the condition of such property prior to the sale. All such property shall be sold in its "as is, where is" condition, and the city shall have no liability for defects or deficiencies in the property. (c) No provision of this section shall prohibit the finance officer, or his or designee, from trading in surplus property on the purchase of new property in accord with the purchasing procedures established by the City of Americus Code of Ordinances. (Code 1962, § 2-5; Code 1986, § 10-5; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005; Ord. No. O-08-12-40, 12-18-2008) Sec. 2-144. - Policy for an economic development loan fund. There is hereby established a policy for the administration of the economic development revolving loan fund of the city, to be applicable to the downtown area or coextensive with the boundary of the downtown development authority area of the city. (1) Source of funds. The economic development loan fund shall consist of federal grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development of the United States of America, program or miscellaneous income, and such other funds as may be available therefor. (2) Object of benefit. Loan funds shall be used primarily to benefit the city's low-income and moderate-income population through economic development of the central business district within the downtown development authority boundaries. (3) Security. Security for the repayment of all loan funds shall consist of a first or second security interest in the borrower's assets (whether real or personal property) being financed by such loan proceeds, or a security interest in whatever assets of the borrower that the city council may require in order to fully secure the economic development loan. Loans to a corporation shall be personally guaranteed by the shareholders of the corporation. If the borrower is not the owner of the real property to be improved with said loan funds, then, unless otherwise authorized by the city council, the owner of said real property shall guarantee repayment of said loan to the city and shall secure such guarantee by execution and delivery of a deed to secure debt with respect to such real property to the city. (4) Annual interest rate. The interest rate shall be four percent per annum or such other interest rates that may be adopted in the future. (5) Maximum loan amount. The maximum loan amount shall be $25,000.00; provided, however, under special circumstances whereby the city council in its sole discretion deems a larger loan is necessary to expedite the downtown development authority program in a timely manner or to bring an individual loan proposal package to completion, said maximum loan amount may be exceeded by the city council. The maximum loan amount shall not exceed 80 percent of the cost of the improvements financed by the loan. (6) Use of loan funds. The use of loan funds shall be limited to: a. Facade improvements, including signage. Historic preservation commission approval shall be obtained where required by ordinance. b. Interior or exterior structural improvements, including roof, heating/air, plumbing and electrical systems or improvements thereto. Such systems and improvements shall become fixtures and remain with the property. c. Provision of financial assistance by way of a loan for start-up operating costs and working capital. Start-up operating costs and working capital shall be limited to $10,000.00. The applicant shall provide all documentary information regarding the ownership of collateral and the market value of the collateral to be used as collateral in connection with the loan for start-up operating costs and working capital. The city shall be authorized to require an appraisal of such proposed collateral at the expense of the applicant, and the city shall be authorized to reject such loan application should such appraisal, if conducted, show that the proposed collateral is of insufficient value, as determined in the sole discretion of the city council, to properly collateralize the proposed loan. (7) Length of loan. No loan may be amortized or repaid over more than ten years. (8) Availability of loans. Loans shall only be made as funds are available to the city council from the economic development loan fund for such loans. (9) Priority. a. The priority for loan funds is the financing of projects that show job creation or job retention, especially jobs which employ low-income and moderate-income persons. In addition, for economic redevelopment activities, a commitment must be made by the recipient of the loan that 51 percent of the jobs created or retained by the economic development activities financed by the loan shall be reserved for low-income and moderate-income persons. b. An equal priority for loan funds is the financing of projects that will benefit low-income and moderate-income persons. Such benefits shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to, the financing of a project to construct or renovate a structure to be used for job training for low-income and moderate-income persons. Notwithstanding the foregoing, it shall be sufficient if the recipient of the loan makes a written commitment to the city, where such written commitment is not prohibited by law, that of the persons benefited by the project, at least 51 percent of them will be low-income and moderate-income persons. c. For the purposes of this section, the terms "low-income persons" and "moderate-income persons" shall be defined the same as they are periodically defined by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. (10) Selection of projects. The loan review committee shall act as agent for the city in determining the selection of projects to be financed. The city council shall have final approval of all such loans and all agreements made in connection therewith. (11) Responsibility and authority over final selection. None of the policies stated herein shall be construed to restrict the city council from having full responsibility and authority over the final project selection to be financed by the downtown development authority revolving loan fund. (12) Repayment. Each loan made shall provide for the repayment of all principal and interest according to the amortization schedule approved by the city council, as well as for the payment of collection costs, attorney's fees, court costs and penalties for late payment in such amounts as may be agreed upon by the parties. (13) Nonrefundable handling fee. Each completed loan application that is submitted for consideration must be accompanied by a nonrefundable handling fee in the amount established by ordinance that will cover the cost of credit checks, copies, postage, and other such costs that are incurred during the application process. (Code 1986, § 10-6; Ord. No. O-89-04-10, 4-24-1989; Ord. No. O-89-07-19, 7-24-1989; Ord. No. O-93-02-05, 2-22-1993; Ord. No. O-99-06-25, 6-24-1999; Ord. No. O-02-03-12, 3-21-2002; Ord. No. O-02-09-25, 9-19-2002; Ord. No. O-03-09-27, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-145. - Establishment of economic development revolving loan fund. (a) There is hereby established an economic development revolving loan fund for the city. The purpose of this fund is to assist in the creation and the retention of jobs, primarily for low-income and moderate-income persons, employed or to be employed by existing or start up businesses located in the city where involvement by the city through financial assistance to the existing or start up business is deemed necessary for the project's viability. (b) The loan fund shall be funded with the proceeds of federal grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development of the United States, community development block grants from the state, program or miscellaneous income, and such other funds as may be made available by the city for such loan fund. (c) The loan fund shall provide financial assistance for eligible activities, which shall include the following: (1) Provision of assistance to public or private nonprofit entities in order to finance activities that will result in the direct creation or employment for low-income or moderate-income persons. (2) Provision of assistance to public or private nonprofit entities in order to finance activities that will benefit low-income and moderate-income persons. Such benefits shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to, the financing of a project to construct or renovate a structure to be used for job training for low-income and moderate-income persons. (3) Such assistance may not be in the form of outright grants, although it may consist of loans, interest subsidies, guarantees, and the financing of such activities as the: a. Acquisition of real property; or b. Acquisition, construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or installation of buildings, except for buildings for the general conduct of government, such as: 1. Public facilities, site improvements, and utilities; and 2. Commercial, educational, or industrial buildings or structures or other commercial, educational, or industrial real property improvements. (4) Provision of assistance to private, for-profit entities, when the assistance is necessary or appropriate to carry out an economic development project. Such assistance may not be in the form of outright grants, although it may also consist of loans, interest subsidies, guarantees, or technical assistance, or a combination thereof. In addition, financial assistance to private, for-profit entities shall be contingent upon firm commitments of financial participation from other sources such as private financial institutions, or the private entities themselves; and must create or retain permanent jobs. (d) Passive income or real estate companies, lending and investment institutions, unregulated media such as newspapers and magazines, speculative ventures and charitable organizations shall not be eligible to receive loan funds. (e) Regulations regarding the terms and conditions of such loans from the revolving loan fund, the selection process for such loans, nonrefundable handling fees, repayment terms, interest rate terms, maximum loan amounts, and other such requirements shall be established by the city council pursuant to a resolution approved by the city council for that purpose. (f) All loans from the revolving loan fund shall be approved by the city council, and no proposed loan shall be presented to the city council for such approval unless such proposal has been reviewed and approved by the staff of the city department of community and economic development under procedures authorized in the resolution establishing the policies, terms, and conditions pursuant to which such loans may be granted. (Code 1986, § 10-7; Ord. No. O-93-12-41, 12-27-1993; Ord. No. O-94-01-08, 1-25-1994; Ord. No. O-94-02-09, 1-25-1994; Ord. No. O-99-06-26, 6-24-1999; Ord. No. O-02-09-25, 9-19-2002; Ord.
