(Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-110. - Additional activities prohibited; rationale and findings; exception. (a) Rationale and findings. Whereas, Article III, Section VI, Paragraph VII of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, delegates authority to counties and municipalities "for the purpose of regulating, restricting, or prohibiting the exhibition of nudity, partial nudity, or depictions of nudity in connection with the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages;" and, Whereas, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit has upheld a municipal ordinance prohibiting the serving or consumption of alcoholic beverages in adult entertainment establishments; and, Whereas, the Supreme Court of Georgia has upheld a municipal ordinance prohibiting the serving or consumption of alcoholic beverages in adult entertainment establishments; and, Whereas, among the undesirable community conditions identified with live nude entertainment and alcohol are depression of property values in the surrounding neighborhood, increased expenditure for the allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order; increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior, and acceleration of community blight; Daytona Grand, Inc. v. City of Daytona Beach, 490 F.3d 860 (11th Cir. 2007); 5634 East Hillsborough Ave., Inc. v. Hillsborough County, 2007 WL 2936211 (M.D. Fla. Oct. 4, 2007), affd, 2008 WL 4279670 (11th Cir. Sept. 18, 2008) (per curium); California v. LaRue, 409 U.S. 109 (1972); N Y. State Liquor Authority v. Bellanca, 452 U.S. 714 (1981); and, Whereas, the Supreme Court of Georgia, in Chambers d/b/a Neon Cowboy v. Peach County, Georgia, 266 Ga. 318, 467 S.E.2d 519 (1996), held that local governments may adopt ordinances designed to combat the undesirable secondary effects of sexually explicit businesses, and further held that a governing authority seeking to regulate adult entertainment establishments must have evidence of a relationship between the proposed regulation and the undesirable secondary effects it seeks to control. The Georgia Supreme Court further held in the same opinion that in passing its regulations, a local government may rely on the experience of other counties and municipalities to demonstrate such a relationship; and, Whereas, the United States Supreme Court, in City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S. 41 (1986), held that a local government may rely on the experience of other Cities in enacting legislation to regulate adult entertainment businesses; and, Whereas, Federal and State appellate courts, have previously held that before enacting an ordinance to combat undesirable secondary effects of adult entertainment, a legislative body is required to consider specific evidence of the undesirable secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments that it reasonably believes relevant to the interests it seeks to address by passing the ordinance; and, Whereas, based on the experiences of other municipalities and counties including, but not limited to, Fulton County, Georgia; Adams County, Colorado; New York City, New York; Indianapolis, Indiana; Dallas, Texas; Sandy Springs, Georgia; Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; City of St. Mary's, Georgia; Hamilton County, Tennessee; Amarillo, Texas; Rome, Georgia; Gwinnett County, Georgia; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; Manatee County, Florida; City of Garden Grove, California; Forth Worth, Texas; Houston, Texas; St. Cloud, Minnesota; Whittier, California; and the City of Los Angeles, California, which are found to be relevant to the problems faced by the City of Americus, the Mayor and City Council of the City of Americus note the documented negative economic, physical, and social impact adult entertainment businesses have on the community; and, Whereas, based upon the experience of other urban counties and municipalities, which experiences the mayor and city council of the city find are relevant to the problems faced by the city, and which do not vary greatly among generally comparable communities within this country, the mayor and city council of the city find that public nudity, under certain circumstances, particularly circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in adult entertainment establishments offering adult entertainment, begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. Flanigan's Enterprises, Inc. of Georgia et al. v. Fulton County, Georgia, 596 F.3d 1265, 2010 WL 520542 (11th Cir. 2010); and, Whereas, the mayor and city council of the city find and declare that nudity and sexual conduct and depiction thereof, coupled with alcohol in public places, encourages undesirable behavior and is not in the interest of public health, safety, and welfare; and, Whereas, the mayor and city council of the city have chosen to avoid the disturbances associated with mixing alcohol and nude dancing by means of a reasonable restriction upon establishments which sell spirituous or vinous liquors or malt or brewed beverages; and, Whereas, the ordinance furthers important governmental interests of reducing crime and protecting property values which are unrelated to the suppression of speech; and, Whereas, it is the intent of the mayor and city council of the city to enact an ordinance, narrowly tailored, sufficient to combat the undesirable secondary effects of the serving and consumption of alcoholic beverages at adult entertainment facilities; and, Whereas, it is not the intent of the mayor and city council of the city, in enacting this article to deny to any person the right to speech or expression protected by the United States or Georgia Constitutions, nor it is the intent to deny or restrict the rights of any adult to obtain or view any sexually oriented performance or materials protected by the United States or Georgia Constitutions, but to adopt a content neutral ordinance to combat the undesirable secondary effects of adult entertainment where alcoholic beverages are served or consumed; and, Whereas, this section is enacted to further the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city; Now, therefore, this section is hereby enacted to further such health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. (b) Activities prohibited; minimum clothing requirements; exception. (1) No person shall suffer or permit any person to engage in live conduct exposing to public view the person's genitals, pubic area, vulva, anus, anal cleft or cleavage or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola on the licensed premises. (2) It shall be unlawful for any employee of any licensee to consume alcoholic beverages on the premises of the licensee during such employees working hours. (3) No drugs or illegal or controlled substances of any kind shall be allowed, permitted, used, possessed or sold upon the premises of any licensee, and no gambling shall be allowed or permitted therein. (4) No licensee shall allow any person to engage in specified sexual activities on the licensed premises. (5) No licensee shall use any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the male or female pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva, and or genitals. (6) No licensee shall allow the holding, promotion, or sponsoring of any contest, promotion, special night, event, or any other activity where patrons of the licensed establishment are allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in this section. (7) Exception. Nothing contained in subsection (b) of this section shall apply to the premises of any theatre, concert hall, art center, museum, or similar establishment primarily devoted to the arts or theatrical performances, where the performances that are presented are expressing matters of serious literary, artistic, scientific, or political value. (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Secs. 6-113—6-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SOCIAL HOSTING
Sec. 6-131. - Findings and intent. The mayor and the city council finds and declares as follows: (a) In 2007, the U.S. Surgeon General issued a report entitled "The Surgeon General's Call to Action to Prevent and Reduce Underage Drinking," which can be found at http://www.surgeongeneral.gov/topics/underagedrinking/calltoaction.pdf. ("Surgeon General's Call to Action"). (b) "Early alcohol consumption by some young people will result in an alcohol use disorder—that is, they will meet diagnostic criteria for either alcohol abuse or dependence." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page four. (c) "A higher percentage of youth in 8th, 10th, and 12th grades used alcohol in the month prior to being surveyed than used tobacco or marijuana, the illicit drug most commonly used by adolescents." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 5. (d) Various surveys have found that: approximately ten percent of children who are nine to ten years old have started drinking alcoholic beverages; nearly 33 percent of youth start drinking alcoholic beverages before the age of 13; more than ten percent of youth who are 12 to 13 years old and over 33 percent of youth who are 14 to 15 years old reported drinking a whole alcoholic beverage in the year before they were surveyed, and the peak years of alcohol initiation are when youth are in 7th and 8th grades. Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page six. (e) While adolescents typically drink alcoholic beverages less often than adults, when they do drink alcoholic beverages, adolescents tend to drink more alcoholic beverages at each event than adults. Surgeon General's Call to Action, at pages 6-7. (f) Persons who are less than the age of 21 often possess or consume alcoholic beverages at social parties or gatherings held at or on private residences and other private property under control of a person who either has provided the alcoholic beverages or who knows or reasonably should know of such conduct, but fails to take steps to prevent it. (g) "Annually, about 5,000 people under age 21 die from alcohol-related injuries involving underage drinking." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page ten. (h) Underage drinking "[plays a significant role in risky sexual behavior, including unwanted, unintended, and unprotected sexual activity, and sex with multiple partners. Such behavior increases the risk of unplanned pregnancy and for contracting sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page ten. (i) Underage drinking increases the risk of physical and sexual assault." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page ten. (j) Underage drinking "can cause a range of physical consequences, from hangovers to death from alcohol poisoning." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 11. (k) Underage drinking, "can cause alterations in the structure and function of the developing brain, which continues to mature into the mid-to late twenties and may have consequences reaching far beyond adolescence." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 11. (l) Underage drinking, "creates secondhand effects that can put others at risk. Loud and unruly behavior, property destruction, unintentional injuries, violence, and even death because of underage alcohol use afflict innocent parties. For instance, about 45 percent of people who die in car crashes involving a drinking driver under the age of 21 are people other than the driver." Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 11. (m) Law enforcement agency responses to disturbances involving underage consumption of alcoholic beverages at parties or gatherings at or on private residences or other private property frequently require the use of extensive public resources. Further, when law enforcement personnel respond to such disturbances it limits their ability to respond to other service calls in the community, thereby placing the community at increased risk. Law enforcement is not currently reimbursed for their expenses when called to a party or gathering at or on a private residence or other private property. (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-132. - Title. This article shall be referred to as the "Americus Social Hosting Ordinance." (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-133. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, or as set forth in section 6-1 of this Code, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Dwelling unit means, without limitations, any of the following: (1) Any single and multi-family residence including, but not limited to, any apartment, cabin, condominium, duplex, house, or log cabin, and the land on which it is located, whether owned, leased, rented, or occupied for no compensation by the occupant or occupants; (2) Any mobile home and the land upon which the mobile home is located, whether or not rent is paid for the mobile home, for the land upon which the mobile home is located, or for both; (3) Any recreational vehicle, whether located on privately-owned or publicly-owned property, and whether rent or not is paid for the recreational vehicle, and the land upon the recreational vehicle is located. Gathering means an assembled group of people for the purpose of a social occasion or activity. Legal guardian is a person who is lawfully vested with the power and charged with the duty of taking care of an underage person. Other private property . (1) The term "other private property" includes the following locations: a. A hotel or motel room; b. An assembly hall or meeting room; c. A common room of a dwelling unit used for a party (e.g., a recreation room of an apartment building or a common room of a condominium complex); d. A site in a privately-owned campground; e. A privately-owned vacant lot; or f. Privately-owned land or real estate of any type. (2) Such locations constitute "other private property" under all of the following conditions: a. The location is occupied by one or more persons on a temporary or permanent basis; b. The location is occupied as a dwelling, permanent residence, or temporary residence, for a party or for any other social function; c. The location is owned, leased, rented, or used with or without compensation. Parent means any person who is a natural parent, an adoptive parent, a foster parent, a step-parent, or who a person who stands in loco parentis. Party means a gathering or event at which two or more persons assemble or gather for a social occasion or activity. Person who has a right of possession means, with respect to a private residence or other private property, as follows: (1) Owner of the dwelling unit, private residence, or other private property; (2) The record owner of the title to the property as of the time of the party regardless of where that person currently resides; (3) Tenant or lessee of the dwelling unit, private residence, or other private property; (4) Landlord of another person who has a right of possession in the dwelling unit, private residence, or other private property; (5) The person or persons who are in charge of the dwelling unit, private residence, or other private property; or (6) Social host. Private residence means the following: (1) A dwelling unit, whether occupied on a temporary basis, whether occupied as a dwelling or for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without compensation, (2) Any other item on the same land parcel as the dwelling unit, which includes, but is not limited to any of the following: an animal pen, an animal shed, a bam, a boat dock, a boat house, a cabana, an equipment shed, a free-standing office, a garage, a gazebo, a granary, a hot tub, a hunting cabin, a corn crib, a sauna, a stable, a studio, a swimming pool, a private office, a shed, a silo, a tent, a tool shed, a tree-house, a tractor, or a vehicle of any type or nature; (3) Other items or areas accompanying or on the same land parcel as the dwelling unit, whether improved or unimproved, such as a yard (whether fenced or unfenced), patio, outdoor grilling or eating area, open fields, jetty, pier, dock, or lake shore; (4) Water bodies contiguous to or on the same land parcel as a dwelling unit, such as a basin, bayou, brook, creek, dam, lagoon, lake, marsh, pond, river, stream, or swamp. Reasonable steps means steps that include, but are not limited to: (1) Controlling access to alcoholic beverages; (2) Controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages; (3) Verifying the legal minimum drinking age of persons at the party or gathering by inspecting drivers licenses or other government-issued identification cards all of those persons in attendance; and (4) Supervising and monitoring the activities of underage persons at the party or gathering. Social host means: (1) The person or persons who organize, supervise, officiate, conduct or control a party or gathering at or on or at a dwelling unit, a private residence, or other private property owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by that person or those persons; (2) The person or persons receiving money or any other type of consideration for granting access to a party or gathering at or on a dwelling unit, a private residence, or other private property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by that person. Underage person means any person under the age of 21, (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-134. - Prohibition. (a) It shall be a violation of this article for any person who has a right of possession of a dwelling unit, a private residence, or other private property to knowingly host, permit, or allow a party or gathering to take place or continue at or on such private residence or other private property if any underage person at the party or gathering possesses or consumes any alcoholic beverage and the person knows or reasonably should know, after taking all reasonable steps to prevent alcoholic beverage possession or consumption by the underage person, that the underage person is possessing or consuming any alcoholic beverage at the party or gathering. (b) It shall be a violation of this article for a parent or legal guardian to allow any underage person under the care of that parent or legal guardian to allow to attend a party or other social gathering if that parent or legal guardian knows or reasonably should know that the underage person will possess or consume any alcoholic beverage at that party or social event. (c) It is the duty of any person having a right of possession of a dwelling unit, a private residence, or other private property, who knowingly hosts, permits or allows a party or gathering at or on the dwelling unit, the private residence, or other private property, to take all reasonable steps to prevent the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages by any underage person at the party or gathering. A breach of this duty shall be a violation of this article. (d) Any violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23, as amended, shall also be a violation of this article. (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-135. - Protected activities. (a) Nothing in this article should be interpreted to prohibit legally protected practices held at or on a dwelling unit, a private residence, or other private property that includes the possession and/or consumption of alcohol by persons under the age of 21: (1) As part of religious practices on private property; or (2) For medical purposes pursuant to a prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in this state and the consumption occurs on private property pursuant to and in accordance with that prescription; or (3) When the parent or legal guardian of the underage person physically gives the alcohol to that underage person when in their own residence and while in their presence and as permitted under O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23, as amended. (b) Notwithstanding the exemptions for protected activities found in section 6-135(a) of this article, if an underage person leaves said private property intoxicated where he or she was provided the alcohol and is found in public, then said furnishers of alcoholic beverages to that underage person shall be held responsible in the same manner as furnishers of alcoholic beverages to underage persons at non-protected activities. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-137. - Enforcement authority. The city police department, the city attorney, and any other person designated by the mayor and the city council may exercise any enforcement powers provided by law. (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017) Sec. 6-138. - Enforcement remedies. (a) Criminal penalties. (1) Consistent with O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10(a), the first violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 shall also be a violation of this article. Any person who violates O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23 shall be punished by a fine of not more than the maximum fine for which the Georgia Statutes provide for a violation of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. (2) Any parent who violates section 6-134(b) of this article may be assessed the maximum penalty for which the City Ordinances and Georgia Statutes provide for a misdemeanor. (b) Civil penalties. (1) Any person who violates section 6-134(a), (b) and/or (c) of this article has committed a public nuisance constituting an immediate threat to public health, safety and welfare, warranting summary abatement and is guilty of a civil violation. (2) On the violation of section 6-134(a), (b) and/or (c), the violator shall be assessed a civil penalty for each such violation of not more than the maximum allowed by the city ordinances and the Georgia State Statutes. (3) Violations of section 6-134 of this article shall be noticed by citation, issued by the city police department. The citation shall also give notice of the right to request a hearing to challenge the validity of the citation, the time for requesting that hearing, and that the person has a right to appeal. (Ord. No. O-2017-4, 4-20-2017)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-6.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Bird sanctuary; constituted. The city as now constituted or as may hereafter be constituted, together with all property belonging to it or under its jurisdiction, is hereby established as a bird sanctuary. (Code 1962, § 4-1; Code 1986, § 4-1) Sec. 10-2. - Injuring, molesting or killing wild fowl and other birds. It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to trap, hunt, kill, shoot, or attempt to shoot, wound, injure, abuse or molest any wild fowl or other bird or to rob bird nests; provided, however, if starlings, English sparrows or any other kind of bird are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to the health or property of the citizens of the city in the opinion of the public health authorities, it shall be so declared by such authorities. Then such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by said health authorities. (Code 1962, § 4-6; Code 1986, § 4-2) Sec. 10-3. - Cruelty to animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to overload, cruelly treat, maim, bruise, abuse, mistreat, torture, deprive of necessary sustenance, ill use or otherwise wrongfully deal with any domestic animal or fowl or otherwise treat such domestic creatures in a harsh, inhumane or unreasonable manner. Shelter for horses, cattle or other domestic animals shall be provided to protect such creatures against inclement weather and extreme temperatures. (Code 1962, § 4-4; Code 1986, § 4-3) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. Sec. 10-4. - Poisoning animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to put out or cause to be put out any poison within the city for the killing of any domestic animal. (Code 1962, § 4-5; Code 1986, § 4-4) Sec. 10-5. - Livestock running at large; impounding; sale; redemption by owner; fees. (a) No horse, mule, cow, hog, goat, or other animal used or fit either for food or labor, shall be permitted to run at large upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds in the city. Any such animal found at large within the city shall be taken up and impounded by the impounding officer, or other officer of the city. (b) Each animal so impounded shall be sold by the finance director or his designee, at public outcry, after an advertisement of at least five days in the newspaper in which the city printing is published, giving the time and place of sale. The proceeds of said sale, after paying all costs and expenses thereof, and of taking up and keeping such animal, shall be deposited in the city treasury for six months to await the claim of the owner; at the expiration of which time, if there is no claimant therefor, it shall be used for general city purposes. (c) The owner of such animal may, at any time before the sale, reclaim such stock by paying all costs and expenses of impounding and keeping the same. The fee for taking up and impounding any such animal shall be as established by ordinance, and for keeping the same shall be as established by ordinance. (Code 1962, § 4-2; Code 1986, § 4-5) Sec. 10-6. - Swine prohibited. No person shall keep any swine within the city. (Code 1962, § 4-3; Code 1986, § 4-6) Sec. 10-7. - Manner of keeping of animals and fowl—Sanitation of enclosures; nuisance. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or possess any animal or fowl in the city in such manner as to create an unsanitary or obnoxious condition, or to become noisy, offensive or a nuisance to the neighbors or citizens of the city, or to disturb the peace of the city. (b) Should a complaint arise from the causes referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the person involved will be properly notified and given adequate time to either dispose of the animal or fowl or eliminate the cause of the complaint. (Code 1962, § 4-7; Code 1986, § 4-7) Sec. 10-8. - Same—Pens or enclosures within 300 feet of building. It shall be unlawful for any person to build any pen, coop or enclosure for animals or fowl, or to permit any animal or fowl to be kept, maintained or grazed, within 300 feet of any house or other building where people reside or work. This section shall not apply to any house or other building on the same premises where such animal or fowl is kept or maintained, nor shall it apply to dogs or cats kept as household pets, but it shall apply to dog kennels, where more than one dog is kept. (Code 1962, § 4-11; Code 1986, § 4-8) Sec. 10-9. - Vicious animals. It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person to maintain or harbor within the city a manifestly vicious animal unless the same is securely, but humanely, confined or restrained in such manner as to prevent such animal from attacking or biting a person or another animal. It shall be prima facie evidence of viciousness if an animal, without provocation, fiercely attacks or bites a person or animal not on the owner's premises. (Code 1962, § 4-8; Code 1986, § 4-9) Sec. 10-10. - Dead animals—Duty of owner to remove from public ways. The owner of dead animals upon the public streets and ways shall remove the same so as not to constitute a nuisance. If the owner fails to do so the city shall remove and dispose of such carcass, and charge the cost of such removal and disposition to the owner of the carcass, if known. (Code 1962, § 4-9; Code 1986, § 4-10) Sec. 10-11. - Same—Removal from private property. When any dead animal is found on private property, the owner of the dead animal or the owner of the premises upon which such animal is located shall remove the same immediately at such owner's own cost. Upon failure to do so within a reasonable time the city shall remove same, the cost to be collected from the offending party. (Code 1962, § 4-10; Code 1986, § 4-11) Sec. 10-12. - Nuisances prohibited and defined. (a) For the purposes of this section, the term "nuisance" means an act or situation caused by or contributed to by an animal with or without the permission of the animal's owner or keeper, which act or situation substantially interferes with the rights of citizens to enjoyment of life or property or unreasonably annoys humans or endangers the life or health of persons or other animals. Such a nuisance shall include, but shall not be limited to the following acts by an animal: (1) Molesting or threatening to molest pedestrians; (2) Chasing vehicles; (3) Causing loss or damage to the person or property of someone other than the owner or keeper of the animal; or (4) Continually and repeatedly howling, barking, whining or otherwise making noises which cause unreasonable annoyance, disturbance or discomfort to neighbors or others. (b) Where a nuisance is a public nuisance, an action or a proceeding to abate same, may be brought in the municipal court for the city by the appropriate city official or officials. (c) Where such nuisance is a private nuisance, a proceeding to abate such nuisance may be brought in the municipal court for the city by the party or parties aggrieved thereby. Such court shall have all authority granted pursuant to city ordinances and state law to order abatement of such nuisance. (Code 1962, § 4-22; Code 1986, § 4-30; Ord. No. O-90-09-22, 9-24-1990) Sec. 10-13. - Control and removal of animal waste. (a) The owner or custodian of any animal shall immediately remove any feces deposited by such animal upon the public sidewalks, public streets, public parks, or other public property in the City of Americus, or upon any private property within the City of Americus not under the use and control of said owner or custodian. The owner of any such animal, or the custodian of any such animal, shall be in possession of materials to remove feces left by such animal at any time during which the animal is not on property under the use and control of said owner or custodian. (b) Violation of this section shall be punishable upon conviction by a fine of not less than $75.00, nor more than $500.00. Each act in violation of this section shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. No. O-10-05-18, 5-20-2010) Secs. 10-14—10-42. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 10-43. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Animal control officer means an employee of the police department of the city whose duties specifically include enforcement of the provisions of this article. Dangerous dog means any dog or breed of dog that, according to records of an appropriate authority: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation, on public or private property; or (2) Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification; or (3) Any dog breed which, notwithstanding the records of an appropriate authority with respect to any particular dog, has been determined, by proper resolution of the governing body of the city, to be a dangerous dog breed in accord with the provisions of section 10-67.1 of the City Code. Dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breeds means a breed or breeds of dogs which the governing body of the City of Americus has determined, by resolution, to be a breed which consists primarily of dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs. Dog control officer means the chief of police of the city, and such employees of the animal control division of the police department acting under his supervision and control. Owner means any natural persons or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust, owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dog or cat within the territorial boundaries of the city. Potentially dangerous dog means either: (1) any dog that has, without provocation, bitten a human being while on public or private property; or (2) any dog that has been determined, by proper resolution of the governing body of the city, to be a member of a dangerous dog breed or a potentially dangerous dog breed in accord with the provisions of section 10-67.1 of the City Code. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, while on the owner's property, securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Rabies control officer means an employee of the county board of health whose specific duties include enforcement of the rabies control rules and regulations of the county. Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency, records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state or local court; or records maintained by the dog control officer pursuant to this article. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. (Code 1986, § 4-20; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990; Ord. No. O-09-07-22, 7-23-2009) Sec. 10-44. - Restraint of dogs and prohibition against nuisances. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of any dog to allow the same to run upon the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city, unless said dog is accompanied by its owner or other person having charge of said dog, in which event said dog must be tied with a cord or chain of sufficient strength to hold such dog. (b) No person owning or having custody of any female dog shall permit such female dog off the premises of the owner or person having control of such dog when dog shall be in heat, unless the same is under control and attached to a leash, as herein provided. (c) Whenever a dog is allowed to run free, in violation of this section, impoundment of the animal is authorized. Upon identification of the owner, citation shall be issued for violation of this section. (d) The owner and keeper of each animal within the city shall keep it from becoming a nuisance and from endangering or injuring any person. As a consequence thereof, it shall be the duty of every owner or keeper of any animal to exercise reasonable care with respect to said animal, and to take all reasonable steps and precautions necessary to protect other persons, property and animals from injury, loss or damage which might be caused by or arise from such animal's behavior, regardless of whether such behavior is motivated by mischievousness, playfulness or ferocity. If the owner or keeper of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible for ensuring compliance with this section. (e) Whenever an animal is kept in such a manner as constitutes a nuisance as defined under either city ordinances or state law, a proceeding to abate the nuisance may be brought by the party aggrieved, pursuant to section 10-12. Such an action may also be brought by the city pursuant to said section. An animal found by the court to constitute a nuisance may be impounded by the city if the owner, after reasonable opportunity to do so, fails to abate the nuisance as ordered by the court. (Code 1986, § 4-21; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990; Ord. No. O-90-09-22, 9-24-1990) Sec. 10-45. - Inoculation; registration; tagging of animals. (a) All dogs and cats shall be inoculated against rabies in accordance with the procedures set forth in the rabies control rules and regulations of the county, as promulgated and from time to time amended by the county board of health, which by reference are expressly incorporated as part of this section as if fully set out herein. Violation of said rules and regulations may be enforced by the rabies control officer in the municipal court of the city, upon citation, as an offense against the city. (b) The numbered vaccination tag, issued by a licensed veterinarian upon inoculation, shall be attached to a collar or harness and worn by the animal at all times. Every dog found roaming or running free, whether tagged or untagged, shall be impounded; every tagged or untagged cat found roaming or running free shall be impounded. If a tagged animal is impounded, and it is found not to be registered or its current registration has expired, the owner may be cited for violation of this section. (Code 1986, § 4-22; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990) Sec. 10-46. - Impoundment and actions related thereto. All animals impounded by the city shall be held in a humane manner and in accord with an agreement between the city and the Sumter Humane Society, Inc., or some other entity as may from time to time be determined and established by action of the city council. (Code 1986, § 4-23; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990; Ord. No. O-90-09-22, 9-24-1990) Secs. 10-47—10-65. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 10-66. - Penalties. Violations of this division shall be punished by the issuance of a state warrant pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28. (Code 1986, § 4-26; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990) Sec. 10-67. - Dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs. (a) Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the dog control officer's jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. Whenever the dog control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, notice shall be given the dog's owner in writing by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification or reclassification. Such notices shall be deemed complete upon mailing. (b) The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address. (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's finding that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog before the governing authority. (4) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this section on the day after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing. (c) When the governing authority receives a request for a hearing it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The governing authority shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time and place of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and in addition thereto the governing authority shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the governing authority may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the governing authority shall notify the owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify it is effective on the third day following the date of receipt by the owner. (d) Issuance of a certificate of registration shall be made pursuant to the following: (1) Subject to the requirements of this section, the dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or if the dog control officer finds sufficient evidence of: a. A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. b. The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the premises. The sign required to be posted must substantially conform to the design provided by the department of natural resources. c. Payment to the city of a fee in the amount of $50.00, to defray the cost of administering and enforcing this section. (2) In addition, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present evidence to the dog control officer of: a. A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00, issued by an insurer authorized to transact business within the state insuring the owner of the dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or b. A surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00, or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state payable to any person or persons injured by the dangerous dog. (e) Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of an annual renewal of a certificate of registration, a dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this article. (f) Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the local government does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsection (d) of this section are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. (g) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, if unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (h) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. (i) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register the dog in the manner provided by this article within 30 days after becoming a resident. (j) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from one jurisdiction to another within the state shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in the manner provided by this article within 30 days after becoming a resident of the new jurisdiction. (k) The fee to be paid to the city for a certificate of registration for a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25 shall be as established by ordinance. (Code 1986, § 4-24; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990) Sec. 10-67.1. - Determination by city council of dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breeds. (a) In making a determination that a particular dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed, the governing body shall undertake the following steps: (1) In the event that the dog control officer receives a report or obtains other information which leads the dog control officer to believe that a particular dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed, such information shall be provided to the city manager of the city. (2) The city manager shall review all evidence and other information submitted by the dog control officer regarding the particular dog breed involved and, in the event that the city manager determines that a particular dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed, the city manager shall report such fact, and the information and evidence supporting such fact, to the governing body of the city. (3) Upon receipt of such report from the city manager, the governing body of the city shall, upon recommendation of the public safety committee, hold a public hearing on the issue of whether or not the particular dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed. Notice of such public hearing shall be published at least once per week for the two calendar weeks immediately prior to the date of the public hearing. Such published notice shall appear in the legal organ of the city, and the cost of such publication shall be paid by the city. (4) At the public hearing, the findings and evidence that the dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed shall be presented to the governing body by the city manager or his or her designee. Upon presentation of such evidence, persons desiring to speak in favor of declaring the particular dog breed a dangerous or potentially dangerous breed shall have ten minutes to make their presentations to the governing body as to why such dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous breed. At the conclusion of such presentations, persons opposed to declaring the particular dog breed a dangerous or potentially dangerous breed shall have ten minutes to present evidence as to why such dog breed is not a dangerous or potentially dangerous breed. At the conclusion of the evidence, the governing body shall consider all evidence presented and shall determine whether the particular dog breed is a dangerous or potentially dangerous breed based upon the evidence and argument presented at the public hearing. Such determination shall be made by the governing body in the form of a resolution declaring that such breed is either a dangerous or a potentially dangerous dog breed. (5) For purposes of such a determination, the governing body of the city shall be required to establish that a particular breed is dangerous or potentially dangerous by reviewing evidence presented to the governing body regarding the dog breed in question, including the dog breed's propensity for inflicting severe injuries on humans without provocation or aggressively biting, attacking or endangering the safety of humans without provocation, or that the breed is likely, based upon the characteristics of the breed, to do so. The final determination as to whether a particular breed is a potentially dangerous dog breed or a dangerous dog breed shall be made by the governing body of the city based upon the evidence presented to the governing body at the public hearing required in accord with the Code section. (b) In the event that the governing body of the city adopts a resolution declaring a particular dog breed as a dangerous dog breed, the provisions of section 10-67 and section 10-68 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Americus which are applicable to dangerous dogs shall be applicable to that particular dog breed. (c) In the event that the governing body of the city adopts a resolution declaring a particular dog breed as a potentially dangerous dog breed, the provisions of section 10-67 and section 10-68 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Americus which are applicable to potentially dangerous dogs shall be applicable to that particular dog breed. (Ord. No. O-09-07-22, 7-23-2009; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 10-68. - Possession without certification; keeping dog in violation of certification; failure to post clearly visible warning sign; confiscation and impoundment; destruction of animal. (a) It shall be unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with this article. (b) It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. (c) It shall be unlawful for a potentially dangerous dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (d) It shall be unlawful for the owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog to fail to post a warning sign on the premises where a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is housed or kept by its owner in accordance with this article. The warning sign shall give notice to the public of the housing or keeping of a dog or a breed of dog which has been declared to be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog. (e) It shall be the duty of the dog control officer, and any person under his employ, to impound the dog if: (1) The owner does not secure a certificate of registration in accordance with this article. (2) The owner does not secure liability insurance or meet the bond requirement of this article. (3) The owner does not keep the dog within a proper enclosure or permits the dog to roam or run free. (f) Any dog impounded under the provisions of this section shall be returned to the owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article and upon payment of reasonable impoundment costs, as fixed by a schedule approved by the governing authority, as from time to time amended. Notice of impoundment under this section shall be given the owner, in writing, by certified mail, at his last known address. This notice shall state that if the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within 20 days from receipt of such notice, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner; provided, however, no dog shall have been destroyed under this section unless it has been held a full 20 days, exclusive of the date of giving notice. (g) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be solely liable for any injury to or death of a person caused such dog. (h) Under no circumstances shall the city or any employee or official of the city which enforces or fails to enforce the provisions of this article be held liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by a dog: (1) That has been identified as being a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog; (2) Which the city has failed to identify as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (3) Which has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog but has not been kept or restrained in the manner described in this section; or (4) Whose owner has not maintained insurance coverage or a surety bond as required in this section. (Code 1986, § 4-25; Ord. No. O-90-02-06, 2-26-1990; Ord. No. O-09-07-22, 7-23-2009) Sec. 10-69. - Penalty for violation of city ordinances related to dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breeds. Notwithstanding the provisions of section 10-66 of the City Code, any violation of the provisions of the City Code, related to dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breeds, shall be punished in accord with the provisions of section 1-8 of the City Code. In addition to the penalty provisions of section 1-8 of the City Code, any person owning a dog breed which has been declared as a dangerous or a potentially dangerous dog breed who violates the provisions of the City Code relative to dangerous dog breeds or potentially dangerous dog breeds shall have his or her dangerous or potentially dangerous dog breed immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or another person authorized by the dog control officer and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health and, thereafter, the dog which is a member of the dangerous dog breed or a member of the potentially dangerous dog breed may be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Ord. No. O-09-07-22, 7-23-2009)

div.head: Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Advisory board for physically disabled access. (a) There is hereby established an advisory board to review plans for major construction projects in the city in connection with access to such buildings by disabled individuals. Such advisory board shall consist of the following persons: (1) Not less than three physically disabled residents of the city appointed by the city council who have an interest in providing information and in put regarding construction of buildings in such a manner so as to ensure, to the greatest extent reasonably possible, access to such buildings for physically disabled individuals; (2) Two other persons appointed by the city council. (b) The persons appointed to the board shall serve staggered term such that one person shall be appointed for an initial term of one year, two persons will be appointed for an initial term of two years, and two persons will be appointed for an initial term of three years. Thereafter, all persons shall be appointed for three-year terms. Persons appointed to the board may succeed themselves and shall serve until their successor is appointed and qualified. Each member of the board shall serve at the pleasure of the city council and may be removed at any time by the city council with or without cause. (c) The members of the board shall elect one of their number as chairman and one of their number as vice-chairman. The board shall also elect a secretary of the board who may or may not be a member of the board. All meetings of the board shall be subject to the state's open meetings statutes. (d) The board shall have the following duties and responsibilities: (1) All major construction project plans within the city shall be referred to the board for review in connection with access for the disabled to the building or buildings that are the subject of such construction plans; (2) The board shall make recommendations to the city building official 's office as to any suggested changes in major construction plans so as to increase or enhance disabled persons' access to and from such buildings; (3) The board shall be authorized to make such other additional recommendations regarding disabled persons' access as it may deem appropriate. (e) For the purpose of this section, the term "major construction" shall be deemed to include construction of commercial buildings to be undertaken within the limits of the city for which a certificate of occupancy is or will be acquired upon completion of such construction in accord with current ordinances. (f) Nothing in this section shall require the building official nor any builder or owner of a building to comply with any recommendations made by the advisory board, but such recommendations of the advisory board should be taken into consideration by the city building official in connection with approval by the building official of major construction project plans in the city. All recommendations of the board shall be submitted to the city building official's office within five business days of the board's receipt of major construction project plans from the building official's office. (g) Nothing herein shall be deemed to conflict with any provision of any code adopted within the city, as such codes may now exist or be hereafter amended. (Code 1986, § 5-8; Ord. No. O-97-11-38, 11-20-1997) Sec. 14-2. - Stormwater management. (a) Plans required. Stormwater management plans shall be required for a development before any building permits may be issued. Those developments include: (1) Any commercial, industrial, school, church or places of religious worship, recreational facilities, and private clubs and golf courses, where the development will disturb or alter more than 1.1 acres of land area. (2) Any subdivision, multifamily, or group housing development where at least ten dwelling units are proposed. (3) Any other development where the building official with consultation with the utilities director deems appropriate because of location, terrain, grade, or any other possible stormwater problem. (b) Application procedure. Two copies of the stormwater management plans shall be submitted to the building risk management office. These plans shall bear the signature/seal of a registered or certified professional in engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, land surveying, or erosion and sedimentation control. The building official will forward one copy to the city utilities director for review and approval, and the other copy shall be retained in the project construction files within the building official's office. The utilities director will notify the building official of approval or disapproval of the stormwater management plans as designed within seven working days. (c) Standards for stormwater management. (1) A combination of storage and controlled release of stormwater runoff shall be required when the proposed development shall increase the peak rate of runoff by more than one percent for a 25-year frequency storm; (2) Should the peak rate of stormwater runoff from the site exceed the permitted peak release rate, then on-site retention or detention shall be required. All retention or detention facilities shall be designed for all intensities up to and including 25-year frequency for all duration of rainfall. The peak runoff rate from the site after the development shall not be greater than the permitted peak release rate; and (3) The retention or detention storage to be provided shall be calculated on the basis of the 25-year frequency rainfall, as published by the National Weather Service for the affected site. The retention or detention volume required shall be that necessary to handle the runoff of the 25-year rainfall for any and all durations from the proposed development, less than that volume discharged during the same duration at the approved release rate as specified in subsection (c)(1) of this section. (d) Inspection. Inspection of the site for plan compliance shall be made periodically by the utilities director of the city. Any plan variation noted by the utilities director shall be addressed in writing to the developer of the site or contractor in charge and a copy sent to the city building official for filing with the project documents. (e) Permit. A stormwater management plan approved by the city utilities director shall constitute a permit that will satisfy the requirements of this section. (Code 1986, § 5-79.1; Ord. No. O-97-03-06, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-99-03-11, 3-18-1999) Sec. 14-3. - Site plans applicable to more than one city ordinance. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code to the contrary, in the event that a site plan must be submitted to the city council in connection with, or in compliance with, the requirements of the city's wetland protection ordinance, the city's flood damage prevention ordinance, the city's soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance, or the city's groundwater recharge protection ordinance, and in the event that such site plan be deemed sufficient by the permitting officer to satisfy the requirements of more than one of said ordinances, then, at the request of the permit applicant, the permitting officer shall be authorized to waive the submission of additional site plans for such project and may use such site plan as submitted in connection with the granting or denying of permit applications as to any or all of such ordinances. (Code 1986, § 5-9; Ord. No. O-99-11-42, 11-18-1999) Sec. 14-4. - Permit for construction of ponds. (a) Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to collect or pond, by the construction of any dam or otherwise, the waters of any branch, creek or stream, or any other waters within the city in any fish pond, mill pond, bathing pond, or for any other purpose, or cause the same to be so ponded and collected, or to maintain and keep any such pond after the same is constructed without first receiving a written permit for such construction and maintenance from the building official. (b) Permit requests; procedure; fees. (1) Filing with building official required. In order to acquire a permit for the construction and maintenance of a pond as aforesaid, the applicant must file a request in writing with the building official consisting of an original and four copies setting out in detail the location of the pond, the waters to be impounded, the purpose for which the impoundment is requested, the size of the pond, and the method of preparation to be used on the pond site before impoundment of waters. (2) Engineer's plat of survey to be filed with request. There shall be attached to each copy of the request an engineer's plat of survey showing the height, length, and width of the proposed dam, its relative location to the nearest street or highway affected thereby, also a topographic survey of the area that is to be covered by the impoundment. (3) Filing fee. There shall be filed with each request a fee in the amount established by ordinance by check made payable to the city. (4) Building official to forward request to health department within certain time. The building official shall within five days submit the all three copies to the county health department, which shall in turn review the request and the attached plans and specifications, and enter a recommendation regarding construction of the proposed pond. (5) Recommendation of health department to building official; time limit. The county health department shall within ten days from receiving the request, return two copy to the building official with the recommendation stamped on the face thereof, one copy of which will remain on file with the building official. (6) Issuance by building official. Upon direction of the city council the requested permit shall be issued by the building official. (Code 1962, § 12-5; Code 1986, § 5-5) Sec. 14-5. - Permit for diverting natural flow of water. It shall be unlawful for any person to place any obstruction in any stream or drain in the city in such a manner as to divert the natural flow of the water therein, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city council. (Code 1962, § 12-4; Code 1986, § 5-6) Secs. 14-6—14-28. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TECHNICAL CODES[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— State building code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 14-29. - Codes adopted. (a) (1) In accord with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, all of the codes referenced in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(i)(I)—(9)(B)(i)(VIII), as modified pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(ii), or as amended or revised as provided in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-23, are hereby adopted by reference. The codes adopted pursuant to this subsection include the following: a. International Building Code, with Georgia amendments; b. National Electrical Code (NFPA), with Georgia amendments; c. International Fuel Gas Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments; d. International Mechanical Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments; e. International Plumbing Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments; f. International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (ICC), with Georgia amendments; g. International Energy Conservation Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments; h. International Fire Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments. (2) In accord with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, the following codes are also adopted and shall be applicable within the corporate limits of the city: a. International Property Maintenance Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments, and as amended; b. International Existing Building Code (ICC), with Georgia amendments; c. National Green Building Standard Code, with Georgia amendments. (b) The building official of the city shall maintain current copies of such codes on file in his office and such codes shall be available for inspection and review by the public during regular business hours of the building official. Such codes are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions of such codes shall be controlling within the city. (c) The following shall be applicable to such codes: (1) Such codes shall be enforced by the building official and, where applicable, the chief of the fire department, or his designee. (2) Any reference to the term "board of adjustments and appeals" in said codes shall mean the zoning board of appeals of the city as established by section 94-86, and such zoning board of appeals shall have the same powers, duties and authority given to the board of adjustments and appeals in such incorporated codes. (3) In hearing and deciding appeals from decision of the building official or the chief of the fire department made pursuant to their authority under the state minimum codes, the rules of procedure of the adopted codes shall apply; provided, however, that the rules for appointment and terms of office for the appeals board in said adopted codes shall not be applicable to the zoning board of appeals. (4) The building official shall have the authority to render interpretations of the City's Code of Ordinances and the adopted state codes and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the applications of the provisions thereof. (d) Any person charged with the violation of any provision of any of such codes, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (e) Permit and inspection fees. There are hereby established certain permit and inspection fees to be charged by the city for building permits, electrical permits, plumbing permits, mechanical (heating and air conditioning) permits, for moving of buildings or structures within the city limits, and for demolition of buildings or structures within the city limits. Such permit and inspection fees shall be paid to the city in accord with the various provisions of this chapter and the various codes previously adopted by reference in accord with the provisions of this chapter. (f) Building permit and inspection fees. (1) A building permit and inspection fee shall be computed based upon the value of all structures and buildings being built, and such valuation shall be based upon the building valuation data as issued by the Southern Building Code Congress International as of the time of application for said permit. The valuation data actually used in computing the valuation of the structures and buildings shall be 75 percent of the total valuation computed using the building valuation data as issued by the Southern Building Code Congress International. Once the valuation of said structures and buildings is computed, such valuation shall be used in determining the actual building permit and inspection fees. (2) The building permit and inspection fees for the city are as established by ordinance. (3) The building permit and inspection fee for the moving of any building or structure into, out of or within the city shall be as established by ordinance. (4) The building permit and inspection fee for the demolition of a building or structure within the city shall be as established by ordinance. (5) The building permit and inspection fee for the installation of any tent for public gatherings within the city shall be as established by ordinance. (g) Electrical permit fees and inspection fees. There are hereby established electrical permit fees and inspection fees to be paid for work done within the city pursuant to division 2 of this article, and the fees for such electrical permits and inspections are as established by ordinance. (h) Plumbing permit and inspection fees. There are hereby established plumbing permit fees and inspection fees to be paid for work done within the city pursuant to division 3 of this article, and the fees for such plumbing permits and inspections are as established by ordinance. (i) Mechanical permit and inspection fees. There are hereby established mechanical permit and inspection fees for permits and inspections in the amounts established by ordinance. (j) The building official of the city shall be authorized to carry out such inspections and issue such permits as may be required by this Code, but he may only issue such permits upon the payment of the fees as herein provided. Such building official may make such inspections and investigations, notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code providing for any other person or entity to make such inspections. Pursuant to the authority contained in 1996 Georgia Laws (Act No. 1046), page 1632, § 3, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26(d), relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, shall not be applicable within the city. (k) Permit and inspection fees required by this Code shall be paid for prior to obtaining the permits provided for in this Code. Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is begun or initiated prior to obtaining the required permit, the fees required by this Code shall be paid and, as a penalty for the failure to secure a permit, an additional amount equal to the original fee required shall be paid to the city; however, the payment of such penalty shall not relieve any person from otherwise complying with the requirements of this Code in carrying out the work for which the permit is required, nor shall the payment of any such penalty relieve such person from any other penalties prescribed in this Code relating to the work performed. (Code 1962, §§ 5-1—5-1.3, 8-1, 11-1, 11-6, 17-1; Code 1986, § 5-1; Ord. No. O-88-03-10, 3-28-1988; Ord. No. O-92-01-05, 1-28-1992; Ord. No. O-92-03-13, 3-23-1992; Ord. No. O-93-02-06, 2-22-1993; Ord. No. O-94-07-26, 7-21-1994; Ord. No. O-94-10-36, 10-27-1994; Ord. No. O-94-11-38, 11-28-1994; Ord. No. O-95-11-36, 11-30-1995; Ord. No. O-96-09-40, 9-19-1996; Ord. No. O-97-03-07, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-98-06-24, 6-18-1998; Ord. No. O-05-01-04, 1-20-2005; Ord. No. O-2013-31, 11-21-2013) Sec. 14-30. - Building permits. (a) Work plan prerequisite to issuance. No building or other structure or part thereof shall hereafter be constructed, enlarged or altered until a plan of the proposed work, together with a statement of the materials to be used, shall have been submitted to the building official and fire department representative. If in accordance with the provisions herein contained, the building official shall issue a permit for the proposed construction. (b) Removal of nonpermitted, nonconforming structures. Structures hereafter erected without permit, or not in conformity with this chapter, shall be removed and the violator prosecuted. (c) Permit to precede work; compliance with technical codes required. No building shall be constructed, enlarged, altered or moved until a building permit has been obtained from the building official, and such official shall not issue such permit if the proposed construction, enlargement, alteration or moving would in any manner violate the housing, building, fire, plumbing, electrical, heating and air conditioning, zoning, or subdivision codes or regulations or any other codes or ordinances now or hereafter adopted by the city. (d) Application. All applications for building permits shall be made in duplicate upon forms provided for this purpose by the office of the building official with payment in the amount necessary to cover the cost of such building permit, together with all other exhibits and information as provided and set forth in section 94-28. (e) Persons responsible. The persons responsible for obtaining permits called for herein shall be the person actually doing the construction work or the person in charge of the construction work regardless of whether such person doing the actual construction work or in charge of the actual construction work is the owner, lessee or contractor. (f) Display. All building permits called for in this section shall be displayed in a manner on the property under construction or on which repairs are being made so as to be visible from the public street closest to such construction site. (g) Penalty for violation. All persons violating any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1962, § 5-2; Code 1986, § 5-2; Ord. No. O-88-03-10, 3-28-1988) Sec. 14-31. - Water conservation restrictions. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit or a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling built shall not include a hotel or motel. (b) Residential buildings. On or after July 1, 1991, no construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992; (2) Employs a showerhead that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 psi of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one gallon of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (c) Commercial buildings. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type that does not meet the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. (d) Repair, renovation, addition to existing buildings. The requirements of subsection (b) of this section shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers or both. (e) Exemptions. (1) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsections (b)—(d) of this section when: a. The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; b. When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this section were installed; c. Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; d. Units to be installed are: 1. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; 2. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or 3. Toilets for juveniles. (2) The owner or his agent of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (e)(1) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building official for the city. A fee in the amount established by ordinance shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (f) Enforcement. This section shall be enforced by the office of the building official of the city. Citations for violations may be issued by the chief building official of the city. (Code 1986, § 5-7; Ord. No. O-91-02-04, 2-25-1991) Sec. 14-32. - State license required. The building official shall be authorized to cause charges to be brought for violations of this chapter against any person found to be installing, or known to have installed, electrical, plumbing, mechanical, gas, or other facilities that require a person to have a State of Georgia license in order to undertake such installation. (Ord. No. O-2013-31, 11-21-2013) Secs. 14-33—14-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICITY
Sec. 14-51. - Electrical inspector—Generally. (a) Position designated. The building official for the city shall perform the duties of electrical inspector. (b) Authority. The electrical inspector shall be the enforcing officer, supervising the enforcement of the provisions of the electrical code. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey any order of the electrical inspector issued under the provisions of this article and such person shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8. (c) Assistants. The electrical inspector, with the approval of the chief appointing authority of the city, may appoint such number of officers, inspectors, assistants and other employees as shall be authorized from time to time. (d) Records. The electrical inspector shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of the office. Such records shall be open to the inspection of the public at all times. (e) Duty. The electrical inspector is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to regulate the placing of electrical wiring and equipment for electric light, heat or power within the scope of the electrical code and to cause all such wiring and equipment to be so placed to accomplish the purpose of the electrical code. (f) Right of entry. The electrical inspector shall have the right in the discharge of such inspector's duties to enter any building, manhole, or subway, or to climb any pole for the purpose of examining and testing the electrical wiring and equipment therein or thereon. For this purpose, such inspector shall be given prompt access to such places on application to the person owning or in charge of same. It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entry to the electrical inspector when such inspector is performing the duties prescribed in this article. (g) Permit application forms.
