Sec. 46-89. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. Gross receipts. (1) The term "gross receipts" means the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without limitation the following: a. Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; b. Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets, or instruments of indebtedness; c. Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods, or services; d. Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and e. Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty, or dividend income. (2) The term "gross receipts" shall not include the following: a. Sales, use, or excise tax; b. Sales returns, allowances, and discounts; c. Interorganizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(2), or between or among a parent corporation, wholly owned subsidiaries of such parent corporation, and any corporation in which such parent corporation or one or more of its wholly owned subsidiaries owns stock possessing at least 30 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of stock of such partially owned corporation, or between or among wholly owned partnerships or other wholly owned entities; d. Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent that contributed to the gross receipts in issue; e. Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions, or the interest income derived from such funds received by a nonprofit organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this chapter, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organization's receipts; and f. Proceeds from sales of goods or services that are delivered to or received by customers who are outside the state at the time of delivery or receipt. Location of office shall include any structure or vehicle where business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renters or lessees location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofit, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize 80 percent of their proceeds for charitable purposes. Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who, by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by the city as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8), or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. (Code 1986, § 14-8; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-90. - Administration. The finance director shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy, assessment and collection of license taxes, fees and penalties imposed herein. (Code 1962, § 13-29; Code 1986, § 14-1; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-91. - Rules and regulations. The finance director shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city and the state or the constitution of this state or of the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the occupational license taxes, fees and penalties hereunder. (Code 1962, § 13-30; Code 1986, § 14-2; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-92. - Responsible person. Whenever in this article the term "dealer" or "person" is used, the principal, but in such principal's absence, any agent, clerk, or employee, shall be subject to the penalties herein imposed should the business be carried on without registering and paying the required occupational license tax in the same manner as if such agents, clerks and employees were the proprietors of said business. (Code 1962, § 13-25; Code 1986, § 14-3) Sec. 46-93. - Registration. Any person for such person's self or as an officer of a firm or corporation exercising or carrying on any business or operating any establishment for which a license or payment of occupational taxes is required by this article, without first having registered as provided herein, shall be liable to punishment as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1962, §§ 13-6, 13-16; Code 1986, § 14-4) Sec. 46-94. - Levy. The specific and general occupational license taxes provided in this article are hereby levied and shall be collected in the amounts hereinafter specified upon each person engaged in the business, trade, profession or occupation or doing acts named or described herein within the city during each calendar year. All such activities may be hereinafter referred to as "business." (Code 1962, § 13-1; Code 1986, § 14-5) State Law reference— Levy of occupation tax, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-6, 48-13-7. Sec. 46-95. - Payment of tax prerequisite to engaging in business. (a) No person shall be engaged in, prosecute or carry on any business, trade or profession, either in whole or in part, within the city by maintaining an office within the city or by soliciting orders through said office or engage in any business in any manner without having paid a license tax as hereinafter provided. (b) No business license shall be issued by the finance director to any person or entity which is delinquent as to any ad valorem taxes, fees, assessments, charges, including charges for utilities provided by the city, and other indebtedness or fees owed to the city. (Code 1962, § 13-2; Code 1986, § 14-6; Ord. No. O-97-07-25, 7-24-1997) State Law reference— Levy of occupation tax, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-6, 48-13-7. Sec. 46-96. - Occupation tax required. Each person upon whom an occupational license tax is levied shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the finance director or designees, or to any police officer of said city, upon request. (Code 1986, § 14-7; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) State Law reference— Levy of occupation tax, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-6, 48-13-7. Sec. 46-97. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure; occupation tax structure. (a) A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee in the amount fixed by ordinance shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. (b) A regulatory fee in the amount fixed by ordinance is hereby imposed as authorized under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9. Such regulatory fee shall not include an administrative fee. Such regulatory fee applies to each business more particularly set out in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b), such section being incorporated into and being made a part of this section by specific reference thereto. (Code 1986, § 14-9; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-98. - Occupation tax—Levied; restrictions. (a) An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the following criteria: (1) Gross receipts of the business or practitioner in combination with the profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications, or other information published by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, or successor agencies of the United States. (2) The tax rate determined by profitability ratios in combination with gross receipts for each business, trade, profession, or occupation shall be as established by ordinance. (b) No occupation tax will be required upon more than 100 percent of a business' gross receipts. (c) No occupation tax will be required on receipts on which such tax has been levied in other localities or states. (d) An occupation tax shall be required from real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose offices are located outside the taxing jurisdiction and who sell property inside the taxing jurisdiction. (e) An occupation tax shall not be levied in any other manner except as described in this section. (f) Occupation taxes are limited to the gross receipts earned in the taxing jurisdiction or in the state. (g) Out-of-state businesses with no location in the state shall be assessed occupation taxes pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 14-13-7, which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state. (h) The occupation tax payable pursuant to this section shall be as established by ordinance per business, trade, profession, or occupation required to pay the occupation tax. (i) An alphabetical business classification (SIC) index is added to Ordinance No. O-95-12-41 as appendix A thereof, and the same is incorporated into this section by specific reference thereto. (j) A tax class designation by SIC code and business description for tax classes 1 through 6 is added to Ordinance No. O-95-12-41 as appendix B, and the same is incorporated herein by specific reference thereto. (Code 1986, § 14-10; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-99. - Same—Paid by business with no location in the state. Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business' largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city, and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. (Code 1986, § 14-11; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-100. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the dominant line of business that the business conducts. (Code 1986, § 14-12; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-101. - Professionals. Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(c)(18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: (1) The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios as referenced in section 46-98(a)(2). (2) A fee as established by ordinance per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this section shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. (3) Such election shall be made on or before February 1, 1995. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by written request filed by the professional on or before February 1 of the year in which the election is to be changed. (4) Examples of businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations, which are subject to this section include, but are expressly not limited to, the following: a. Lawyers; b. Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 34 (O.C.G.A. § 43-34-1 et seq.); c. Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 34 (O.C.G.A. § 43-34-1 et seq.); d. Chiropractors; e. Podiatrists; f. Dentists; g. Optometrists; h. Psychologists; i. Veterinarians; j. Landscape architects; k. Land surveyors; l. Practitioners of physiotherapy; m. Public accountants; n. Embalmers; o. Funeral directors; p. Civil, mechanical, hydraulic or electrical engineers; q. Architects; r. Marriage and family therapists; s. Social workers and professional counselors; t. Dealers of motor vehicles, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 10-1-622(1); u. Owners or operators of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1, and owners or operators of businesses where bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, provided that such amusement machines have affixed current stickers showing payment of annual permit fees, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-9; v. Merchants or dealers as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-354, as to their deliveries to businesses, and practitioners of professions and occupations in areas zoned for commercial use; and w. Any other business, profession or occupation for which state licensure or registration is required by state law, unless the state law regulating such business, profession or occupation specifically allows for regulation by local governments. (Code 1986, § 14-13; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) State Law reference— Taxation of professionals, O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-9(c), 48-13-10(g). Sec. 46-102. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax. (Code 1986, § 14-14; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) State Law reference— Exemptions generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-13. Sec. 46-103. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Code 1986, § 14-15; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-104. - Tax due, payable; transacting business when tax delinquent; penalty. (a) Each administrative fee, regulatory fee, and occupation tax, as applicable, shall be for the calendar year. Any administrative fee, regulatory fee, or occupation tax shall be payable March 15 of each year. For any new profession, occupation, or business begun in the city after March 15 of any year, the administrative fee, regulatory fee, and occupation tax, as applicable, shall be obtained immediately upon beginning business, and if not so obtained, shall be considered delinquent. Any amounts owed which remain due and unpaid for a period of 90 days shall be subject to penalties for delinquency as provided in this article. A regulatory fee certificate and an occupation tax certificate indicating that the profession, occupation, or business has paid the fees and taxes owed shall be issued by the finance director. Any person practicing a profession, occupation, or business without having a valid certificate issued to him or her shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8. Each day that such fees and taxes remain unpaid shall be deemed to be a separate offense. (b) In addition to the remedies specified in subsection (a) of this section, the finance director may proceed to collect the delinquencies in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. (Code 1986, § 14-16; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-105. - Allocation of gross receipts of business with multiple intrastate or interstate locations. (a) For those businesses that have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupation tax assessed will be those gross receipts attributed to each city location. Where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in those businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere and allotted to those locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide to the city the following: (1) Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and (2) Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. (b) Where the business has locations outside the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. (Code 1986, § 14-17; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-106. - Exemption for businesses operated for charitable purposes. (Code 1986, § 14-18; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-107. - Evidence of state registration; conspicuously displayed; evidence of state sales tax registration. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-114. - Businesses at more than one location. Information provided by a person to the city for the purpose of determining the applicability and the amount of the occupation tax or the levy or collection of occupational tax levied pursuant to this article is confidential and exempt from disclosure. (Code 1986, § 14-32; Ord. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-121. - Revocation. Failure of any person to pay an applicable administrative fee, regulatory fee, or occupation tax, or any part thereof, before it becomes delinquent, or upon the failure to permit inspection of books as required, shall result in any business tax certificates or regulatory fee certificates granted by the city under this article permitting such person to do business in the city for the current year being automatically revoked without any further action required of the city. The lien shall cover the property of the person liable for said tax as provided by this Code, the Charter of the city and the laws of the state. The lien for said occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time that such tax or installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the appropriate city agent upon the person liable for said tax and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and cost allowed by law. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be as provided by this Code, the Charter of the city and the laws of the state. This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the city council. No. O-95-12-41, 12-21-1995) Sec. 46-127. - Exemption or reduction in occupation tax. Sec. 46-187. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to regulate certain types of businesses, including, but not limited to, adult entertainment establishments to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses will be curtailed. However, it is recognized that such regulation cannot be a de facto approach to prohibition. Otherwise, a protected form of expression would vanish. As to adult dance establishments, this article represents a balancing of competing interests; reduced criminal activity and protection of the city's neighborhoods through the regulation of adult entertainment establishments versus the protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and patrons. (Code 1986, § 2.5-1; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-188. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult bookstore means an establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock and trade in books, magazines or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas or an establishment with a segment or section, comprising 20 percent of its net sales consisting of printed material which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult business means any business or establishment which offers its patrons services or entertainment characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, discussing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult dancing establishment means any restaurant, lounge, private club, nightclub, theater or other establishment which features live performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, go-go dancers, exotic dancers, strippers or similar entertainers, where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult entertainment establishment means a business which consists of one or more of the following: an adult bookstore, an adult business, an adult dancing establishment, an adult motion picture theater, an adult minimotion picture theater, an adult hotel or motel, an adult motion picture arcade, an adult video store, or an escort bureau. Adult hotel or motel means a hotel or motel wherein material is presented which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities of specified anatomical areas. Adult minimotion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons used primarily for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin- or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projections or other image producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons, used primarily for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. Adult video store means any establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock and trade in videotapes, movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas or an establishment with a segment or section thereof, comprising 20 percent of its total floorspace, devoted to the sale or display of such material or which derives more than 20 percent of its net sales from videotapes, movies or other reproductions which are characterized or distinguished by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Church means a body of communicants gathered into church order, united under one form of government by the profession of the same faith and the observance of the same ritual and ceremonies. Encounter center or rap establishment means any business, agency or person who, for any form of consideration or gratuity, provides a place where two or more persons may congregate, assemble or associate for the primary purpose of engaging in, describing or discussing specified sexual activities, or exposing specified anatomical areas. Escort bureau or introduction services means any business, agency or person who, for a fee, commission, hire, reward, or profit furnishes or offers to furnish names or persons, or who introduces, furnishes or arranges for persons who may accompany other persons to or about social affairs, entertainments or places of amusement, or who may consort with others about any place of public resort or within any private quarters. Good moral character means a person, according to this article, that has not been convicted of a drug-related crime, an alcohol-related felony, a sex-related crime, or a crime of moral turpitude in the past five years. Minor means, for the purpose of this article, any person who has not attained the age of 21 years. Partial nude dancing means appearing or dancing at an adult entertainment establishment, as defined herein, partially nude, but at a minimum with the human male or female genitals, pubic area and buttocks and all of the nipples of the breasts of a female being at least shielded and covered by a fully opaque covering. Public indecency means as it relates to adult dancing establishment: (1) Engaging in sexual intercourse; (2) Engaging in deviate sexual conduct; (3) Engaging in a state of total nudity as opposed to partial nudity; (4) Fondling the genitals of oneself or another person; or (5) Dancing with the male genitals covered, but in a discernible turgid state. Such activities shall be deemed to be acts of public indecency under the terms of this article. Specified anatomical areas means and shall include any of the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, buttock, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or (2) Human male genitalia in a discernable turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activities means and shall include any of the following: (1) Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory function in the context of sexual relations, and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, zooerasty; (2) Clearly depicting human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; (3) Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; (4) Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; (5) Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the inflicting of pain; (6) Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being; or (7) Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. Such activities shall be deemed to be acts of public indecency under the terms of this article. Total nude dancing means appearing or dancing at an adult dancing establishment, as herein defined, without the protection or benefit of the minimal coverings required for partial nude dancing. (Code 1986, § 2.5-2; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-189. - General regulations. (a) No person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other entity shall operate, attempt to operate, advertise, or cause to be advertised, an adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this chapter, without a valid adult entertainment permit issued pursuant to this article. (b) No later than March 1 of each year an adult entertainment establishment permittee shall file a verified report with the finance director showing the permittee's gross receipts and amounts paid to dancers for the preceding calendar year. (c) An adult entertainment establishment permittee shall maintain and retain for a period of two years the names, addresses, and ages of all persons employed therein. (d) No adult entertainment establishment permittee shall employ or contract with a person under the age of 21 years or a person not permitted pursuant to this article. (e) No person under the age of 21 years shall be admitted to an adult entertainment establishment. (f) An adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this article, shall be closed between 12:45 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. each day, every Sunday, and on Christmas Day. (g) No adult entertainment establishment permitted employee shall fondle or caress any patron and no patron shall fondle or caress any adult entertainment establishment employee on the licensed premises. (h) An adult entertainment establishment permittee shall conspicuously display all licenses required by this article. (i) All dancing by an employee at an adult dancing establishment shall occur on a platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least two feet from the level of the floor. (j) No dancing shall occur closer than four feet to any patron. (k) No adult entertainment establishment permittee shall allow or permit an employee or any other person on the premises to engage in any of the following sexual activities: (1) Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of sexual relations, and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, zooerasty; (2) Clearly depicting human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; (3) Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; (4) Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; (5) Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the inflicting of pain; (6) Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being; or (7) Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. (l) No patron shall directly pay or give any gratuity to any dancer. (m) No dancer shall solicit any pay or gratuity from any patron. (n) All areas of an establishment permitted hereunder shall be fully lighted at all times patrons are present. Full lighting shall mean illumination equal to 3.5 footcandles per square foot. (o) No adult entertainment establishment shall serve, sell, distribute or allow the consumption or possession or any intoxicating liquor or controlled substances upon the premises of the permittee. (p) Total nude dancing, appearing nude or dancing involving acts of public indecency as defined by this article are hereby prohibited in any adult dancing establishment. Any other dancing or acts of public indecency prohibited by other applicable laws of the state or ordinances of the city as now or hereinafter enacted, or the violation of any of the other criminal laws of the state or of the city, are likewise prohibited. (Code 1986, § 2.5-3; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-190. - Permit required. (Code 1986, § 2.5-4; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-191. - Operation of unpermitted premises unlawful. (Code 1986, § 2.5-5; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-192. - Admission of minors unlawful. It shall be unlawful for a permittee to admit or permit the admission of minors into a permitted premises. (Code 1986, § 2.5-6; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-193. - Sales to minors unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give, to any minor any service, material, device or thing sold or offered for sale from an adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater, adult massage parlor or adult dancing establishment or other adult entertainment enterprise. (Code 1986, § 2.5-7; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-194. - Location. No adult entertainment establishment business shall be located: (1) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land which is zoned for multifamily or single-family uses or purposes; (2) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, school, governmental building owned or occupied by such government, library, civic center, public park or neighborhood playground is located; (3) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which another establishment regulated or defined hereunder is located; (4) Within any zoning category other than the following three categories: a. Industrial (I) as defined in section 94-159; or (5) On less than three acres of land containing at least 100 feet of road frontage. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-195. - Adult entertainment establishment employees. It shall be the responsibility of the finance director to enforce the permit provisions of this article. It shall be the chief of police or the chief's designee's responsibility to enforce the operating regulations of this article. (1) Qualifications. Employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall be at least 21 years of age. Any applicant for employment who has been previously convicted within the preceding five years of a sex-related crime, a drug-related crime, or an alcohol-related felony, or a crime involving moral turpitude shall not be eligible for employment as an adult entertainment establishment employee, and any employee who is convicted of a sex-related crime, drug-related crime, or alcohol-related felony while employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee shall not thereafter work at any premises requiring permits under this article for a period of five years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered as part of a court-ordered sentence. The term "convicted" shall include an adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty, or a plea of nolo contendere. The terms "employed as an adult entertainment establishment employee" and "work at any permitted premises" shall include all work done or services performed while in the scope of employment on the permitted premises or elsewhere. (2) Approval for employment. Before any person may be employed at a permitted premises by a permittee hereunder, he shall file a notice with the police chief of the city of his intended employment on forms that require the information set forth in subsection (1) of this section. The city shall have 45 days to review and investigate the application submitted by the employee. If the employee is found to be qualified for such employment by the terms of this article, the police chief shall grant approval of the employment. Upon approval, the employee may be employed by the permittee. If approval is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of said denial, apply to the city manager of the city for a hearing. The decision of the city manager after hearing the appeal shall be final. (3) Investigation fee . An investigation fee in the amount established by ordinance, or a receipt from the finance director evidencing the payment of such fee at the time the notice is filed, shall accompany the notice of intended employment submitted to the police chief. (4) Independent contractors. For the purpose of this article, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and shall be permitted as employees regardless of the type of business relationship with the owner or permittee of the adult entertainment establishment. (Code 1986, § 2.5-9; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 46-196. - Permit application. (a) Any person desiring to obtain a permit to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult entertainment establishment business shall make application to the finance director. Prior to submitting such application, the nonrefundable fee established by ordinance, shall be paid to the finance director to defray, in part, the cost of the investigations and reports required by this article. Upon payment thereof, the finance director shall issue a receipt showing that such application fee has been paid. (b) The application for such a permit shall not authorize the engaging in, operation of, conduct of or carrying on of any adult entertainment. (Code 1986, § 2.5-10; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 46-197. - Application information. (a) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment permit shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: (1) The applicant's full name, social security number, and date of birth. (2) The present address and telephone number of the applicant. (3) Acceptable written proof that the applicant is at least 21 years of age. (4) The business, occupation and employment history of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of application. (5) The business permit history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous businesses in this or any other city, state or territory, has had any license or permit for an adult entertainment business or similar type of business revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation of the applicant subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation. (6) If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation and charter, together with the place and date of incorporation, all states or other jurisdictions in which the applicant is authorized to do business (including written evidence of such authorizations), and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors. (7) If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the name, residence address and dates of birth of the partners. (8) If the applicant is a limited partnership, it shall furnish a copy of its certificate of limited partnership. (9) If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply to the corporate partner. (10) The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one or more of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated person or persons shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this article, but only one application fee shall be charged. (11) Whether or not the applicant, any partners or any corporate officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, have been convicted of any crime evidencing a lack of good moral character, as defined in this article, in the past five years and, if so, a complete description of any such crime including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction where the crime or act occurred, and any disposition thereof, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether terms of any court-imposed sentence have been fully completed. (12) If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of all trade name documents properly recorded as required by law. (13) If the applicant is a corporation, a copy of the articles of incorporation, trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report to the Georgia Secretary of State. (14) At least three character references from individuals who are in no way related to the applicant or individual shareholders, officers or directors of a corporation and who are not and will not benefit financially in any way from the operation of the business if the permit is granted and who have not been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude. The police chief shall prepare forms consistent with the provisions of this section for the applicant who shall submit all character references on such forms. (15) The address of the premises to be permitted. (16) Whether the premises are owned or rented by the applicant. (17) A plat by a registered surveyor, licensed by the state, showing that the location of the proposed premises is in accord with the provisions contained in section 46-194 and the zoning chapter. In addition to the information required herein, the application shall disclose the name, address, social security number and date of birth of all persons who have a financial interest of any type in the business that is applying for the permit, and any other matter reasonably required by the chief of police. (b) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment permit shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: (1) If the applicant is an individual, the individual; (2) If a partnership, the manager or general partner; (3) If a corporation, the president of the corporation; (4) If any other organization or association, the chief administrative official of such organization or association. (Code 1986, § 2.5-11; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-198. - Applicant to appear. The applicant, if an individual, or the designated responsible managing officer, if a partnership, corporation, or other entity, shall personally appear at the finance department before the finance director, or his designee, and produce proof that the nonrefundable application fee, established by ordinance, has been paid, and shall also present the completed permit application containing the required information to the police chief or his designee. (Code 1986, § 2.5-12; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 46-199. - Application investigation and recommendations. (a) The city shall have 45 days to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the investigation, the police chief shall report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall consider the application within 30 days of receipt of the report from the police chief. After a hearing on the application, at which any interested persons present may be heard, the planning commission shall recommend to the city council the grant or denial of the permit at its next regular meeting; but the commission may only recommend the granting of such permit if it finds: (1) The required application fee has been paid. (2) The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this article. (3) The applicant has not knowingly made a material misrepresentation in the application. (4) The applicant has fully cooperated in connection with the investigation of his application. (5) The applicant, if an individual, or any officers or directors of the applicant, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not been convicted, entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, in a court of competent jurisdiction to an offense involving a sex-related crime or drug-related or alcohol-related felony or have been convicted, enter a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, of an attempt to commit any of the above-mentioned offenses, or convicted, entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere in any other state as to an offense which, if committed or attempted in this state, would have been the same or substantially the same offense as one or more of the above-stated offenses. (6) The applicant has not had an adult entertainment establishment permit or other similar license or permit denied or revoked for cause in this city or in any other local government jurisdiction located in or out of this state prior to either the date of the application or the date of the granting of the application. (7) The building, structure, equipment, and location of such business, as proposed by applicant, would comply with all applicable zoning and distance laws and would qualify to receive a certificate of occupancy under the law of this state and the ordinances of this city. (8) The applicant is at least 21 years of age. (9) That neither the applicant, nor any of the applicant's employees, agents, partners, directors, officers, or managers, has within five years of the date of the application, knowingly allowed or permitted any of the specified sexual activities defined herein to occur in or upon the premises where such adult entertainment establishment is to be located, nor has such applicant or other persons knowingly allowed or permitted the proposed permitted premises to be used as a place in which solicitations for any of the specified sexual activities occurred within said time period. (10) That on the date the business for which a permit is required herein commences, and thereafter, there will be a responsible person actually on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open. (11) That the proposed premises shall not be located at any location not authorized by this article or by the zoning chapter. (12) That the grant of such permit will not result in a violation of this article or any other ordinance or regulation of the city, or of any laws, rules or regulations of the state, or the United States. (13) Any other inquiry deemed necessary or desirable by the city to ensure the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city or the preservation of its neighborhoods. (b) The planning commission shall forward its recommendation to the city council which shall have the final authority to grant or deny the permit, but such permit shall not be granted unless the city council finds that all of the requirements of this chapter, including, but not limited to, this section and section 46-200, have been met by the applicant. (c) All hearings regarding such application shall be open to the public and advertised in the legal organ of the city as required by state law and this section. (Code 1986, § 2.5-13; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 46-200. - Additional permit requirements. (a) The permittee shall maintain with the finance director and the police department, at all times, a written statement of the name, address, and phone number of the manager or assistant manager in charge of the permitted premises, and there shall, at all times, be a manager in charge and on the premises during operating hours. (b) Each permittee shall have a continuing obligation to comply with all provisions of this Code relating to the operation of the permittee's business. (c) The applicant may be required to appear at any hearing on the issue of the grant, denial, suspension, or revocation of the required permit governed by this article. (Code 1986, § 2.5-14; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 46-201. - Persons prohibited as permittees. (a) Subject to the other requirements of this article, no permit authorized by this chapter shall be issued to or held by: (1) An applicant who has not paid all required fees and taxes, including ad valorem taxes, for a business at that location; (2) Any person who is not of good moral character as defined in this article; (3) Any corporation, any of whose officers, directors, or shareholders is not of good moral character as defined in this article; (4) Any partnership or association, any of whose partners or members is not of good moral character as defined in this article; (5) Any person employing or assisted financially, in whole or in part, by any person who is not of good moral character as defined in this article; or (6) Any applicant who is not qualified to hold and conduct a business according to the laws of the United States, the state or the city. (b) Should there be a sufficient number of current permits to meet the needs and desires of the inhabitants of the city, no new permits shall issue. In determining the needs and desires of the inhabitants, the standard of review shall be that the market is virtually unrestrained as defined in Young v. American Mini Theaters, Inc. (427 US 50, 81). (Code 1986, § 2.5-15; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-202. - Permit—Renewal. Permits for adult entertainment establishments shall be renewed on a calendar-year basis provided that the permittee continues to meet the requirements set out in this article. The renewal fee for the adult entertainment establishments permits shall be as established by this article. Renewal applications shall be submitted by November 1 of each year prior to the year for which such permit is requested. (Code 1986, § 2.5-16; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-203. - Same—Nontransferable. No adult entertainment establishment permit may be sold, transferred or assigned by a permittee, or by operation of law, to any other person. Any such sale, transfer or assignment, or attempted sale, transfer or assignment, shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such permittee and such permit shall thereafter be null and void; provided, however, that if the permit is a partnership and one or more of the partners should die, one or more of the surviving partners may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner without effecting a surrender or termination of such permit, and in such case, the permit, upon notification to the city, shall be placed in the name of the surviving partner, subject to compliance with all other requirements of this article. (Code 1986, § 2.5-17; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-204. - Change of name. (a) No permittee shall advertise, operate, conduct, manage, engage in, or carry on an adult entertainment establishment business under any name other than the name of the business as specified on the permit. (b) Any application for an extension or expansion of a building or other place of business where an adult entertainment establishment is located shall require inspection and shall comply with the provisions and regulations of this article, and all other ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. (Code 1986, § 2.5-18; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-205. - Penalty for violation. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to such fine or imprisonment, violation of this article shall also be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of any permit granted hereunder. (Code 1986, § 2.5-19; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-206. - Unlawful operation declared a nuisance. Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this article shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to, or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal or enjoining thereof, in the manner provided by law. The city shall further be authorized to take such other steps and apply to such court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate such nuisance and retrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining an adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this article. In addition, violation of the provisions of this article shall be per se grounds for suspension or revocation of any permit granted hereunder. (Code 1986, § 2.5-20; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-207. - Revocation and appeal. (a) After notice and hearing, the police chief shall be authorized to suspend or revoke a permit previously granted hereunder. In the event the police chief seeks to suspend or to revoke a permit the police chief shall give written notification to the permittee of such action and such notice shall contain a specification of the violation or violations upon which such suspension or revocation is based and shall be served upon the permittee, by registered mail, return receipt requested, at least five days prior to the date of the hearing. The permittee shall be given written notice of the time and place of the hearing. (b) The police chief shall be authorized to suspend or revoke a permit in the event of the occurrence of any one or more of the following: (1) A permittee provided false or misleading information in the original or subsequent application process; (2) A permittee has knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled substances on the premises; (3) A permittee has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state or of the United States to occur on the premises; (4) A permittee has violated any provision of this article; (5) A permittee has been convicted, during the license period, of any drug-related, alcohol-related or sex-related crime by the state, the city, or the United States regarding an offense which was committed on the premises, or which would otherwise violate the provisions of this article when such offense would serve to prohibit the permittee from obtaining a permit under this article; or (6) A permittee fails to pay any fee, fine or other amount of money due the city under this article or any other license or occupational taxation ordinance of the city. (c) In the event the police chief shall suspend or revoke any permit hereunder, the suspension or revocation shall be for a period of not less than one day nor more than 365 days, within the sound discretion of the police chief; provided, however, that the permittee shall be authorized to continue its business operations until the date of any hearing scheduled in accordance with subsections (a) or (d) of this section. No permittee or other applicant may apply for a permit during any period of suspension or revocation. In any hearing or investigation conducted by the police chief in connection with a possible suspension or revocation of a permit issued hereunder, the police chief shall consider, among other things, the severity of the allegations, the evidence submitted and the testimony presented, in making any decision on suspension, revocation and the duration of any suspension or revocation. (d) In the event of a suspension or revocation by the police chief, the permittee may appeal the decision of the police chief to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days from the date that the permittee receives written notification of the decision of the police chief. Such written notification shall be mailed to the permittee by certified mail, return receipt requested. Thereafter, a hearing shall be scheduled before the city council within 45 days after the filing of the notice of appeal by the applicant. After hearing by the city council, the city council may take such action as it finds warranted from the evidence submitted to it, including, but not limited to, the affirming of the action of the police chief, the reversal of such action, or the imposition of modified sanctions upon the permittee. (Code 1986, § 2.5-21; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 46-208. - Permit and annual renewal fees. (a) There is hereby established a nonrefundable fee in the amount established by ordinance to be paid to the finance director with each application to operate an adult entertainment establishment pursuant to this article. The annual renewal fee for any such permit shall be as established by ordinance. (b) Any permittee shall also be subject to all business license fees and occupational taxes imposed by the city pursuant to this chapter. (Code 1986, § 2.5-22; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-209. - Advertising and posting. The premises for which the permit herein is sought either as an initial permit or a renewal thereof, shall be posted with a notice in a form prescribed by the city manager for at least 21 days prior to any hearing on such application. In addition, a newspaper advertisement shall be published in the city's legal organ in a form prescribed by the city manager at least two times during the ten days prior to any hearing on such permit application or renewal. Such posted notice and newspaper advertisements shall notify all interested persons of the date, time, location and purpose of the hearing on such application. (Code 1986, § 2.5-23; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 46-2010. - Premises open for inspection. The permitted premises shall be open at any and all reasonable times for inspection by the city to establish and ensure compliance with this article. (Code 1986, § 2.5-24; Ord. No. O-93-06-25, 6-24-1993) Sec. 46-211. - Compliance in newly annexed areas. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, any adult entertainment establishments are not permitted pursuant to this article that are located in newly annexed areas shall have 90 days from the effective date of the annexation to obtain a license hereunder and otherwise comply with all the terms, requirements and standards hereof. Sec. 46-229. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Month means that period of time from one date in a calendar month to the corresponding date in the following calendar month, but if there is no such corresponding date, then the last day of such following month. Pawn transaction means any loan on the security of pledged goods or any purchase of pledged goods on the condition that the pledged goods may be redeemed or repurchased by the pledger or seller for a fixed price during a fixed period of time. Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller during a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this definition. Pawnshop means any business, a substantial portion of which is to take or receive, by way of pledge, pawn, or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise, or any kind of personal property whatsoever, as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. (Code 1986, § 14-202; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-230. - Purpose. This article is enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the purpose of promoting the health and general welfare of the community, to provide, establish, and ascertain standards for the regulation and control of pawnshops or similar places where money is advanced on goods and other effects, merchandise, or personal property. (Code 1986, § 14-200; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-231. - Compliance required. All persons, before beginning the business of operating a pawnshop, shall first file an application with the city and receive a business license for the operation of a pawnshop in order to conduct such business from the finance director. The application for such business license shall be made upon such forms and in such manner as the finance director may establish from time to time. Such business license shall be obtained in accordance with regular business license application procedure, which is required under article IV of this chapter. (Code 1986, § 14-201; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-232. - General qualifications for business license. (a) No license shall be issued if the application or other evidence available to the city reveals that any one or more of the following conditions to exist: (1) The applicant is of bad moral character or does not have the mental capacity to conduct the business for which the application is made. (2) The applicant has had any business license or permit issued under the police powers of this or any other city or other governmental subdivision previously suspended or revoked. (3) The applicant, while a holder of a license to operate a pawnshop has been convicted of, or pled guilty or nolo contendere to, a violation of any law, regulation, or ordinance relating to the pawnshop business within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of application. (4) The applicant has failed to produce any paper or document necessary in the operation of its business as may be required by any officer, agency, or department of a municipality, county, state, or the United States under authority of any law, ordinance, or resolution of such municipality, county, state, or the United States. (5) The applicant has provided false information either upon his application or in any communication with any official of the city relative to his application. (6) The applicant has failed to pay any fee required under this article or has otherwise failed to comply with the provisions of this article. (b) In addition to the criteria in subsection (a) of this section, in determining whether or not any license applied for shall be issued, the following criteria shall be considered as being relevant to the city's obligation to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public, and in such connection, a negative finding by the city as to one or more of the following criteria shall authorize the denial of a licensure application: (1) Whether the applicant is a previous holder of a pawnshop business license, the manner in which he conducted the business thereunder as to the necessity for unusual or enhanced police effort, observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business; (2) The number of licenses already granted for similar businesses operating in the same general vicinity or neighborhood. (Code 1986, § 14-203; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-233. - Nontransferable. No business license granted under this article shall be transferable. (Code 1986, § 14-204; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-234. - Revocations and suspensions of licenses. (a) In the event that the owner of the pawnshop business or any employee of such owner fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article, the finance director shall be authorized to suspend or revoke the pawnshop business license previously issued to such owner. In the event of such a suspension or revocation, notice of such decision shall be communicated to the owner in writing by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Such notice is deemed to be effective upon personal service or upon mailing; provided, however, that such suspension or revocation shall be effective no sooner than ten calendar days from the effective date of such service or mailing. Any suspension hereunder shall be for such duration as the finance director deems appropriate, but any such suspension shall not exceed 30 calendar days. Violation of a written notice of suspension by the owner or any employee of the owner shall be grounds for revocation of the owner's pawnshop business license. (b) Any person whose pawnshop business license is suspended or revoked has the right to appeal such suspension or revocation to the city council within ten calendar days of the effective date of such suspension or revocation. Such appeal must be in writing, must be filed with the finance director, and must set out the grounds upon which the appellant contends that the suspension or revocation was erroneously issued. The filing of such an appeal shall constitute an automatic stay of the suspension or revocation, and such automatic stay shall continue in effect until such time as the appeal is finally adjudicated by the city council. The city manager of the city shall be notified of the filing of such an appeal and shall schedule a hearing thereon by the city council within 30 calendar days from the date of filing such appeal. In considering such appeal, the city council shall affirm the action or decision of the finance director if the city council finds that such decision was supported by any evidence. (Code 1986, § 14-205; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 46-235. - Daily report to police required. (a) Every licensee shall prepare a daily report for the city police department, in such form as may be prescribed by the police department, of all property pledged to or bought by the licensee during the preceding 24 hours ending at 8:00 p.m. on the effective date of the report. In addition to any other information required by the police department, the report shall disclose: (1) The name and address of the licensee; (2) Time of transaction; (3) Serial numbers of pawn tickets; (4) Full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry, and all identifying names, marks, and numbers; (5) A description of persons pledging, selling, or pawning; including name, address, information from such person's driver's license or government-issued identification, including weight, height, and eye color; and (6) Serial numbers on items must be included in the report. Insufficient or incomplete reports shall be rejected. (b) Any licensee or employee who fails or refuses to prepare and keep reports as provided in this section or makes false entries concerning a transaction or who fails or refuses to permit an inspection or examination of the report by any police officer, designated by the chief of police to conduct such inspections, shall constitute a violation of this Code, which shall be punishable as provided in this article. (c) Each licensee shall require any person pawning, pledging, or selling an article or articles to display government-issued identification which at a minimum contains a photograph of the person, the person's date of birth, race, and sex as well as the identification number, drivers license number and/or social security number of the person, the type of identification and the name of the city council issuing such identification. The licensee shall record all of the above information from such identification. (d) The failure of any licensee or employee to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this Code, which shall be punishable as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 14-206; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-236. - Violations; penalties. (a) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere in the city municipal court, be subject to: (1) First offense: by a fine of not more than $600.00 or by confinement in the common jail of the county for a period of not more than 60 days or by both fine and confinement. (2) Second offense: by a fine of not more than $900.00 or by confinement in the common jail of the county for a period of not more than 90 days or by both fine and confinement. (b) Each violation of this article shall be deemed a separate offense. (c) Any violation of the provisions of this article may also be enjoined by the Superior Court of Sumter County in an action filed for such purpose by the city. Such injunction may be granted by said court notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law may exist. Remedies contained in this article shall be cumulative in nature. (d) Any violation of the provisions of this article by a licensee hereunder, and any failure to pay any taxes or fees owed to the city by a licensee hereunder, shall also subject the business owner of the pawnshop to suspension or revocation of such owner's business license under section 46-234. (Code 1986, § 14-207; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-237. - Disposal period for pawned, purchased articles. Any licensee who takes goods on pawn or buys goods in its capacity as a pawnshop, taking full title thereto, shall hold such goods for at least 40 calendar days in the case of pawned goods and 15 calendar days in the case of purchased goods before disposing of same by sale, transfer, shipment, or otherwise unless such goods are redeemed by the owner thereof. Failure to comply with this section shall constitute a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 14-208; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-238. - Dealing with minors prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any licensee, his agents or employees, to receive in pawn, pledge, or sale goods of any character or description from a minor. For the purpose of this article, a minor is any person who is 17 years of age or younger. Any licensee or employee thereof violating this section shall constitute a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 14-209; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-239. - Sale of prohibited weapons. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell, offer for sale, or expose for sale any weapons, the sale of which are prohibited by city ordinance, state law, or federal law or regulation. Any licensee or employee thereof violating this section shall constitute a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 14-210; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-240. - Security cameras required. (a) Any establishment which is licensed by the city to engage in the business of operating as a pawnshop and which is open to the public for business any day of the week is required to install security cameras and recording mechanisms of a type and number capable of recording evidentiary quality images for the prosecution of criminal cases, or for such other uses as may be deemed authorized by law. (b) Cameras and recording mechanisms meeting the requirements of this section must be capable of producing a retrievable image on video tape or other medium that can be made a permanent record and can be enlarged through projection or other means. Cameras and recording mechanisms meeting the requirements of this section shall be maintained in proper working order at all times and shall be subject to inspection by the city police department. (c) Security videos must have a shelf life of 15 calendar days from time of daily taping. The security video must be maintained at the licensee's place of business in an unaltered state and be available for inspection by the city police department. (d) In the event that the security cameras and recording mechanisms become inoperative, any licensee or employee thereof shall not be in violation of this section for conducting business if the licensee is diligently pursuing repairs of such system; provided that such repairs must be completed within ten days after such system becomes inoperative. (e) Any licensee or employee thereof violating this section shall constitute a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in this article. (Code 1986, § 14-211; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003) Sec. 46-241. - Licenses constitute grant of privilege; fees; duration of licenses. (a) All licenses issued hereunder shall be a mere grant of a privilege to carry on a pawnshop business during the term authorized in the license subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this article and by any other ordinance, resolution, or law of the county, state, or United States relating to such business. (b) The cost of such pawnshop business license shall be as established from time to time by the city council and shall be paid as a regulatory fee under article IV of this chapter. (c) Each pawnshop business license issued pursuant to this article shall expire on December 31 of the year in which such pawnshop license was issued. Applications for renewal of such pawnshop business license shall be accepted by the finance director between January 1 and March 15 of each calendar year, but no person shall be authorized to engage in the pawnshop business beyond March 15 of any calendar year until such person's application for a new pawnshop business license and city business license is approved in accord with this article. (Code 1986, § 14-212; Ord. No. O-03-09-25, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Secs. 46-242—46-260. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - TRANSIENT SALES, TEMPORARY SALES, PEDDLING, CANVASSING, AND SOLICITING[5] Footnotes: --- (5) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-2012-19, adopted July 19, 2012, amended art. VIII in its entirety, inasmuch adding div. 1 and div. 2, subdivs. I, II, to read as herein set out. Former art. DIVISION 1. - SALES FROM PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY LOCATIONS
Sec. 46-261. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City. The City of Americus, a Georgia municipal corporation. Goods. For the purposes of this division, "goods" is defined as merchandise, wares, fabric, material, furniture, clothing, shoes, and other articles of commerce; provided, however, that "goods" shall not include the sale of motorized vehicles or boats. Governing body. The mayor and city council of the City of Americus. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-262. - Enforcement and penalty for violation. (a) The finance director shall be the enforcement officer and shall insure that the provisions are complied with prior to the issuing of any license. (b) Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation that violates the terms of this division shall upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-263. - Location requirements. Except as otherwise provided in this Code: (1) No merchant, trader, manufacturer, dealer, salesperson, or other person, either in person or by or through agents, servants, or employees, shall offer for sale any kind or character of goods except from established places of business. (2) No article of any kind or nature whatsoever shall be sold or offered for sale from vehicles, stands, or containers while standing or located in the streets, parks, or other property of the city. (3) No display shall be erected or installed, nor shall any sales of goods or merchandise outside of a permanent place of business, take place within 50 feet of the curb or paved edge of a public street or roadway. (4) Sales shall be permitted only on property where controlled vehicular ingress and egress or adequate off-street parking is provided. (5) No portable structure shall be erected in connection with the sale of goods within the city. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-264. - Sales from private property. (a) Notwithstanding any other provisions of this division to the contrary, goods may be sold from vehicles, stands, or containers, while located on private premises, but not until and unless the persons offering the same for sale have secured the written consent of the owner of such premises to sell the same thereon, and have paid for and obtained from the finance director a regular license to conduct such business within the city. (b) In order to obtain such license, the seller shall have filed an application with the finance director for such license, which application shall contain, at a minimum the following information: (1) Name of applicant; (2) A copy of picture identification; (3) Permanent address and telephone number of applicant; (4) Local address and telephone number of the applicant; (5) Applicant's date of birth and age, if an individual; (6) Applicant's Social Security number or federal employer identification number; (7) If applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name and home address of each partner, principal, or corporation officer; (8) If applicant is a corporation, the day, date, and state of incorporation; (9) If applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name, home address, date of birth, age, and Social Security number of the principal representative in the city; (10) Name and home address of all employees to work in the city; (11) Name of business represented by applicant, if different from applicant; (12) Permanent address of the business represented by the applicant; (13) Name of agent conducting the sale, if any; (14) Local address and telephone number of sales agent, if any; (15) Type of merchandise or service offered for sale; (16) A brief statement of the nature and character of advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; (17) Place where business is to be conducted and written approval from the property owner of such location; (18) Fingerprints of the person or persons having the management of supervision of the applicant's business; (19) Dates to be in business and total number of days to be in business; (20) Hours in which the business will be conducted; (21) Manner in which business is to be conducted; (22) State sales tax number or authorization; (23) State business license, if required; (24) State license tag number of each vehicle to be used; and (25) List of cities where business has been conducted by the applicant within the past 12 months. (c) The license application shall be signed under oath by the applicant.
