(d) In the event that the applicant provides all required information to the finance director and the applicant has not been previously convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude as evidenced by the fingerprint records submitted in accordance with section 46-69 hereof, and the applicant otherwise qualifies for the license, then such license shall be issued by the clerk upon payment of the appropriate fees therefor. (e) A separate application, license, and fee shall be required for each separate location from which such applicant proposes to do business. (f) In the event that a licensee violates any of the provisions of this division, then the license may be revoked by the finance director, and the justification of each revocation may be considered by the clerk in the event that such licensee applies for a license under this article at a future date. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-265. - Applicability to residents and nonresidents. The prohibitions provided in this division shall apply to all persons, whether residents of the city, nonresidents of the city, residents of the state or nonresidents of the state. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-266. - Agricultural products exemption. The provisions of this division shall not apply to the sale by the producers of agricultural products within the state; provided, however, such producers shall fully comply with all regulations heretofore and hereafter prescribed by the governing body and by any federal or state agency or department relative to the inspection and the sale of such products. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-267. - Exceptions. (a) This division shall not apply to sales made to or by dealers, traders, manufacturers, merchants, or businesses at their established places of business within the incorporated limits of the city. (b) This division shall not apply to any sidewalk sale, flea market, art show, or arts and crafts show or other merchandise on the public sidewalks, walkways, or other open areas at the invitation of or as a part of the downtown promotional activities of the downtown development authority or an organization licensed to do business as a charity under Georgia law. (c) This division shall not apply to yard sales conducted in accord with the provisions of section 46-3 of this Code. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-268. - Fees. Licensees under this division shall pay a daily license fee of $100.00 per day for each day and for each location from which the licensee proposes to do business within the city. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-269. - Fingerprints to accompany application. Any applicant for license to be issued pursuant to this division shall accompany the application with one complete set of fingerprints of the applicant and the applicant's manager or agent, if the operation of the business will be conducted by one other than the applicant; if the applicant is a partnership, of all partners of said partnership; if the applicant is a corporation, of all officers and directors of said corporation. The fingerprints shall be taken by the city's police department on forms to be provided by said department, and the applicant shall pay a fee of $15.00 for each individual fingerprinted. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) DIVISION 2. - SALES BY SOLICITORS Subdivision I. - Generally
Sec. 46-270. - Definitions. The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City means the City of Americus. Goods means, for the purposes of this division, merchandise, wares, fabric, material, furniture, clothing, shoes, and other articles of commerce. Governing body means the Mayor and City Council of Americus. Solicitor means any person who solicits orders for the sale of goods or services on behalf of a business, individual, vocation, or occupation by means of door-to-door or house-to-house solicitation. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-271. - Exemptions. The following shall be exempt from compliance with the requirements of division 2 of this article: (1) Representatives or agents of charitable or nonprofit organizations or corporations registered with the Georgia Secretary of State, or tax-exempt organizations which have been recognized as such by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States Treasury Department, shall be treated as exempt from the provisions of this division. (2) Any sales representative who calls upon prospective customers at their prior invitation shall be treated as exempt from the provisions of this division of this article. (3) Any sales representative who does not demand, accept, or receive payments in advance of final delivery and who has had, for the previous six months, a regularly established place of business or permanent residence in the city shall be treated as exempt from the provisions of this division. Any person who is exempt under this subsection must be soliciting orders only for goods capable of being delivered at one time and must have on such person proper identification which substantiates the claim to an exemption. This division shall not apply to any individual or individuals engaged in door-to-door canvassing activities solely for the purpose of dispensing public information, engaging in religious activities, or engaging in political campaign activities. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-272. - Violation of other ordinances and laws. It is unlawful for any person while engaging in any activity for which a permit is required by this division to violate any city ordinance, criminal law of this state, or any state or federal consumer protection law. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-273. - Hours of operation. It is unlawful for any person to engage in any of the conduct for which a permit is required by this division between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., according to the standard time in effect. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-274. - Restriction on number of persons soliciting. It is unlawful for more than two individuals to engage in solicitation upon any premises at the same time for the same goods or services. Each individual member of a group engaged in solicitation in violation of this provision shall be deemed to have violated this section. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-275. - Persons with criminal records. It is unlawful for any person with a criminal record as described in section 46-525, whether or not otherwise eligible for an exemption under section 46-502, to engage in any of the activities for which a permit is required by this division. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-276. - Frequency of solicitation of same premises. It is unlawful for any person to make more than one solicitation call at the same premises for identical goods or services within any consecutive two-week period, without receiving a prior invitation therefor from the occupant of any such premises. This section includes solicitation upon the same premises by employees, agents, or representatives of any person, organization, or corporation more than once during such period without a prior invitation. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-277. - Solicitation to be at main entrances. It is unlawful for any person to solicit or attempt to solicit at a place of residence at any entrance or part of the building other than the main entrance to the residence. A solicitor shall honor any sign or notice located at the premises, or any verbal direction from the owner or occupant of the premises, that states or advises persons that no solicitation is authorized upon the premises. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-278. - Identification and announced purpose of call. At each dwelling, whether it is an apartment unit or private residence, the solicitor shall, at the time of initial contact with a prospective customer, identify himself or herself, identify his or her organization or corporation, and inform the occupant in unambiguous terms of the purpose of the solicitation. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-279. - Fraud, etc. It is unlawful for any person engaged in solicitation to misrepresent the purpose of the solicitation or use any false or deceptive statements or any misrepresentation to induce a sale or contribution, or use any plan, scheme, or ruse which misrepresents the status or purpose of the person making the call. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Subdivision II. - Permit
Sec. 46-280. - Required. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, any person engaged in or desiring to engage in any type of selling, soliciting, or any other business, occupation, or vocation, which by its nature requires going from door-to-door or house-to-house in the city, whether on a temporary or a permanent basis shall obtain a solicitor's permit from the city finance director. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-281. - Application. (a) Questionnaire. The finance director shall prepare a questionnaire requiring pertinent information regarding the physical description, identity, and background of each applicant for a permit, to include the following: (1) Name, local address, and telephone number. (2) Date and place of birth. (3) Driver's license number and issuing state. (4) Social Security number. (5) Race and sex. (6) Height and weight. (7) Eye color and hair color. (8) Name, address and telephone number of the organization represented. (9) Name and telephone number of immediate supervisor. (10) Product or service. (11) A list of all arrests, convictions, and the disposition of each charge, other than minor traffic violations. (b) The questionnaire form shall also bear the following statement: "Official Code of Georgia Annotated § 16-10-71, provides that a person to whom a lawful oath or affirmation has been administered or who executes a document knowing that it purports to be an acknowledgment of a lawful oath or affirmation commits the offense of false swearing when, in any matter or thing other than a judicial proceeding, he knowingly and willfully makes a false statement." (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-282. - Investigation and issuance. (a) Upon filing of an application for a solicitor's permit, the police department shall review the application for the purpose of ascertaining whether the applicant has plead to, or has been convicted of, a felony, or a misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude. After ascertaining that the application has been properly completed, and that the applicant has not been disqualified by virtue of prior pleas or conviction, the finance director shall approve the application. (b) The finance director shall charge a fee of $100.00 for each permit issued. (c) In any case in which it appears to the finance director that a solicitor's permit should not be issued to an applicant, the finance director shall so inform the applicant of such decision in writing, and shall include in such writing a written statement of the reasons why the permit cannot be issued. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-283. - Expiration and renewal. Each solicitor's permit shall indicate thereon an expiration date which is one year from the date of issue. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-284. - Denial; suspension or revocation. (a) No solicitor's permit shall be issued to any person who has been found guilty of any misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude any time within five years prior to the date of application, nor shall a permit be issued to any person convicted of a felony. (b) The permit of any solicitor charged with a felony or a misdemeanor involving violence or moral turpitude shall be deemed suspended from the time of lawful arrest, formal accusation, or indictment, whichever shall first occur. Such suspension shall remain in effect until the solicitor is convicted or acquitted. (c) The permit of any solicitor who is convicted of a felony, or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude or violence, shall be deemed revoked from the time of such conviction. The permit of any solicitor convicted of having violated any provision of this article after issuance of the permit shall be deemed revoked from the time of such conviction. (d) Any suspension or revocation occurring pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be effective by operation of law, whether or not any formal notification to the solicitor is given or received. (e) It is unlawful for any person to act as a solicitor while such person's permit has been suspended or after it has been revoked. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Sec. 46-285. - Appeals. A person to whom the finance director refuses to issue a solicitor's permit or whose solicitor's permit is suspended or revoked may appeal to the mayor and city council. Such appeal shall be submitted to the city clerk in writing within 15 calendar days of the date of the notice of denial, suspension, or revocation of a solicitor's permit. The legal and factual basis for such appeal shall be stated in the written notice of appeal. Such appeal shall be heard and determined by the city council within 45 days of the date of filing of the notice of appeal. (Ord. No. O-2012-19, 7-19-2012) Secs. 46-286—46-329. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - TRAVELING AND ITINERANT DEALERS OF GOLD AND SILVER[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- State Law reference— Dealers in precious metals and gems, O.C.G.A. § 47-37-1 et seq.
Sec. 46-330. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Itinerant or traveling dealer, salesperson or buyer means a person who does not have a business license in the city or shall enter the city for any period of time and advertise by any form of media communication to the public that such person will buy, sell, trade, or otherwise trade in and receive precious metals, gold, silver, coins and jewelry. (Code 1962, § 13-72; Code 1986, § 14-60) Sec. 46-331. - Applicability. This article shall be applicable to all traveling and itinerant dealers, salespersons, and buyers of gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals, whether said sales, trades and purchases are retail, wholesale, or by any form of pawn. Specifically excluded are wholesalers; buyers and sellers, who sell, trade and deal only with mercantile establishments and buyers; and sellers who have permanent mercantile establishments. (Code 1962, § 13-71; Code 1986, § 14-61) Sec. 46-332. - Notice of intent; required information. (a) Prior to advertising any buying, selling, trading, or otherwise dealing in precious metals, gold, silver, coins, or jewelry, the person shall, at least 72 hours prior to the initial advertising, file with the chief of police a written notice of intent to conduct business in the city. (b) Such notice shall include the following: (1) Full name of the person and such person's address. (2) The name of the person who will be in the city and such person's address. (3) The length of the stay in the city, including the dates of opening and closing. (4) Where business will be conducted and during what hours. (Code 1962, § 13-73; Code 1986, § 14-62) Sec. 46-333. - Records and information to be maintained. All traveling and itinerant dealers, salespersons, and buyers of gold, silver, coins, jewelry, and other precious metals shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property pledged, traded, or sold by them. Such description shall include, to the extent possible, the name or the make of the article, any identifying mark or number and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. In such books there shall be entered also the full name and address of the person by whom same was deposited or sold, and the time this was done. Such entries shall be made as soon after the transaction as is possible, and in no event more than four hours thereafter. (Code 1962, § 13-74; Code 1986, § 14-63) Sec. 46-334. - Report to police; contents, submission. (a) Every traveling and itinerant dealer, salesperson, or buyer shall make a written report to the police department no less than 24 hours after completion of its business in the city. The report shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police, and of all property pledged, traded, bought, or sold during the period of operation in the city. In addition to any other information required by the chief of police, they shall show: (1) The name and address of any person who bought, sold, traded, or otherwise disposed of or received any item; (2) The date and time of the transaction; (3) The amount paid or advanced, or the item traded; (4) The full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry, and all identifying names, ranks, and numbers; and (5) A description of persons trading, buying, selling or pawning, including the name, address, race, weight and height. (b) Such report shall be delivered to the police department no less than 24 hours after completion of business. It shall be neat and legible. (Code 1962, § 13-75; Code 1986, § 14-64) Sec. 46-335. - Dealing with minors. It shall be unlawful for any traveling or itinerant dealer, salesperson, or buyer to receive in pawn, trade, or to buy from minors or to sell to minors, goods of any character or description. A minor, for the purposes of this section, is an individual 17 years of age or under. (Code 1962, § 13-77; Code 1986, § 14-65) Sec. 46-336. - Receiving or possessing prohibited items. No traveling or itinerant dealer, salesperson, or buyer shall take in pawn, or receive, sell, trade, or exchange any of the following named articles: knucks, dirk, sword-cane, blackjack, bowie knife, spring-back knife, switchblade knife, or any knife with a blade exceeding four inches in length, but it is not the intention thereof to prohibit case knives, butcher knives or other knives customarily used for domestic or industrial purposes only; nor shall they own or keep on hand any of the weapons named or referred to in this section. (Code 1962, § 13-78; Code 1986, § 14-66) Sec. 46-337. - Articles not to be disposed of seven days after acquisition. All traveling and itinerant dealers, salespersons, and buyers of gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals shall hold such goods so pledged, traded, or purchased by them for at least seven days before disposing of them in any way. (Code 1962, § 13-79; Code 1986, § 14-67) Sec. 46-338. - Surrender of stolen property. In the event it is determined that any item bought, sold, or traded to, or received by the traveling or itinerant dealer, salesperson or buyer is the subject of any theft or crime, the dealer, salesperson, or itinerant buyer shall, upon demand of the chief of police, or the chief's designee, surrender the same to the police department. (Code 1962, § 13-76; Code 1986, § 14-68) Sec. 46-339. - Penalties; suspension or revocation of authority to do business. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8. Further, any person failing to comply with any provision of this article, or such other laws or ordinances as may be passed by the city council shall, by vote of the city council, be barred from conducting business in the city until such time as they fully comply with this article. (Code 1962, § 13-82; Code 1986, § 14-69) Secs. 46-340—46-366. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE
Sec. 46-367. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Vehicle for hire means and shall refer to any vehicle utilized by a person has been issued a permit to transport persons for a fee by the chief of police consistent with the provisions of this article. Such a vehicle of hire shall be owned only by a person who has been issued a business license by the finance director for the operation of a vehicle for hire business within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1986, § 22-1; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-368. - Business license required; cost. In order to operate a vehicle for hire business within the corporate limits of the city, the owner of such business must obtain a business license from the finance director of the city for such business. The cost of such business license, which shall be paid at the time of application and which shall be nonrefundable, shall be in an amount to be determined from time to time by the city council. The issuance of such business license for a vehicle for hire business shall not authorize the owner of the business, or any other person employed by such owner, to engage in the vehicle for hire business until such owner complies with all of the other provisions of this article. (Code 1986, § 22-2; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-369. - Documentation required; notification of changes. The owner of such business shall keep on file with the chief of police documentation providing the name of the owner of the business, the owner's business address, all business telephone numbers listed in the owner's name, the names of all drivers of vehicles for hire employed by such owner, the permit number for each such driver, the home address of each such driver, and the total number of vehicles for hire that such owner operates as part of such business. Any changes in such information shall be reported by the owner in writing to the chief of police within 48 hours of such change. (Code 1986, § 22-3; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-370. - Regulations; compliance. Every owner of a vehicle for hire business shall comply with the following regulations: (1) Include in the application for such owner's business license the hours and service periods during which the vehicles for hire will be available to the public; (2) Provide a telephone call system for vehicle for hire customers and sufficient vehicles to provide the public with the service as contemplated in the license application; (3) Require vehicle for hire drivers to comply with all city, county, state, and federal statutes, laws, ordinances, and regulations; (4) Submit all vehicles used as vehicle for hire to inspection when requested by the chief of police or his designee for the purpose of maintaining all such vehicles in a safe, sanitary, and clean condition at all times; (5) Require that each vehicle for hire display the business name, the business telephone number or numbers, and the vehicle for hire permit number appropriately; (6) Maintain a record of all telephone calls requesting vehicle for hire service for a minimum of 90 calendar days from the date of such call for use by the police department if necessary; and (7) Require that each driver of a vehicle for hire maintain a daily written trip log or manifest. (Code 1986, § 22-4; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-371. - Serial numbers; locations; decals; size. Upon the issuance of a business license by the finance director to the owner of the vehicle for hire business, the finance director shall also provide to such owner a distinct serial number that shall be painted or stenciled on each vehicle for hire. One distinct serial number shall be issued to each vehicle for hire, and no two vehicles shall be authorized to use the same serial number. Such number shall be at least six inches in height and shall be placed on a conspicuous part of the vehicle for hire so that it may be visible. In addition, the name and address of the vehicle for hire business shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on all of the vehicles for hire at all times. The name of the driver shall be prominently displayed within all vehicles for hire. No vehicle for hire shall be authorized to operate within the corporate limits of the city as a vehicle for hire until compliance with the provisions of this section is completed. (Code 1986, § 22-5; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-372. - Business location in city. No vehicle for hire business shall operate in the city unless the owner thereof shall maintain a place of business within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1986, § 22-6; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-373. - Drivers' permits—Required; applications. (a) Any person, including any person who owns and operates a vehicle for hire business, who intends to drive a vehicle for hire within the corporate limits of the city, shall apply for a permit to do so from the police department. Such permit shall be applied for in writing upon such application forms as are deemed appropriate by the chief of police. Such application shall require such information as may be deemed necessary by the chief of police. Such permit shall be in addition to the vehicle for hire business license that the owner of such vehicle for hire business is required to obtain from the finance director as required by this chapter. (b) Such permit application shall be signed by at least two individuals who are personally familiar with the applicant and can testify to the applicant's good character. No person may sign such application as a reference who either owns a vehicle for hire business or who has, or is in the process of applying for, a permit to operate a vehicle for hire as a driver. Such application shall also be signed by the applicant. (c) No permit to operate a vehicle for hire shall be issued to any person who has not exhibited a familiarity with this article and the traffic laws, statutes, ordinances, and regulations of the state, who has been convicted by the state or any other state of a felony within the past five years, or who has been convicted of three or more moving traffic offenses during the five years immediately preceding the date of the application; provided, however, that any applicant who has been convicted of a felony within the prescribed time may be issued a permit if the chief of police has determined that the sentence imposed for such felony conviction has been served, that the service of such sentence has been completed for at least three calendar years from the date of the application, and the nature of the felony for which such applicant was convicted is determined by the chief of police not to be such an offense that would adversely impair the applicant's ability to operate a vehicle for hire and would not endanger or be reasonably likely to expose any vehicle for hire passengers to an unacceptable risk of bodily injury, property damage or loss. (Code 1986, § 22-7; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 46-374. - Same—Valid state driver's license. In order for a person to receive a permit to operate a vehicle for hire within the city, such person must have attained the age of at least 18 years and must possess a valid state driver's license issued by the state department of motor vehicles of the appropriate class under O.C.G.A. title 40 (O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.) that would authorize the applicant to drive persons in a vehicle for hire. Any loss of the privilege to drive a motor vehicle arising out of or in connection with the permit holder's arrest for or violation of any of the traffic or drug statutes or ordinances of this state, any other state, or any county or municipality located in this or any other state, shall immediately invalidate any permit to operate a vehicle for hire issued under this article. (Code 1986, § 22-8; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-375. - Health certificate; vision certificate. Each person applying for a permit to drive a vehicle for hire shall furnish a health certificate and a vision certificate to the chief of police with such permit application. The health certificate shall be signed by a practicing physician in good standing and the vision certificate shall be signed by a practicing ophthalmologist or optometrist in good standing. The form of the certificate must be approved by the chief of police. (Code 1986, § 22-9; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-376. - Drivers permit—Examination; familiarity with this article and traffic laws. No person shall be authorized to drive a vehicle for hire carrying passengers until such person has exhibited, upon examination by the chief of police or his designee, a familiarity with the provisions of this article and the traffic statutes, laws, ordinances, and regulations in force in the city. The chief of police shall provide at least one copy of the vehicle for hire article to each vehicle for hire driver. (Code 1986, § 22-10; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-377. - Same—Expiration date. Each permit issued to a driver of a vehicle for hire shall expire on December 31 of the year in which such permit was issued. Applications for renewal of such permit shall be accepted by the police department between December 1 and December 31 of each calendar year, but no person shall be authorized to operate a vehicle for hire beyond December 31 of any calendar year until such person's application for a new or renewal permit is approved in accord with this article. (Code 1986, § 22-11; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-378. - Same—Application fee; permit display. (a) The application fee required to be paid at the time of the submission of the application for a permit as a driver of a vehicle for hire, shall not be prorated. (b) The permit issued to a successful applicant shall be numbered, dated as of the date of issue, and shall have such other information displayed thereon as may be deemed appropriate by the chief of police. (c) The permit shall, at all times when the permittee is engaged in driving a vehicle for hire within the city, be displayed in a conspicuous place by said permittee in the vehicle so that the permit can be easily seen by passengers riding in said vehicle for hire. (Code 1986, § 22-12; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-379. - Liability insurance. (a) Each applicant for a vehicle for hire business license shall, before the license is granted, provide evidence of a policy or certificate of motor vehicle liability insurance, with respect to each vehicle to be operated as a vehicle for hire, with coverage in the following amounts: (1) Ten thousand dollars for injury to one person; (2) Twenty-five thousand dollars for injury to more than one person in any one accident; and (3) Five thousand dollars for property loss or damage. (b) Such insurance shall be issued by a company authorized to do business in the state. The policy or certificate of insurance shall identify all vehicles insured under such policy and shall contain a provision obligating the insurance carrier to provide notice of cancellation or modification of the policy to the chief of police within 15 calendar days after such a cancellation or modification. In the event of lapse, cancellation, or termination of such policy or certificate of insurance, or in the event that such coverage as required above are no longer afforded under such policy or certificate of insurance, then the license for the vehicle for hire business shall be deemed to have immediately expired. (c) In lieu of such liability insurance requirement, the licensee shall be authorized to operate as a "self-insurer" if such operation is otherwise authorized under O.C.G.A. § 33-34-5.1. (Code 1986, § 22-13; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-380. - Rates posted in vehicle, visible to passengers. The rates charged by vehicles for hire must be posted in the vehicle, for inspection by passengers at all times. (Code 1986, § 22-14; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-381. - Inspection by police department; driver and vehicle. Each person who drives a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city shall submit to inspection of both the vehicle and the driver by a certified police officer of the city police department whenever directed to do so. (Code 1986, § 22-15; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003) Sec. 46-382. - Suspension or revocation of license or permit. (a) In the event that the owner of the vehicle for hire business fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article, the finance director shall be authorized to suspend or revoke the business license previously issued to such owner. In the event of such a suspension or revocation, notice of such decision shall be communicated to the owner in writing by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Such notice is deemed to be effective upon personal service or upon mailing. Any suspension hereunder shall be for such duration as the finance director deems appropriate, but any such suspension shall not exceed 30 calendar days. Violation of a written notice of suspension by the owner shall be grounds for revocation of the owner's license to operate such vehicle for hire business. (b) In the event that a person issued a permit to drive a vehicle for hire violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article, then the chief of police shall be authorized to suspend or revoke such permit. In the event of such a suspension or revocation, notice of such decision shall be communicated to the permittee in writing by personal service or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Such notice is deemed to be effective upon personal service or upon mailing. Any suspension hereunder shall be for such duration as the chief of police deems appropriate, but any such suspension shall not exceed 30 calendar days. Violation of a written notice of suspension by the permittee shall be grounds for revocation of the permittee's permit to drive a vehicle for hire. (c) Any person whose business license to operate a vehicle for hire business, or whose permit to drive a vehicle for hire in the city has been suspended or revoked, has the right to appeal such suspension or revocation to the city council within ten calendar days of the effective date of such suspension or revocation. Such appeal must be in writing, must be submitted to the city official who ordered such suspension or revocation, and must set out the grounds upon which the appellant contends that the suspension or revocation was erroneously issued. The city manager of the city shall be notified of the filing of such an appeal and shall schedule a hearing thereon by the city council within 30 calendar days from the date of filing such appeal. In considering such appeal, the city council shall affirm the action or decision of the finance director or the chief of police, as the case may be, if the city council finds that such decision was supported by any evidence. (Code 1986, § 22-16; Ord. No. O-03-12-41, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Secs. 46-383—46-400. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - FEES AND CHARGES
Sec. 46-401. - Fee schedule. The fees and charges to be charged by the city are more particularly established and adopted in accord with the following fee schedule attached to the ordinance from which this article derives and incorporated into this article as follows:
(Ord. No. O-08-02-01, exh. A, 2-21-2008; Ord. No. O-08-12-42, exh. A, 12-18-2008; Ord. No. O-09-03-06, exh. A, 3-19-2009; Ord. No. O-09-04-12, exh. A, 4-23-2009; Ord. No. O-09-04-13, exh. A, 4-23-2009; Ord. No. O-09-05-16, exh. A, 5-21-2009; Ord. No. O-09-12-35, exh. A, 12-17-2009; Ord. No. O-10-04-09, exh. A, 4-22-2010; Ord. No. O-10-12-43, exh. A, 12-16-2010; Ord. No. O-11-12-34, exh. A, 12-15-2011; Ord. No. O-12-02-02, exh. A, 2-23-2012; Ord. No. O-12-04-11, exh. A, 4-19-2012; Ord. No. O-2012-26, 10-18-2012; Ord. No. O-2012-29, exh. A, 12-20-2012; Ord. No. O-2013-10, 4-18-2013; Ord. No. O-2014-21, 12-18-2014; Ord. No. O-2015-7, exh. A, 4-15-2015; Ord. No. O-2015-17, exh. A, 10-22-2015; Ord. No. O-2015-19, exh. A, 12-17-2015; Ord. No. O-2016-7, 12-22-2016; Ord. No. O-2017-6, Exh. A, 6-22-2017; Ord. No. O-2017-14, exh. A, 12-21-2017) Secs. 46-402—46-450. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - DUE COMPENSATION APPLICABLE TO ANY TELEGRAPH OR TELEPHONE COMPANY
Sec. 46-451. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. (a) The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenue, as defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 46-5-1(b)(8), (9); provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement, shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement, or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement, shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. (b) Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (Ord. No. O-09-08-29, 8-20-2009) Sec. 46-452. - Authorized designee. The city manager of the city shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day to day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. and shall perform the following duties: (1) Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies; (2) Report the receipt of a completed application to the city council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application; (3) Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to insure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and the ordinance from which this article derives; (4) Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and the ordinance from which this article derives; (5) Arrange and evaluate, no more than once per year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation; (6) Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way, written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Ord. No. O-09-08-29, 8-20-2009; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015)

div.head: Chapter 50 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 50-1. - Recreational vehicles at nursing homes or convalescent centers. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the parking of recreational vehicles on property owned and controlled by a nursing home or convalescent home where the following conditions are met: (1) The area where such recreational vehicles are to be parked is paved with asphalt or other suitable paving material and is not larger than 15,000 square feet. (2) The area where the recreational vehicles are to be parked is not located adjacent to a city street or state highway but is located at least 500 feet from the right-of-way of any city street or state highway. (3) No occupant of any recreational vehicle may reside at such location for more than 30 consecutive days and that there are no more than ten recreational vehicles parked at such location at any one time. (4) The owner of the nursing home or convalescent home shall be authorized to establish electrical connections and running water connections to the area set aside for the parking of such recreational vehicles, but such electrical connections and water connections shall, in all respects comply with the other provisions of this Code. (5) Under no circumstances shall any sewage from such recreational vehicles be disposed of in the city's sewerage system, but the owner of the nursing home or convalescent home shall be responsible for ensuring that all such sewage is disposed of properly in appropriate locations. (6) The owner or operator of any recreational vehicle parked in accord with the terms of this section shall not be required to pay any rent or lease for the space utilized by such vehicle; nor shall such owner or operator be charged for the use of any electricity or water at such location. (7) Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing herein shall prohibit the owner of a recreational vehicle who resides at a nursing home or convalescent center from parking his recreational vehicle at such location during such times and for such lengths of time as he or she may deem appropriate, and the nursing home or convalescent center shall be authorized to permit the owners of such recreational vehicles to connect to the electrical and water connections at such parking area. (Code 1986, § 21-16; Ord. No. O-97-02-03, 2-20-1997) Secs. 50-2—50-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAILER CAMPS
Sec. 50-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Automobile trailer, trailer coach, or trailer means any vehicle or structure so designed and constructed in such manner as will permit occupancy thereof as sleeping quarters for one or more persons, for the conduct of any business or profession, occupancy or tract, or use as a selling of advertising device, and so designed that it is or may be mounted on wheels and used as a conveyance on highways or city streets, propelled or drawn by its own or other motor power, excepting a device used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. Trailer camp means any park, trailer park, trailer court, court, camp, site, lot, parcel, or tract of land designed, maintained or intended for the purposes of supplying a location or accommodations for any trailer coach or trailer coaches and upon which any trailer coach or trailer coaches are parked and shall include all buildings used or intended for use a part of the equipment thereof whether a charge is made for the use of the trailer camp and its facilities or not. The term "trailer camp" shall not include automobile or trailer sales lots on which unoccupied trailers are parked for purposes of inspection and sale. Unit means a section of ground in a trailer camp of not less than 1,000 square feet of unoccupied space in an area designated as the location for only one automobile and one trailer. (Code 1986, § 21-1; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-22. - License. (a) Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained upon any property owned or controlled by him, a trailer camp within the limits of the city without having first secured a license therefor. Such license shall expire one year from the date of issuance but may be renewed under the provisions of this chapter for additional periods of one year. (b) Application. The application for such license or the renewal thereof shall be filed with the finance director, there will be no such fee charged for this license, for each unit in the existing or proposed camp. The application for a license or renewal thereof shall be made on such printed forms or other documents as may be furnished by the finance director and shall include the name and address of the owner of the tract and such a legal description of the premises, upon which the trailer camp is or will be located as will readily identify and definitely locate the premises. The application shall be accompanied by four copies of the camp plan showing the following, either existing or as proposed: (1) The extent and area to be used for camp purposes. (2) Roadways and driveways. (3) Location of sites or units for trailer coaches. (4) Location and number of sanitary conveniences, including toilets, washrooms, laundries and utility rooms to be used by occupants of units. (5) Method and plan for sewage disposal. (6) Method and plan for garbage removal. (7) Plan for water supply. (8) Plan for electrical lighting of the units. (c) Recommendation; procedure. Before such license may be issued, there must be a favorable recommendation by the majority of the planning commission and the plan and premises must be inspected and approved by the chief of the fire department and the county health department. Upon obtaining the recommendation of the planning commission, the chief of the fire department, and the county health department, the license application shall be transmitted to the city council for public hearing. Such public hearing shall be conducted in the same manner as public hearings are conducted for rezoning or amendments to the zoning chapter, with the additional requirement that the city council shall consider and determine whether or not the proposed camp complies with the requirements contained in this chapter. After initial approval of the application and the granting of the license by the city council, the city council shall not be required to have a public hearing on the renewal of such license in subsequent years unless so requested by the planning commission, the chief of the fire department, or the county health department, or where a license previously issued shall have expired prior to the renewal thereof. (d) Determination. Upon the conclusion of the public hearing, the city council shall determine whether or not to grant the license to the applicant. (e) Limitations. Licenses issued under the terms of this chapter convey no right to erect any building, to do any plumbing work or to do any electrical work. (Code 1986, § 21-2; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-23. - Zoning. (a) No trailer camp shall be located in any zone within the city limits other than an R-4 MH residential district, as amended. (b) No trailer or tourist camp shall be located within the limits of the city unless city water and sewer connections and fire protection facilities are available. (c) No occupied trailer or any other building shall be located within the city limits within the recognized setback line for the zoning district in which such trailer is located nor less than ten feet from any other building or vehicle or the boundary line of the tract on which located. (d) No trailer camp shall be licensed or operated in conjunction with or as part of a mobile home park or as a part of a mobile home subdivision. (Code 1986, § 21-3; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-24. - Plan for stormwater, driveways, electricity, etc., required. (a) Every trailer camp shall be located on a well-drained area, and the premises shall be properly graded so as to prevent the accumulation of stormwater or other waters. (b) Units shall be clearly designated and the camp so arranged so that all units shall face or abut on a driveway of not less than 16 feet in width, giving easy access from all units to a public street. Such driveway shall be maintained in good condition having natural drainage into a city street catchbasin, be well lighted at night, and shall not be obstructed. (c) The camp shall be laid out so that no trailer shall be located farther than 200 feet from the toilets and service buildings provided for herein, and walkways to such buildings shall be well lighted at night. (d) Every trailer unit shall be furnished with an electric service outlet. Such outlet shall be equipped with an externally operated switch or fuse of not less than 30 amperes capacity, and heavy duty outlet receptacle. (Code 1986, § 21-4; Ord. No. O-90-07-18, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-25. - City water required; adequate faucets and hot water. (a) An adequate supply of pure water, furnished through a pipe distribution system connected directly with the city water main, with supply faucets located not more than 200 feet from any trailer shall be furnished for drinking and domestic purposes. (b) No common drinking vessels shall be permitted, nor shall any drinking water faucets be placed in any toilet room. (c) An abundant supply of hot water shall be provided at all times for bathing, washing and laundry facilities. (Code 1986, § 21-5; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-26. - Service building requirements; accommodations based on plan. (a) Every trailer camp shall have erected thereon, at a distance not greater than 200 feet from any unit it is designed to serve, a suitable building for housing toilets, showers, and laundry facilities as required by this article. (b) There shall be provided separate toilet rooms for each sex. Flush toilets provided with an adequate water supply shall be enclosed in separate compartments and shall be provided for each sex in the ratio of one toilet for each eight units. (c) Separate bathing facilities for each sex shall be provided with one shower for each eight units. (d) Laundry facilities shall be provided. (e) The accommodations, specified in this section, shall be based on the total camp capacity according to its accepted plans. (Code 1986, § 21-6; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-27. - Connection to city sewer system required; garbage collection by city services. (a) All waste from showers, toilets, laundries, faucets and lavatories shall be wasted into a sewer system extended from and connected with the city sewer system. (b) All sanitary facilities in any trailer that are not connected with the city sewer system by means of rigid pipe connections shall be sealed and their use is hereby declared unlawful. (c) Each faucet site shall be equipped with facilities for drainage of waste and excess water into the sewer. In no case shall any wastewater be thrown or discharged upon the surface of the ground or disposed of by means other than is herein provided. (d) Every unit shall be provided with a wheeled container supplied by the city for garbage depository from which the contents shall be removed by the city garbage collection services. (Code 1986, § 21-7; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-28. - Length of stay; number of occupants. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to remain or live in any trailer or tourist camp for more than 90 days in each 12-month period, unless an exception to this requirement is approved by the city manager of the city, or his designee, and such exception may be approved for good cause only. (b) No trailer may be inhabited by a greater number of occupants than that for which it was designed. (Code 1986, § 21-8; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 50-29. - Management. At all times, the management (licensee) shall: (1) Keep a register of all guests, showing for such guests: a. Names and addresses. b. Dates of entrance and departure. c. License numbers of all trailers and towing or other automobiles. d. States issuing such licenses. e. Place of last location and length of stay. (2) Maintain the camp in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all times. (3) See that the provisions of this chapter are complied with and enforced and report promptly to the proper authorities any violations of this chapter or any other violations of law which may come to their attention. (4) Prevent the running loose of dogs, cats or other animals or pets. (5) Maintain in convenient places, approved by the chief of the fire department, hand fire extinguishers in the ratio of one to each eight units. (6) Prohibit the lighting of open fires on the premises. (7) Prohibit the use of any trailer by a greater number of occupants than that which it is designed to accommodate. (8) Report to the county health department all cases of persons or animals infected or suspected of being infected with any communicable disease. (Code 1986, § 21-9; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-30. - Compliance with plumbing, electrical and building ordinances. All plumbing, electrical, building and other work on or at any camp licensed under this chapter shall be in accord with the ordinances of the city regulating such work unless such ordinances are specifically made inapplicable under the terms of this chapter. (Code 1986, § 21-10; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-31. - Parking restricted. (a) It shall be unlawful within the city limits for any person to park any trailer on any street, alley or highway, or other public place, or on any tract of land owned by any person, occupied or unoccupied, within the city, except as provided in this chapter. (b) Emergency or temporary stopping or parking is permitted on any street, alley or highway for not longer than one hour, subject to any other and further prohibitions, regulations, or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations or ordinances of that street, alley or highway. (c) No person shall park or occupy any trailer on the premises or any occupied dwelling or on any lot which is not part of the premises of any occupied dwelling, either of which is situated outside an approved trailer camp; except, the parking of only one unoccupied trailer in an accessory private garage building, or in a rear yard in any district, is permitted, provided no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced in said trailer while such trailer is so parked or stored. (Code 1986, § 21-11; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990) Sec. 50-32. - Revocation. The planning commission is hereby authorized to revoke any license issued pursuant to the terms of this article if after due investigation they determine that the holder thereof has violated any of the provisions of this article or that any trailer or trailer camp is being maintained in an unsanitary or unsafe manner or is a nuisance. (Code 1986, § 21-12; Ord. No. O-90-07-19, 7-23-1990)

div.head: Chapter 54 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 54-1. - Bail bond or confinement in jail; failure to appear; forfeiture procedure; surrender of principal. (a) The chief of police, any police officer or the judge of the municipal court may take bond with security or bond without security or a cash bond at their discretion, payable to the city, in a sum not exceeding $1,200.00 for the appearance of any person accused or suspected of being guilty of a violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city to stand to and abide trial in the municipal court of the city, and also as a witness to testify in any case pending or about to be commenced in the municipal court. (b) If any party or witness shall fail or refuse to give the bond and security, as required, such person so failing or refusing may be confined in the jail of the county, to be kept under a guard, so as to be present to abide the trial or to testify, as the case may be. (c) All bail taken under this chapter shall be special bail, and the power of the security over the principal, shall be the same as in special bail. Upon the failure to appear of any principal in any bond or recognizance given by a person charged with a violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the city, or by witness to appear to testify, the recorder shall pass a rule requiring the principal and securities on such bond to show cause on any day therein named, not to be less than ten days from the passage of such rule why they should not be required to pay the amount of such bond. (d) A copy of said rule shall be served upon the principal and security by the finance director or any officer or member of the police force, if the principal is to be found in the city or within the county, at least five days before the time therein set for hearing of the same. (e) If no sufficient cause is shown, the municipal judge shall proceed to enter judgment against such principal and securities for the amount of said bond, and the finance director shall issue execution for the amount of such judgment and shall proceed to collect the same by levy and sale as in the case of tax executions. (f) Any surety upon a bail bond of any person charged with a violation of this Code or any other city ordinance, may surrender the principal at any time, to any member of the police force, who shall confine such principal in the jail of the county until discharged by the order of the municipal court, or by giving other and good security. The delivery of the principal as aforesaid, shall discharge the surety of all further liability upon such bond; provided, that such delivery shall be before any judgment of forfeiture upon said bond shall have been entered. (Code 1962, §§ 19-2—19-5; Code 1986, §§ 8-3—8-6; Ord. No. O-03-09-23, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) State Law reference— Authority to provide for bond forfeitures, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-4. Sec. 54-2. - Additional penalties. (a) In every case in which the municipal court shall impose a fine, which shall be construed to include costs, for any offense against a criminal or traffic law of this state, or against an ordinance of this city, there shall be imposed by the judge of the municipal court at the time of sentencing an additional penalty in the amount set by ordinance. (b) The sums provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be assessed and collected by the officer or agent of the court charged with the duty of collecting monies arising from such fines, and such funds shall be paid over to the city treasury at such time as may be required by the finance director. (c) An amount equal to all funds remitted to the city treasury as provided for in this section for the immediately preceding calendar year shall be appropriated to fund the acquisition, maintenance, and operation of information technology equipment and services to be used in the city police department. Such funds shall be exclusively expended for such purposes, and any funds not so expended in any calendar year shall not lapse, but shall be available for use for the same purposes in the next succeeding city fiscal year. Notwithstanding the foregoing, such funds, and the information technology equipment and services for which such funds are to be expended, shall be included as items in the city police department section of the annual operating budget of the city as approved by the city council on an annual basis. (Code 1986, § 8-9; Ord. No. O-04-03-06, 3-18-2004)

div.head: Chapter 58 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 58-1. - Abatement of nuisances, officials designated to petition municipal court; authority of officials to inspect nuisance conditions. (a) The chief of police, the chief of the fire and emergency services department, and the building official, or their respective designees, are each hereby authorized to petition the municipal court to abate any nuisance, as defined under the laws of this state or under the ordinances of this city, which is created or maintained within the city. (b) The chief of police, the chief of the fire and emergency services department, and the building official, and their respective designees, are authorized and empowered to enter upon any real property and structure at reasonable times to inspect the real property and structure for existing or complained of nuisances thereon or therein. (c) The authority granted in this section shall be applicable to nuisances which are violations of state law, nuisances which are violations of city ordinances, including, but not limited to, nuisances which arise in accord with the provisions of article II and article III of this chapter of the Code of Ordinances. (Code 1962, § 2-74; Code 1986, § 12-7; Ord. No. O-10-04-12, 4-22-2010) Sec. 58-2. - Same—Penalties for having a nuisance or failure to abate a nuisance. (a) Any person who is found guilty of violating the nuisance ordinances of the city, including, but not limited to, the nuisance ordinances referenced in article II and the nuisance ordinances referenced in article III of this chapter, shall, upon conviction of a first offense thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code; provided, however, that the minimum fine upon such first conviction shall be $100.00. Upon a second conviction of maintaining a nuisance, such person shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code; provided, however, that the minimum fine for such conviction shall be $300.00. Upon a third or subsequent conviction of maintaining a nuisance, such person shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code; provided, however, that the minimum fine for such conviction shall be $500.00. (b) Each day in which the court finds that the nuisance has existed shall constitute a separate offense, and each such offense shall subject the violator, upon conviction, to the penalties provided in subsection (a) hereof for each such offense. (c) Any person who fails to abate a nuisance within a time period as ordered by the judge of the municipal court may be subject to punishment for contempt by the judge pursuant to the provisions of subsection 4-104(b) of the City Charter. Any penalty for contempt shall be in addition to the penalties that may be imposed in accord with subsections (a) and (b) hereof. (Code 1962, § 2-75; Code 1986, § 12-8; Ord. No. O-10-04-12, 4-22-2010) Secs. 58-3—58-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LOT CLEARING
Sec. 58-23. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Ashes means and includes the waste product from coal, wood, or other fuels used for cooking and heating from private residences. Building refuse means solid waste generated from construction or demolition activities undertaken on property located within the corporate limits of the city. Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses, and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Common continuing nuisance means a wrong that arises from unreasonable, unhealthful, unwarranted, or unlawful use by a person of his property, either real or personal, or from his improper, indecent or unlawful personal conduct, working an obstruction or an injury to the rights of the public, and producing material annoyance, inconvenience, discomfort or hurt to the public continuously or at frequent intervals. Contractor means any person, and the agents and employees thereof, engaged in construction, electrical, mechanical, air conditioning, heating, plumbing, roofing, demolition, landscaping, masonry, allied work, nurserymen, and grounds keepers. Debris means residue of any nature accumulating from the activities enumerated in the definition of contractor. Garbage means all vegetable and animal matter, food, and other refuge from a kitchen, market, store, or elsewhere, including all matter that decays, attracts flies, and creates disagreeable odors. Industrial refuse means waste materials from factories, processing plants, wholesale establishments, assembling plants, food processing wastes, cinders and ashes, lumber scraps, sawdust, shavings, and any other waste products from industrial and manufacturing processes. Junk means old, scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber debris, including tires, waste, junked, dismantled, or wrecked automobiles, trucks, or other vehicles or parts thereof, iron, steel, used household appliances, bottles, containers, boxes, barrels, and plastic. Nuisance means stagnant water on-premises, loud or unusual noises which are detrimental to the public, including without limiting the foregoing, unusual loud disturbances in or around churches or multiple-family complexes such as loud music and other activities; dead or decaying matter which is odorous or capable of causing disease or annoyance to others; obstruction of a public street, highway, sidewalk; unused refrigerators, washing machines and other similar unused or unusable appliances; an accumulation of debris, objects, materials, and other conditions which may constitute a health, accident, or fire hazard, or which creates a blighting or deteriorating effect; any weeds, grasses, or plants other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants, growing to a height of 12 inches anywhere in the city; any vacant lot whereon debris is permitted to accumulate or vegetation, e.g., kudzu, is allowed to remain uncontrolled, in such a manner as to create a fire or other hazard to the public health, safety, or welfare; and any other condition constituting a nuisance under state law. Rubbish means a variety of nonrecyclable household waste derived from places of residence and shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, broken glass bottles and jars, crockery, rubber, discarded clothing, and similar materials. Waste means unwanted or discarded material including, but not limited to, ashes, building refuse, garbage, hazardous waste, industrial refuse, recyclable waste, rubbish, solid waste, and yard debris. Wrong means a violation of public rights and duties which affect the community. Yard debris means tree limbs, branches, stumps and logs, twigs, grass and shrub trimmings and clippings, bushes, weeds, leaves, and general yard and garden waste materials, and includes stone and dirt rakings and similar waste materials resulting from landscaping activities. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-24. - Prohibited generally. (a) Debris that hinders free use of right-of-way. Except for yard clippings and similar debris intended to be picked up by public waste disposal services, it shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, throw, place, or cause to be deposited, thrown, or placed, into or upon any public square, street, alley, or sidewalk of the city, or on the property of another without such person's permission, any paper, rags, shavings, trash, rubbish, chips, ashes, oyster shells, cuttings of vines, shrubbery or trees, filth, offal, rotten fruit, vegetables, dead animals, liquids, or any other thing which is or may become offensive, or which may damage any of said public squares, streets, alleys or sidewalks, or interfere with the free use and enjoyment of the same. (b) Property owners or lessees to maintain. Except for yard clippings and similar debris intended to be picked up by public waste disposal services, no person shall sweep any trash, dirt, filth, clay, manure, or other objectionable matter from the sidewalks into the streets, nor shall any property owners or lessees permit any such to remain on the sidewalk in front of such person's property or on the space between the property line and outer edge of the sidewalk. (c) Injury to persons. It shall be unlawful for any person to create, carry on, or maintain any nuisance, which hurts or inconveniences any person. (d) Injury to health . It shall be unlawful for any person to create, carry on or maintain any nuisance, which tends to injure or does injure or jeopardize the health of any person. (e) Injury to property. It shall be unlawful for any person to create, carry on or maintain any nuisance within the city, which causes damage or injury to any other person's property. (f) Annoyance. No person shall keep or maintain on his premises any nuisance to the annoyance of his neighbor. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-25. - Storage of junked vehicles, garbage, trash, rubbish, scrap parts, household appliances, etc., on property. (a) It shall be illegal to store scrap parts of cars, household appliances, and other similar items on residential lots within the city, unless such items are located within a building or garage upon the premises. (b) It shall be illegal to use porches, decks, patios, or vacant lots for the storage of unused materials, construction materials, appliances, or other similar items that may cause injury to person or property. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-26. - Property owners required to keep premises in sanitary condition. (a) All property owners within the city are required to keep their premises in a clean, sanitary, and healthful condition. (b) It shall be the duty of every owner of any parcel of ground within the city to keep every house, building, establishment, lot, yard, and ground owned by such person at all times free from filth, carrion, impure or unwholesome matter, and noxious odors of any nature whatsoever. (c) No owner of any parcel of land within the city shall allow garbage, trash, junk, dirt, weeds, vines, grass, or other vegetation or trash or rubbish to grow, or accumulate thereon, which would likely become a breeding place for snakes, rats, flies, gnats, mosquitoes, or other harmful or dangerous creatures or insects, or is likely to cause personal injury or property damage by human illness or fire, or which may become a health hazard for any other reason, or which may become a hazard to traffic on the public streets in the city. Nothing herein shall be construed to require the removal of trees and other vegetation from any parcel of land that has never been developed for residential, commercial, or industrial uses. (d) It shall be unlawful for any property owner or lessee to allow any weeds, grass, shrubbery or other rank vegetation of any character to grow between the property line and the outer edge of the street curb, and it shall be the duty of such owner or lessee to keep grass plots between the property line and the outer curb properly cut or mowed. (e) It shall be unlawful for any property owner in the city to allow noxious weeds and grasses to grow upon such person's premises over 12 inches in height. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-27. - Contractor debris. (a) It shall be the duty of every contractor in the city to use extra diligence in the work and conduct of such contractor's business, so that debris therefrom shall not be allowed to fall, be strewn upon, or accumulate upon the streets, sidewalks, and rights-of-way of the city. (b) In the event debris shall be allowed to fall, be strewn, or accumulate upon the streets or sidewalks, it shall be the duty of such contractor to remove such debris, within 12 hours of such debris being left upon the streets, leaving the street, sidewalks, and rights-of-way in a clean, clear, and uncluttered condition. Failure to do so shall be a violation of this Code. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-28. - Junked motor vehicles as nuisance. In the event that a junked motor vehicle falls within the prohibitions provided in this article and article III they shall apply to such junked motor vehicles and to abatements of any nuisances created by such junked motor vehicles. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Sec. 58-29. - Nuisance abatement. (a) Any owner of property who permits the same to become in a prohibited condition under this article shall be notified in writing by the code enforcement officer to remove the condition within 15 calendar days of the date of such notification. (b) Unless the condition complained of is removed, the city, at the expiration of such 15-calendar-day period shall remove the condition or hire a private contractor to remove the condition. (c) The cost thereof will be charged against the property and the property owner thereof, and it shall constitute a lien on the property. (d) In the event the costs of abating the nuisance are not paid, the execution issuing hereunder shall be issued, enforced, and collected in the same manner as that provided by law for executions for ad valorem taxes due the city. (e) In addition, the creation of a nuisance shall be deemed unlawful. (Ord. No. O-06-05-15, 5-18-2006) Secs. 58-30—58-46. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - JUNKED VEHICLES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority as to junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4.
Sec. 58-47. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases and words and their derivation shall have meanings respectfully given herein: Inoperative means not capable of being moved under its own power without additional work or repairs being completed to the motor vehicle or without any additional components being added to or placed upon said motor vehicle. Junked motor vehicle means any motor vehicle, as defined in this article, which does not have, lawfully affixed thereto, both an unexpired license plate and a current license decal, or the condition of such motor vehicle is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, inoperative, abandoned or discarded. Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is or is intended to be self-propelled and designed to travel on the ground and shall include, but shall not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motor scooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts, campers and trailer, as well as any part thereof. Police chief means the police chief of the city or the chief's agents. Private property means any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. Public property means any street or highway, which shall include the entire width between the boundary lines of every publicly maintained way and dedicated to the purposes of vehicular traffic and shall also mean any other publicly owned property or facility. (Code 1986, § 12-35; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 58-48. - Declared nuisance. No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any junked motor vehicle of any kind upon any private property within the city for a period of time in excess of 30 days. The presence of a junked motor vehicle or parts thereof on private property is hereby declared a public nuisance, which may be abated as such in accord with the provisions of this article. (Code 1986, § 12-36; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995) Sec. 58-49. - Exemptions. Those vehicles, which are exempted from the provisions of this article are as follows: (1) Any motor vehicles or parts thereof, which are located on the premises of licensed automobile dealers; (2) Any motor vehicles or parts thereof, which are located on the premises of any licensed junkyard operated in compliance with state and local laws relating to licensing, regulating and zoning of such junkyards; (3) Any motor vehicle enclosed within a building on private property which is not a hazard to public health and which is not an attractive nuisance to children; or (4) Any motor vehicle in operable condition specifically adapted or designed for operation on drag strips or raceways. (Code 1986, § 12-37; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995) Sec. 58-50. - Notice of violation. Whenever it comes to the attention of the code enforcement officer that any nuisance as defined in this chapter exists in the city, a notice in writing shall be served upon the occupant of the real property where the nuisance exists, upon the owner of the property, and upon the owner of the junked motor vehicle or other property which constitutes such nuisance, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and directing its removal within 15 days. In the event that such owners cannot be located, or in the event that the address of such owners is unknown, then notice shall be made to the last known address of such owners, or in the event that the identity of such owners cannot be ascertained after due investigations, such notice shall be posted in a prominent location on the premises where the nuisance exists, and upon the junked motor vehicle itself. (Code 1986, § 12-38; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 58-51. - Responsibility for removal. Upon such notice, the owner of the junked motor vehicle, and the owner or occupant of the private property upon which the same is located, either, or all of them, shall be responsible for its removal. In the event that such owners fail to remove such vehicle and thereby abate such nuisance within the 15-day time period provided in the notice, the police chief shall be authorized to institute proceedings against such owner or owners in the municipal court of the city pursuant to the ordinances and rules of said court, and such persons shall be notified of the date and time of the hearing scheduled no later than five days prior to the date set for the hearing. Such notice shall be served upon such owner or owners in the same manner as provided in section 14-175. (Code 1986, § 12-39; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995; Ord. No. O-00-09-38, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-05-01-06, exh. A, 1-20-2005) Sec. 58-52. - Hearing. (a) At the hearing, the court shall determine the owner of the vehicle and whether or not a nuisance exists and, if so, the court shall order abatement of such nuisance and shall impose such penalty or penalties as may be authorized by this section for failure to abate such nuisance. (b) In the event that the court determines that a nuisance exists and abatement thereof is ordered, the court shall be authorized to grant the owner a period of time, not to exceed 15 days, to abate such nuisance. The court shall further include in its order provisions authorizing the city to abate such nuisance if such nuisance is not abated by the owner within the time period for such abatement as ordered by the court. Such order shall also include authority for the city to enter upon the premises upon which the nuisance exists and abate the same, and shall further provide that the cost of abatement of the nuisance incurred by the city shall be assessed against the owner of the premises upon which the nuisance existed. (Code 1986, § 12-40; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995) Sec. 58-53. - Abatement by the city. In the event that the nuisance is abated by the city pursuant to the authority of the order of the court authorized by this article, the city shall abate the nuisance in the following manner: (1) The city shall hire a wrecker service, or such other service as may be required, to remove the nuisance, and direct that the nuisance be removed to a local licensed junkyard or other similar facility. (2) The wrecker service hired to remove the nuisance shall notify the owner of the property and the owner of the motor vehicle within ten days of removal of the property of the location of the junked motor vehicle and of the cost incurred by the owner in connection with the abatement service. Such cost may include the actual cost of removal of the motor vehicle and storage charges, if applicable, up to and including the date of payment by the owner. (3) In the event that the owner does not pay the charges or otherwise recover the motor vehicle within such time as may be established by the wrecker service or by state law, the wrecker service may be authorized to recover its costs and expenses and dispose of the property in accord with general provisions of state law. (Code 1986, § 12-41; Ord. No. O-95-07-26, 7-20-1995) Sec. 58-54. - Procedures for purchasing junked vehicles by city.
