The procedures to be followed by the governing body in the event that such an application is submitted shall be the same procedures as previously outlined in this section, except that no application fee shall be required, and the application shall not require the signatures of 75 percent of the persons owning real property abutting the new street. (Ord. No. O-07-03-12, § 18-102, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-153. - Determination of name. (a) In making a determination as to the name to be given to a new street, if the street is proposed to be named after a natural person, the governing body shall take into consideration the following: (1) Whether such person has resided for a long period of time on such street; (2) Whether such person has made significant and long-lasting contributions to the city and its citizens; (3) Whether such person is a national or internationally prominent figure who has or may have a direct or indirect connection to the city and its citizens; (4) Whether such person has provided charitable or philanthropic contributions to the city and its citizens; (5) Whether such person has brought honor, prestige, or recognition in a positive manner to the city and its citizens; (6) Whether such person is a leader in local governmental, civic, educational, or public affairs; or (7) Whether such person is a distinguished and accomplished scholar, scientist, educational leader, business leader, government leader, or civic leader. In order to be considered for having a street named after a person, such person may be either living or deceased at the time of the street naming. With respect to a deceased individual, the application shall not be submitted until at least one year after the date of death of such person. With respect to a living person, such person must have reached the age of 75 years at the time of the submission of the application, unless such age limitation is affirmatively waived by the governing body of the city within 30 calendar days after the filing of the application required by section 78-152. (b) In the event that consideration is given to naming a new street after a business, an organization, or a nonprofit entity, the governing body of the city shall consider the following: (1) Whether such entity is located upon such street; (2) The length of time that such entity has been located on such street; (3) The length of time that such entity has been located within the city; (4) The civic, community, and educational contributions of the business to the city and its citizens; or (5) The length of time that such entity is expected to remain in business under the same name on such street. No street shall be named after any ongoing business, organization, or nonprofit entity which is not located upon the street to be named in honor of such entity. (c) In addition to the foregoing factors to be considered by the governing body in naming a new street, the governing body shall also be authorized to consider any and all other relevant factors that the governing body deems appropriate in making a street naming decision. (d) Unless waived by the governing body, new streets which are obviously in alignment with streets already in existence and already named shall be given the name of the existing street. In addition, no applications proposing to change the name of only a portion of a street shall be accepted by the city clerk. (Ord. No. O-07-03-12, § 18-103, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-154. - Prohibition. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit or interfere with the right of the State of Georgia or the Georgia Department of Transportation to name roads or streets under their respective ownership or jurisdiction in such manner as they may be authorized to do in accord with Georgia law or regulations promulgated thereunder. (Ord. No. O-07-03-12, § 18-104, 3-22-2007) Secs. 78-155—78-179. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CHANGING THE NAME OF EXISTING STREETS
Sec. 78-180. - Title. This division shall be known as the "changing the name of existing streets" division and may be referred to by that title. (Ord. No. O-07-03-13, § 18-150, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-181. - Authority. The governing body of the city shall have the sole power and authority to change the name of existing streets located within the incorporated limits of the city where such streets are owned by the City of Americus. (Ord. No. O-07-03-13, § 18-151, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-182. - Procedures. With respect to changing the name of an existing street owned by the city and located within the corporate limits of the City of Americus, the governing body shall be required to follow the following procedures with respect to changing the name of an existing street: (1) By application of a citizen or group of citizens. a. A citizen or group of city citizens may submit an application to change the name of an existing street hereunder. Such application shall be on forms prescribed by the city clerk. Such application shall not be considered unless at least 75 percent of the persons owning real property abutting such existing street submit a written application to the city clerk requesting that the name of such existing street be changed. b. Such application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of $100.00, which is intended to cover administrative and other costs which are anticipated to be incurred by the city in connection with its consideration of the application. Such application fee shall be deposited into the general fund of the city. c. The governing body of the city shall consider such application and act thereon in accord with this division no later than 90 calendar days after the date of submission of such application to the city clerk. In the event that the governing body does not act upon the application prior to the expiration of such 90 calendar day period, then the street shall be automatically renamed as requested in the application. d. Upon receipt of the application by the city clerk, the city clerk shall proceed to validate the application. The city clerk shall validate the application by verifying that the proper number of signatures is contained on the application and that the persons signing the application are owners of real property abutting said street as required by this division. In the event that the city clerk determines that the application is invalid for any reason, or that the application does not contain sufficient signatures, the application shall be returned to the person or persons submitting such application, and it shall not be subject to further consideration by the governing body until such time as a new application is submitted and the city clerk validates the new application. e. In determining the required percentage of the persons signing such application in connection with the validation thereof, where property abutting such street is owned by more than one person, the signature of only one such owner shall be counted in calculating such 75 percent. In addition, persons who rent or lease real property abutting such street may sign such application, but their signatures shall not be counted toward the 75 percent threshold for submission of the application to the governing body. Signatures on any such application signed more than 90 calendar days prior to the date of submission of the application to the city clerk shall be invalid and shall not be counted toward the 75 percent threshold. In the event that more than one application for changing the name of an existing street is presented to the city clerk, the city clerk shall validate such applications in the order received. The first application validated by the city clerk shall be presented to the governing body first, and only if the resolution to approve the application is denied shall the city clerk present the second or subsequent validated application to the governing body. f. The application shall be in such form as established by the city clerk. At a minimum, the application shall indicate thereon the location of the street, the proposed new name of the street, the printed name, street address, and signature of each property owner signing such application, and the date that each property owner signed the application. In addition, each such application shall include therewith a written statement which provides, in succinct detail, the reasons for the proposed street name change in honor of a particular person or business listed in the application. In providing such written statement, the criteria to be considered by the governing body regarding the changing of the name of such street as more particularly established in this division shall be specifically addressed by the application in such written statement accompanying the street name changing application. In addition, the application shall also list any public announcement or public recognition request that should accompany any official street name changing ceremony undertaken by the city in connection with the changing of the name of such street. g. In the event that the city clerk determines that the application is valid, then prior to the submission of the application to the governing body, the city clerk shall undertake the following: 1. Provide notification of the application to and compile for review by the governing body responses to the application from the following: i. All city agencies and departments, including, but not limited to; city police, city fire and EMS, city GIS system personnel, city building risk management risk department, and other city agencies or departments that the clerk deems appropriate; ii. All other local, state, or national agencies which the city clerk determines may be affected by the changing of the name of the street; iii. All schools located in the immediate vicinity of the street; iv. Any other persons or entities the city clerk deems, in his or her sole discretion, should receive notice of the proposed changing of the street's name. 2. Review existing public records for the purpose of establishing that the proposed street name does not duplicate any existing street name and is not confusingly similar to any existing street name in Americus or Sumter County. h. Upon the completion of the foregoing, the city clerk shall be required to place consideration of the application on the agenda for the city council meeting occurring in the calendar month after the month in which the application was finally validated. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the tabling of such proposal by the governing body, but in no event shall consideration of such proposal by the city council be delayed beyond 90 calendar days after the validated application was filed with the city clerk. i. Prior to the governing body considering or voting upon such application, the governing body shall hold a public hearing regarding such application. Notice of such public hearing shall be published once in the city's legal organ no later than the day prior to the date of the public hearing. Such public notice shall advise the public regarding the application, the proposed new street name, and the time and place of the scheduled public hearing before the governing body. Such public hearing shall be conducted with the same formality as that required of public hearings in connection with zoning and rezoning matters before the governing body. Upon conclusion of the public hearing, the governing body shall be authorized to vote on the application. j. In the event that the application is approved by an appropriate resolution of the governing body, the new name of the street shall take effect at such time as is determined by the governing body in such resolution. k. Upon adoption of the resolution by the governing body, the city clerk shall undertake the following: 1. Provide written notice to each property owner owning property abutting the street of the official name of the street as approved by the governing body; 2. Provide written notice of the new name of the street to the United States Postal Service; 3. Provide written notice of the new name of the street to the emergency 911 system in effect for the geographical area including the City of Americus. l. Within 60 calendar days of the effective date of the resolution adopting the new street name, the city utilities director shall have fabricated and installed appropriate signage regarding the new name of the street at such locations as deemed appropriate by the utilities director. (2) By the professional staff of the city. The professional staff of the city, or a member of the city council, may submit an application to change the name of an existing street. The procedures to be followed by the governing body in the event that such an application is submitted shall be the same procedures as previously outlined in section 78-152 of this division, except that no application fee shall be required, and the application shall not require the signatures of 75 percent of the persons owning real property abutting the existing street. (Ord. No. O-07-03-13, § 18-152, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-183. - Determination of renaming. (a) In making a determination as to changing the name of an existing street, if the street is proposed to be renamed after a natural person, the governing body shall take into consideration the following: (1) Whether such person has resided for a long period of time on such street; (2) Whether such person has made significant and long-lasting contributions to the city and its citizens; (3) Whether such person is a nationally or internationally prominent figure who has or may have a direct or indirect connection to the city and its citizens; (4) Whether such person has provided charitable or philanthropic contributions to the city and its citizens; (5) Whether such person has brought honor, prestige, or recognition in a positive manner to the city and its citizens; (6) Whether such person is a leader in local governmental, civic, educational, or public affairs; or (7) Whether such person is a distinguished and accomplished scholar, scientist, educational leader, business leader, government leader, or civic leader. (8) In order to be considered for having an existing street renamed named after a person, such person may be either living or deceased at the time that the street name is changed. With respect to a deceased individual, the application shall not be submitted until at least one year after the date of death of such person. With respect to a living person, such person must have reached the age of 75 years at the time of the submission of the application, unless such age limitation is affirmatively waived by the governing body of the city within 30 calendar days after the filing of the application required by section 78-152. (b) In the event that consideration is given to changing the name of an existing street so as to name such existing street after a business, an organization, or a nonprofit entity, the governing body of the city shall consider the following: (1) Whether such entity is located upon such street; (2) The length of time that such entity has been located on such street; (3) The length of time that such entity has been located within the city; (4) The civic, community, and educational contributions of the business to the city and its citizens; or (5) The length of time that such entity is expected to remain in business under the same name on such street. (6) No street shall be named after any ongoing business, organization, or nonprofit entity which is not located upon the street to be renamed in honor of such entity. (c) In addition to the foregoing factors to be considered by the governing body in changing the name of an existing street, the governing body shall also be authorized to consider any and all other relevant factors that the governing body deems appropriate in making a street naming decision. (d) No applications proposing to change the name of only a portion of a street shall be accepted by the city clerk. (Ord. No. O-07-03-13, § 18-153, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-184. - Prohibitions. Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit or interfere with the right of the State of Georgia or the Georgia Department of Transportation to name roads or streets under their respective ownership or jurisdiction in such manner as they may be authorized to do in accord with Georgia law or regulations promulgated thereunder. (Ord. No. O-07-03-13, § 18-154, 3-22-2007) Secs. 78-185—78-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - CITY SIDEWALK INSTALLATION
Sec. 78-201. - Title. This article shall be known as the "city sidewalk installation article." (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-201, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-202. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, as follows: City block is the smallest area that is surrounded by public streets within the incorporated area of the city. Lot owners means the owner or owners of record of each lot abutting a proposed sidewalk, whether or not there is constructed on such lot a dwelling, house, commercial building or other structure. Such term shall include both personal and business owners of such lots of record. Petition means a petition as more particularly described in section 78-203 of this article. (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-202, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-203. - Petition. (a) Whenever any lot owner or owners located within the corporate limits of the city desire to request the city to install a sidewalk fronting the property owned by such lot owner or owners along one or more sides of a city block, then such lot owner or owners shall notify the city clerk, who shall provide the lot owner or owners with a pre-printed petition, which petition shall be for the purpose of ascertaining the level of support for the installation of such sidewalk. At the time of providing the petition to the lot owner or owners, the city clerk shall determine an estimated installation cost of the proposed sidewalk, which cost shall be assessed to each lot owner in a prorated amount as established in this article, and such estimated cost shall be provided to the lot owner or owners requesting the application. (b) Such petition shall have typed thereon a title, which shall be "Petition Requesting the City of Americus to Install a Sidewalk Along the ____________ Side of ____________ Street from ____________ Street to ____________ Street." There shall further be typed thereon the following statement at the top of each page of the petition: The undersigned, by signing this petition, do hereby request the City of Americus to install a sidewalk as described above. The undersigned have been informed and do understand that if at least 75 percent of the record owners of lots abutting such proposed sidewalk sign this petition, the governing body of the city may authorize the installation of such sidewalk, and each record owner of a lot or lots abutting said sidewalk shall be required to pay the pro-rated cost of installation of such sidewalk as established by city ordinance. (c) Such petition shall thereafter have spaces for the printed name and address, the legal signature, and the date of signing for each lot owner who signs such petition. Such petition shall be returned to the city clerk within 90 calendar days of the date that the petition was delivered by the city clerk to the lot owner or owners requesting such petition. No such petition shall be returned to or accepted by the city clerk until at least 75 percent of the record lot owners abutting the proposed sidewalk shall have signed the petition. For purposes of ascertaining the 75 percent threshold, the following shall apply: (1) A lot owner may be counted as signing the petition only once, regardless of the number of lots such lot owner may own abutting said sidewalk. (2) Where property is owned by more than one person, the signature of only one such owner shall be counted in calculating such 75 percent. (3) Persons who rent or lease property abutting such proposed sidewalk may sign such petition, but their signatures shall not be counted toward the 75 percent threshold. (4) Where the lot owner is a corporation or other legal entity, the petition shall only be signed by an authorized officer or agent of the corporation. (d) Upon submission of said petition as a single petition to the city clerk, the city clerk shall cause the signatures thereon to be verified. The city clerk shall validate the petition by verifying that the proper number of signatures is contained on the petition and that the persons signing the petition are owners of real property abutting said proposed sidewalk as required by this article. In the event that the city clerk determines that the petition is invalid for any reason, or if the application does not contain sufficient signatures, the application shall be returned to the person or persons submitting such application, and it shall not be subject to further consideration by the governing body until such time as a new application is submitted and the city clerk validates the new application. Any persons who are not record owners of lots abutting the proposed sidewalk, or who are otherwise not authorized to sign such petition or have their signatures counted, shall have their names stricken from the petition and shall not be counted for purposes of ascertaining the 75 percent threshold. (e) If, after verification of the signatures, the city clerk determines that at least 75 percent of the lot owners owning real property abutting the proposed sidewalk have signed the petition, then said petition shall be presented to the governing body of the city at its next regular monthly meeting for consideration. In the event that the petition contains the properly verified signatures of at least 75 percent of the persons owning real property abutting the proposed sidewalk, the city council shall be authorized to approve the installation of the sidewalk, but the city council shall not be required to approve such installation. (f) If the installation of such sidewalk is approved by the city council, the appropriate city departments shall proceed with the installation of such sidewalk, which installation shall be performed in accord with applicable building and other codes. (g) The city shall provide all labor and materials required for the installation of the sidewalk. At the conclusion of the installation, the city clerk shall determine the actual total installation cost incurred by the city, including, but not limited to; the cost of labor, materials, right-of-way acquisition, surveys, and engineering costs. Such cost shall be determined within 30 calendar days of the completion of the installation. The finance director shall then determine the cost of the installation per linear foot and shall cause each lot owner abutting such subdivision to be billed an amount equal to such cost per linear foot times the number of linear feet owned by such lot owner abutting the installed sidewalk. Such bills shall be paid by the lot owners within 30 days of submission by the city. In the event that it is requested by one or more lot owners and approved by the governing body, and in lieu of payment of such cost of installation in one payment, as to any lot owner or owners so requesting, the city shall be authorized to bill each lot owner for such lot owner's prorated cost over a 12-month period; provided, however, that any lot owner requesting to be billed over a 12-month period shall also pay interest equal to one percent per month on the unpaid principal balance until all payments are paid in full. The sale of the lot prior to the lot owner's payment of such prorated cost shall not relieve the lot owner of the obligation to pay such cost in full as required by this article. Failure to pay any installment when due shall entitle the city to terminate utility services to the lot owner in the same manner as if the lot owner had failed to pay a city utility bill. Nothing herein shall prohibit the city from including the billing for the pro-rata share of the installation of such sidewalk to the lot owners in the lot owner's monthly utility bill. (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-203, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-204. - Application acceptance; right-of-ways. (a) The city shall not be required to install such sidewalk unless the city obtains from each lot owner a deed to such real property as the city may require in order for the city to construct said sidewalk. Such right-of-way shall be conveyed to the city in fee simple and at no cost or expense to the city. (b) No application for the construction of a sidewalk shall be accepted by the city clerk hereunder, unless such application includes the construction and paving of a sidewalk for the distance of at least one side of a city block. (c) No application shall be accepted by the city clerk hereunder for the repaving of an existing paved sidewalk. (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-204, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-205. - Maintenance and upkeep. Upon completion of the installation of the sidewalk, the city shall assume responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep thereof. (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-205, 3-22-2007) Sec. 78-206. - Prohibition. Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the city from undertaking to construct sidewalks at such locations as the city may deem appropriate and in the best interest of the city and its citizens, regardless of whether a petition as described in section 78-203 hereof, has been submitted to the city. Any such construction by the city shall be undertaken and completed at the sole cost and expense of the city. (Ord. No. O-07-03-11, § 18-206, 3-22-2007) Secs. 78-207—78-300. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - IMPROPER USE OF PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY
Sec. 78-301. - Urban camping and improper use of public property. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep, lie down, to reside upon, or to store personal property in any park, in any cemetery, upon any sidewalk, or in or upon any public property of the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to use any public park, cemetery, public sidewalk, or public property for living accommodations or for camping, except in areas specifically designated for such use. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person other than the owner, tenant, employee, or other person with permission from the owner, to camp, sleep, reside, store personal property upon, or lie down outside upon any private property without the owner's permission to do so. (d) Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, this section shall not apply to the following: (1) Persons sitting or lying down as a result of a medical emergency; (2) Persons sitting in wheelchairs while using parks, sidewalks or other public places; (3) Persons sitting down while attending parades for which valid permits have been issued; (4) Persons sitting down while patronizing outdoor cafes; (5) Persons sitting on chairs or benches supplied by a public agency or by an abutting private property owner; provided, however, that such exception shall not apply to persons sleeping, lying down, residing upon, or storing personal property upon such chairs or benches; (6) Persons sitting down or lying down while attending sporting events, performances, festivals and concerts taking place in any park, or upon any street or sidewalk where such event is authorized by the city; (7) Children under the age of 13 years sleeping in parks while being carried by or accompanied by another person over such age, or while sitting or lying in a baby stroller or carriage; (8) Persons offering the sale of merchandise, food, vegetables, fruit, produce and similar items from the sidewalk in front of a business where such sale is otherwise authorized by the City Code. (e) A person convicted of violating this Code section, or a person entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendre to a violation of this Code section, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of the City Code. Each day that a person violates this Code section shall be considered to be a separate offense. In no event shall a violation of this Code section be considered or held to be a lesser included offense of the offense of loitering as provided in section 62-114 of the City Code. (Ord. No. O-09-07-21, 7-23-2009)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 82-1. - Definitions; street classifications. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alleys means minor ways used primarily for vehicular services access to the rear or sides of commercial or industrial properties. Collector streets means a street used to carry traffic from minor streets to major streets, including the principal entrance streets to a neighborhood or group development and streets for circulation within such neighborhood or development. Streets are as defined in section 1-2, and for the purposes of these regulations, streets are classified as follows: Major streets means a street used primarily for fast or heavy traffic. Minor streets means a street used primarily for access to the abutting properties. Subdivision. (1) The term "subdivision" means any division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or the future sale, legacy or building development, and includes any division of land involving a new street or a change in one or more existing streets and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. (2) Provided, however, the following are not included in this definition: a. The subdivision of land for agricultural purposes provided no lot thereby produced is less than five acres or no new street is involved. b. The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining properties, provided that additional lots are not thereby created, and that the lots created are in accordance with other city regulations. c. The division of land into parcels where no new street is to be established and the resulting lots are equal to or larger than the standard required in the city, and a zoning classification of resulting lots remains the same as the zoning classification of the land before such division; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the rezoning, of such property on proper application and approval granted in accordance with this Code. (Code 1986, § 19-1; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-2. - Zoning; conflict of standards. (a) No final plat of land within the force and effect of an existing zoning regulations will be approved unless it conforms with such regulations. (b) Whenever there is a discrepancy between minimum standards or building code, or other official standards, the highest standard shall apply. (Code 1986, § 19-38; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-3. - Variances. Where the subdivider can show that a provision of these standards would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and where, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site, in the opinion of the planning commission a departure may be made without destroying the intent of such provisions, the planning commission may authorize a variance. Any variance thus authorized is to be stated in writing in the minutes of the planning commission with the reasoning on which the departure was justified set forth. (Code 1986, § 19-39; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-4. - Enforcement—Authorities designated; duties. The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the community development director and the planning commission. The community development director shall: (1) Receive all subdivision plats; (2) In cooperation with the planning commission review and approve or disapprove subdivision plats; (3) Inspect subdivisions for compliance with the requirement of this chapter and other applicable city ordinances. (Code 1986, § 19-2; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-5. - Same—Circumventing requirements; approval of plat required; access street required. (a) The owner or agent of the owner of any land to be subdivided within the city who transfers or sells or agrees to sell negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of or by other use of a plat to subdivide such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county, shall be denied all building permits, public services, and utility connections, and subject to punishment for ordinance violation and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. The city, through its attorney or other official designated by the city council, may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by appropriate action. (b) No plat or plan of subdivision within the city shall be filed or recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county until it has been approved by the planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the secretary of the planning commission. (c) No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the city unless the street giving access to the lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted or opened as, or shall have otherwise received the legal status of a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and line with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by said planning commission or with a street located and accepted by the city. Any building erected in violation of this section shall be deemed an unlawful structure, and the building official, city attorney or other official designated by the city council may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. (Code 1986, § 19-3; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-6. - Preliminary plat filing fee. The developer shall be assessed a filing fee in the amount established by ordinance payable to the finance director at the time of filing the preliminary plat. (Code 1986, § 19-4; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Secs. 82-7—82-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURES FOR PLAT APPROVAL
Sec. 82-31. - Generally. (a) The procedure for formal review and approval of a subdivision plat shall consist of the following three separate steps: (1) The subdivider should consult early and informally with the community development director and/or other city technical staff for advice and assistance before the preparation of the preliminary sketch plat and its formal application for approval. This will enable the subdivider to become thoroughly familiar with these standards, the major street plan and other official plans or public improvements that might affect the area. Such informal review should prevent unnecessary and costly revisions. (2) Prior to the making of any street improvement, or installations of utilities, the developer shall submit to the planning commission a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision. After receiving the planning commission's approval of the preliminary plat and full concurrence and approval by the city, the developer may then proceed to grade the streets and install all improvements required by this chapter and any other applicable city ordinances. In lieu of the completion of all improvements prior to submission of the final plat, the developer may post a bond with the city, or certified check, in an amount and with surety satisfactory to the city and conditions satisfactory to the city, providing for and securing to the city the actual construction and installation of such improvements within a period specified by the planning commission and stated in the bond. (3) After completion of the physical development of the subdivision or the posting of a bond or certified check to guarantee the same, the developer shall submit to the planning commission a final plat together with any required certificates. The final plat, along with any deed restrictions, becomes the instrument to be recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county. (b) No final subdivision plat shall be approved by the planning commission or accepted for record by the office of the clerk of the superior court of this county until the required improvements listed shall be constructed in satisfactory manner and approved by the appropriate approving agent. (Code 1986, § 19-20; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-32. - Preliminary plat. (a) At least ten days prior to the regular meeting of the planning commission the subdivider shall submit to the building official's office three copies of the plat of the proposed subdivision drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet, along with a receipt for the filing fee from the finance director. (b) The preliminary plat shall meet the minimum standards of design and general requirements for the construction of public improvements as set forth in article III of this chapter and shall give the following information insofar as possible: (1) Description: a. Proposed name of subdivision. b. Name and address of subdivider. c. Graphic scale, north point and date. The north point shall be identified as magnetic, true, or grid north. d. Location sketch map showing the relationship of the subdivision site to the surrounding area, including directions and distances to readily identifiable landmarks in the surrounding area. e. Acreage to be subdivided. (2) Existing conditions: a. Topography by contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet, or as determined necessary by the city utilities director, when a new street is involved in a subdivision, including outline of wooded areas and classifications of land. b. Zoning district classification on land to be subdivided and of adjoining land. c. Names and addresses of adjoining property owners or subdivisions. d. In case of resubdivision, a copy of existing plat with proposed resubdivision superimposed thereon. e. Location of streams, lakes and swamps and land subject to flood as determined from past history of flooding (listed on appropriate FEMA map). f. Location of existing and platted property lines, location, width and names of all platted roads, railroads, utility rights-of-way, public areas, existing buildings or structures. g. Existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract or within the right-of-way of boundary roads, with sizes, grades and invert elevations from public records, or from field surveys, or other sources. All sizes and data on all utilities shall be provided. h. Certification by the county health officer when individual sewage disposal or water systems are to be installed. (3) Proposed conditions: a. Layout of roads, alleys and public crosswalks, with widths, road names or designations. b. Layout of all lots and the area of each lot, including building setback lines and lot divisions with scaled dimensions and utility easements with width and use on all lots. c. Preliminary plan of all utilities to be constructed. d. Designation of all land to be reserved or dedicated for public use. (c) Within 30 days after submission of the preliminary plat, the planning commission shall review it and indicate its approval, disapproval, or approval subject to listed modifications, as a basis for preparation of the final plat. If a plat is disapproved, reasons for such disapproval will be stated in the records of the planning commission. Failure of the planning commission to act on the preliminary sketch within 30 days will be deemed approval of this plat, unless the developer agrees to an extension of time. (d) Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall not constitute acceptance of the final plat and shall not be indicated on the preliminary plat. (e) The approval of the preliminary plat shall lapse until a final plat based thereon is submitted within one year from the date of such approval, unless an extension of time is applied for and granted by the planning commission. (f) After the planning commission has reviewed and acted on the preliminary plat, one copy will be returned to the developer, one copy will go to the building official's office and one copy will be retained in the records of the planning commission. (g) After the planning commission has approved the preliminary plat, construction plans should be submitted to the building official and include the following: (1) Layout of roads, alleys and public crosswalks, with widths, road names or designations, grades and cross sections. (2) Preliminary plan of sanitary sewers with grades, service, pipe size and points of discharge, together with certified copy of all load design factors and computations. (3) Preliminary plan of storm drainage system with glade, pipe size and location of outlet, together with certified copy of all design factors and computations. (4) Preliminary plan of water supply system with pipe sizes and location of hydrants, valves and all appurtenances. (Code 1986, § 19-21; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 82-33. - Final plat. (a) At least ten days prior to the regular meeting of the planning commission the subdivider shall submit to the building official's office an original on reproducible Mylar or vellum, and three copies, of the final plat. The final plat shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat as approved and, if desired by the subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the preliminary plat which such developer proposes to record and develop at the time, provided, however, that such portion conforms to all requirements of these standards. (b) The original shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet on reproducible Mylar or vellum and shall correspond to plat book dimensions. It shall be the developer's responsibility to provide the clerk of superior court with a plat that will fit in the plat book/cabinet. When more than one sheet is required, an index sheet of the same size shall be filed showing the entire subdivision with sheets lettered in alphabetical order as a key. (c) When the plat has been approved, the original will be returned to the developer with the approval of the planning commission certified thereon for filing with the clerk of the superior court of this county; one copy will be returned to the developer for such developer's records; one copy will be forwarded to the building official's office and one copy will be returned in the records of the planning commission. (d) The planning commission shall approve or disapprove this final plat within 30 days after its submission to that body. Failure of the planning commission to act on this final plat within these 30 days shall be deemed approval of it. If the plat is disapproved, the grounds for disapproval shall be stated upon the records of the planning commission. (e) Approval of the final plat by the planning commission shall not constitute acceptance by the public of the dedication of any streets or public ways or ground. (f) The final plat shall comply with the plat act and shall give the following information: (1) Certification that the applicant is the landowner, all parties with mortgage or lien interest to be included, and that applicant dedicates street rights-of-way and any sites for public use. (2) Certification by a licensed surveyor to the accuracy of survey and plat and placement of monuments. (3) Certification by the proper city officials that the developer has complied with the following: All improvements have been installed in accord with the requirements of this chapter and other applicable city ordinances. (4) Protective covenants or deed restrictions, if any, shall be placed directly on the final plat or attached thereto in form for recording. (5) Certificate on the plat to be signed by the secretary of the planning commission when the plat has been given final approval by the planning commission. (Code 1986, § 19-22; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-99-02-08, 2-18-1999) Sec. 82-34. - As-built construction plans. (a) The as-built construction plans shall give the following information: (1) Sufficient information to reproduce the plat on the ground, including tract boundary lines and their relation to established land lot lines, right-of-way, property lines of residential lots, and other sites with accurate dimensions to the nearest one-hundredth of a foot, bearings, and angles on all lines, radii, arcs, and central angles of all curves with readings to the nearest minute. (2) Profiles of grades for streets when required by the city. (3) Blocks designated by letter and lots by number or lots numbered consecutively. (4) Location and description of monuments. (5) Final plan of sanitary sewers with grade, pipe sizes, and point of discharge. (6) Final plan of storm drains with grade, pipe sizes, and point of discharge. (7) Final plan of water supply system with pipe sites and location of hydrants and valves. (b) The as-built construction plans shall be furnished to the public works department on a 3½-inch disk or CD and shall be in a .DWG or .DXF format. (Code 1986, § 19-23; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997; Ord. No. O-99-08-34, 8-19-1999) Secs. 82-35—82-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - REQUIREMENTS AND STANDARDS
Sec. 82-57. - Basic requirements; minimum standards. (a) Land which the planning commission has found to be unsuitable for subdivision due to flooding, bad drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, or other features likely to be harmful to the safety, health, and general welfare of the future residents shall not be subdivided unless adequate methods approved by the planning commission are formulated by the developer for meeting the problems created by the subdivision of such land. (b) Land subject to flooding shall not be platted for residential occupancy or for such other uses, as will not comply with chapter 34, article II, the danger to health, life and property unless such land is not to be used as a building site. In applying this provision, land liable to flooding as determined from past history shall be considered subject to flood. Fill shall not be used to raise the land in areas subject to flood unless the fill proposed does not restrict the flow of water and unduly increase flood heights. (Code 1986, § 19-30; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-58. - Streets. (a) Conformity to the major street plan. The location and width of all streets and roads shall conform to the official major street plan; i.e., provision must be made for the location of thoroughfares as shown on the major street plan. (b) Relation to adjoining street system. The proposed street system shall extend existing streets at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required minimum width. It shall connect with streets already dedicated in adjacent subdivisions or where no such streets exist, it shall follow the projection of streets in related subdivided tracts so that other subdivisions may connect therewith. The city reserves the right to require the developer to meet minimum road design standards. (c) Restriction of access. When a tract fronts on an arterial street or highway, the planning commission may require all residential lots to be provided with frontage on a minor residential street. (d) Street right-of-way widths. The minimum width of right-of-way, measured from lot line to lot line, shall be as shown on the major street plan, or if not shown on such plan, shall be not less than as follows: (1) Arterial streets and highways: 80 to120 feet. (2) Collector streets: 60 feet. (3) Commercial and industrial streets: 80 feet. (4) Minor residential streets: a. Curb and gutter: 50 feet. b. Ditches: 60 feet. For both of the above, a 15-foot utility drainage easement shall be provided on each side of the right-of-way. (e) Exceptions. In cases where topography or other physical conditions made a street of the required minimum width impracticable, the planning commission may modify the above requirements. Through proposed business areas the street widths shall be increased ten feet on each side if needed to provide parking without interference to normal passing traffic. (f) Additional width on existing street. Subdivisions that join existing streets shall dedicate additional rights-of-way if needed to meet the above minimum street width requirements. (1) The entire right-of-way shall be provided where any part of the subdivision is on both sides of the existing street. (2) When the subdivision is located on only one side of an existing street, one-half of the required right-of-way, measured from the centerline of the existing roadway shall be provided. (g) Street grades and elevations. Grades on major streets shall not exceed seven percent and grades on other streets shall not exceed 12 percent. (h) Horizontal curves. Where a deflection angle of more than two degrees in the alignment of a street occurs, a curve of reasonably long radius shall be introduced. On streets 60 feet or more in width, the centerline radius of curvature shall be not less than 300 feet; on other streets it shall not be less than 100 feet. (i) Vertical curves. All changes in grade shall be connected by vertical curves of minimum length in feet equal to 15 times the algebraic difference in rates of grade for major streets, and one-half this minimum length for other streets. Profiles of all streets showing natural and finished grades drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet horizontally and one inch equals 20 feet vertically may be required by the planning commission upon recommendation of the city utilities director. (j) Intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible, and no intersection shall be at an angle of less than 60 degrees. Property line radii at street intersections shall not be less than 20 feet, and where the angle of street intersection is less than 75 degrees the planning commission may require a greater curb radius. To permit the construction of a curb having a desirable radius without curtailing the sidewalk at a street corner to less than normal width, the property line at such street corner shall be reduced or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit such construction. (k) Tangents. A tangent of at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on all streets. (l) Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall not be allowed. (m) Dead-end streets. (1) Minor terminal streets or courts designed to have one end permanently closed shall be no more than 600 feet long unless necessitated by topography. They shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 90 feet and a street right-of-way diameter of at least 110 feet for curb and gutter and 130 feet for ditches. (2) Where phases may be proposed a temporary turnaround shall be provided. (n) Private streets and reserve strips. There shall be no private streets platted in any subdivision. Every lot of subdivided property shall be served from a publicly dedicated street. There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to streets, except where the control of such strips is definitely placed with the city under conditions approved by the planning commission. (o) Street names. Proposed streets that are obviously, in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the names of existing streets. In no case shall the names for proposed streets duplicate names of existing streets, irrespective of the use of the suffix "street," "avenue," "boulevard," "driveway," "place" or "court." (p) Alleys. Alleys shall be provided to the rear of all lots used for business purposes; alleys shall not be provided in residential blocks except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. (q) Construction requirements. (1) Every subdivision developer shall be required to make adequate provision for handling drainage problems, to grade and improve streets and alleys, to install curbs or invert ditches and to install street name signs in accordance with specifications established by the city utilities director. (2) All street design and construction and related matters shall be in strict accordance with Georgia Department of Transportation Standard Specifications, volume 1 "Construction of Roads and Bridges" and volume 2 "Materials for Roads and Bridges" and all revisions thereto. Where circumstances dictate variations from the standard specifications, the city utilities director may vary the requirements providing the design or materials accepted are in all ways commensurate with good practice. (3) All materials, equipment, labor and other matters related to street construction shall be provided by the developer. The following is a summary of the improvements required: a. Grading. All streets, roads and alleys shall be graded to their full width by the subdivider so that pavements and sidewalks, if installed in the future can be constructed on the same level plane. The preparation of the right-of-way before grading is started and the construction of cuts and fills shall be accomplished according to the specifications of the city. b. Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system, including necessary curbs, pipes, culverts, headwalls, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges, swale ditches, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water. c. Installation of utilities. After grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied all of the underground work (water mains, gas mains, etc. and all service connections) shall be installed completely and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section. All driveways for houses to be built by the developer shall be cut and drained. d. Roadway base. After preparation of the subgrade, the roadbed shall be properly based with one of the following: 1. A six-inch sand clay base (class B); 2. A six-inch graded aggregate base; or 3. Six-inch mixed in place soil cement base. e. Roadway surfacing. The paved surface shall be a two-inch compacted asphalt plant mix. f. Minimum pavement width. Minimum pavement including paved gutters between curbs shall be as follows: 1. Minor residential streets: 30 feet. 2. Access routes: 38 to 44 feet. 3. Arterial streets or through routes: As may be required. 4. Ditch sections: 24 feet. g. Curbs. Where the subdivider elects to provide curbs or it is deemed essential and necessary by the city utilities director, a permanent six-inch Portland cement concrete curb and gutter with a longitudinal storm drain system shall be installed. Backfill shall slope toward the curb to ensure drainage of surface water into the storm drainage system. h. Rural ditch section. Where the developer does not install curb and gutter, a rural ditch section shall be provided. Said ditch shall be constructed with a minimum of 3:1 slope on both sides of the ditch. And shall have a minimum channel width of at least two feet. All rural ditch sections shall be designed and constructed to accommodate a 25-year flood. No rural ditch section shall be constructed within a right-of-way less than 60 feet wide with a 15-foot utility/storm drainage easement, on both sides. All rural ditch sections shall be seeded or sodded to provide for a permanent stand of grass. i. Outfall ditches. Outfall ditches shall be piped 130 feet from the right-of-way. (Code 1986, § 19-31; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-59. - Blocks. (a) In general, blocks shall be not less than 400 feet, nor more than 1,200 feet in length, except where topography or other conditions peculiar to the site make such dimensions impracticable. (b) Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where fronting on major streets or prevented by topography conditions or size of the property, in which case the planning commission will approve a single tier or lots of minimum depth. (Code 1986, § 19-32; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-60. - Lots. (a) Arrangement. Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines. Each lot shall front upon a public street or road that is not less than 50 feet in width. Each lot shall be at least 30 feet in width at the front property line. (b) Minimum size. The size, shape and orientation of lots shall be such, as the planning commission deems appropriate for the type of development and use contemplated. Where a public sanitary sewer is reasonably accessible, the subdivider shall connect with such sewer and provide a connection to each lot. Where a public sewer is not accessible, an alternate method of sewage disposal may be used when meeting all applicable public health regulations. (1) Residential lots served by a public sewer system shall be not less than 60 feet wide at the building setback line, nor less than 7,000 square feet in area. Where a rural ditch section is used, each lot shall maintain a 100-foot width at the setback line, not less than 13,000 square feet in size, and maintain a minimum frontage at the right-of-way line of 50 feet. Where a cul-de-sac is constructed using the rural ditch section method, the maximum number of lots on a cul-de-sac shall be five lots, with a minimum right-of-way diameter of 130 feet, and a minimum paving diameter being 90 feet. (2) For residential lots not served by a public sewer system, the planning commission shall require that data from percolation tests be submitted as a basis for approving subdivisions dependent upon septic tanks as a means of sewage disposal, and no lot shall be less than 100 feet wide at the building line, nor less than 15,000 square feet in area. (3) For residential lots not served by a public water supply or a public sewer system, no lot shall be less than 100 feet wide at the building line, nor less than one acre in size except upon approval of the county health officer and in no case shall any lot be less than one-half acre in size. (4) The minimum size of residential lots to be served by a private source of water supply shall be determined by the county health officer after investigations of soil conditions, proposed sewer system and depth of groundwater. (5) Size of properties reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial properties shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. Platting of individual lots shall be avoided in favor of an overall design of the land to be used for such purposes. (6) The size and widths of lots shall in no case be less than the minimum requirements of the zoning regulations in effect. (c) Building setback lines. The minimum depth of building setback lines from any street shall be 30 feet. If, however, suitable provision is made in connection with the plat or restrictions pertaining to the plat, building lines may be varied, provided such variation does not reduce the setback more than five feet. Where rural ditch section construction for a subdivision is used the minimum building setback line from any street right-of-way shall be 50 feet for any zoning district. (d) Corner lots. Corner lots shall be sufficiently wider and larger to permit the additional side yard requirements of the zoning regulations or building setback lines outlined above. (Code 1986, § 19-33; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-61. - Utilities. (a) Water. Water mains for both domestic use and fire protection shall be properly connected with the city water system. The lines shall conform with accepted standards of good practice for municipal water systems, and shall meet, as a minimum, the requirements of the state environmental protection division and the city. All materials, labor, equipment, and other matters related to the water distribution system shall be provided by the developer. (b) Sewer. When the subdivision is located within the service area of a public sewer system, sanitary sewers shall be installed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots with connection to the public system. Where lots cannot be economically connected with a sewer system, they must contain adequate area for the installation of approved septic tank and disposal fields and must be approved in writing by the county health officer. All materials, equipment, labor, and other matters related to the sanitary sewer system shall be provided by the developer and all sewer facilities shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the department of human resources of the state and standards of the city. (c) Installation of utilities. After grading is completed and approved and before any base is applied to the street, all of the underground work, water mains, gas mains, etc., and all service connections shall be installed completed and approved throughout the length of the road and across the flat section. Where the utility mains are off the pavement, the developer may elect to omit the installation of service connections providing that at such time as these service connections are needed, they may be jacked across the street without breaking or weakening the existing pavement. (d) Easements for utilities. Except where alleys are permitted for that purpose, the city may require easements for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary sewers, gas, and water mains or other utility lines, along rear lot lines or side lot lines, if, in the opinion of the city utilities director such action is desirable. Easements of the same or greater width may be required along the line of or across lots, where necessary for the extension of existing or planned utilities. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way along each side for the purpose of widening, depending, relocating, improving or protecting such drainage easement. (e) Street lighting. Either underground or overhead electrical service shall be provided by the developer of a subdivision, through a public utility. All subdivisions with underground electrical lines shall have placed appropriate utility poles for street lighting. The installation of streetlights shall adhere to the following requirements: streetlights shall be installed at each street intersection and streetlights that are to be installed along the proposed blocks shall be equally spaced between street intersections. However, the maximum distance between any two streetlights shall not exceed 400 feet in length. After construction has been completed for an accepted phase or for an entire subdivision, and where the streets have been dedicated to the city, the city will be responsible for the costs associated with the operation of the streetlights. Streetlight design, size, and wattage must be approved by the city as part of the preliminary platting process. For example, a block 800 feet in length, it would be necessary to install three streetlights. For a block 1,100 feet in length, four streetlights would be necessary. (Code 1986, § 19-34; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-62. - Monuments. Concrete monuments four inches in diameter or square, four feet long, with a flat top, shall be set at all street corners at all points where the street lines intersect the exterior boundaries of the subdivision, and at angle points and points of curve in each street. The top of the monument shall have an indented cross to identify properly the location and shall be set flush with the finished grade. All other lot, corners shall be marked with iron pipe not less than three-fourths inches in diameter and 24 inches long and driven so as to be flush with the finished grade. (Code 1986, § 19-35; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-63. - Large tracts. When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of future streets and logical further resubdivision. (Code 1986, § 19-36; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997) Sec. 82-64. - Group housing developments. A comprehensive group housing development, including the large scale construction of housing units together with necessary drives and ways of access, may be approved by the planning commission although the design of the project does not include standard street, lot and subdivision arrangements, if departure from the foregoing standards can be made without destroying their intent. The developer shall provide proof that adequate access is provided for emergency vehicles. (Code 1986, § 19-37; Ord. No. O-97-03-05, 3-20-1997)

div.head: Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Traffic generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - State law—Adoption by reference. Pursuant to chapter 6 of title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (Code §§ 40-6-372—40-6- 376, Code §§ 40-6-1—40-6-397) of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the City of Americus with like effect as if recited herein. (Code 1962, § 23-152(a); Code 1986, § 20-1; Ord. No. O-2013-4, § 1, 2-21-2013) Sec. 86-2. - Same—Penalty. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Code 1962, § 23-153; Code 1986, § 20-2; Ord. No. O-2013-4, § 2, 2-21-2013) Sec. 86-3. - Riding on outside of vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride on the fenders, bumpers or any other portion of any motor vehicle, except on the inside thereof. (Code 1962, § 23-27; Code 1986, § 20-30) Secs. 86-4—86-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 86-25. - Authority of police and fire department officials. (a) It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to enforce this chapter and all other traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city. (b) Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformity with traffic laws, provided, that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. (c) Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic threat or in the immediate vicinity. (Code 1962, § 23-9; Code 1986, § 20-4) Sec. 86-26. - Authority of chief of police to delegate power and duties. The chief of police shall have the power to delegate to any other officer in the police department the duties and responsibilities conferred on such chief by this chapter. (Code 1962, § 23-10; Code 1986, § 20-5) Sec. 86-27. - Authority of utilities director. (a) Signs on one-way streets. Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of this city designates any one-way street or alley, the utilities director shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. (b) Speed signs. The police chief shall cause to be erected and the utilities director shall erect throughout the city signs indicating the maximum speed limit and/or such other information as will be informative to drivers of motor vehicles as it pertains to traffic control regulations at said location or in the city. (c) Turn signs. The police chief is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right or left turn. The utilities director shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs, or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. (d) Turn markers. The utilities director is authorized to place markers, buttons, and signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersection, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by this chapter or other law or ordinance. (e) Marking crosswalks, safety zones, traffic lanes. The utilities director is hereby authorized: (1) To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as such engineer may deem necessary. (2) To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be necessary for the protection of pedestrians. (3) To make lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as may be advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city. (f) Stop signs. Whenever this chapter or any ordinance of the city designates and describes a through street it shall be the duty of the utilities director to place and maintain a stop sign or yield right-of-way sign on each intersection of such through street or intersection of that portion described and designated as such by this chapter or any ordinance of this city. (g) Hazardous locations. The police chief is hereby authorized to determined and designate intersections where particular hazards exist upon streets other than those designated by this chapter or any other ordinance of this city as through streets, and to place at such determined and designated hazardous intersections at one or more entrances to any such intersection either a stop sign or yield right-of-way sign. (Code 1962, §§ 23-12, 23-32, 23-54, 23-55, 23-64, 23-118, 23-119; Code 1986, § 20-6; Ord. No. O-92-03-15, 3-23-1992) Sec. 86-28. - Temporary traffic rules. Where the traffic upon the streets becomes congested, and upon occasions of parades, at theaters and other public places where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the police may make temporary rules regulating the traffic in such congested districts. (Code 1962, § 23-62; Code 1986, § 20-17) Sec. 86-29. - Play streets; authority to establish. The police chief shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof a play street and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. (Code 1962, § 23-71; Code 1986, § 20-40; Ord. No. O-92-03-15, 3-23-1992) Secs. 86-30—86-46. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
Sec. 86-47. - Owner liable for parking violation. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, permit, or suffer any vehicle registered in such person's name to stand or park in any street, in violation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles. Such person shall be equally liable with the operator for such violation and in addition thereto may have the vehicle impounded; provided, however, this shall not apply in those instances described in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-207. (Code 1962, § 23-144; Code 1986, § 20-80) Sec. 86-48. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. (a) In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time which, such violation occurred; provided, however, this shall not apply in those instances described in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-207. (b) The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure in section 86-49 has been followed. (Code 1962, § 23-142; Code 1986, § 20-81) Sec. 86-49. - Notice on illegally parked vehicle. Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter or other ordinance of this city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the city clerk for the driver to answer to the charge at the time and place specified in the notice. (Code 1962, § 23-143; Code 1986, § 20-82) Sec. 86-50. - When summons for arrest to be issued. In the event any person fails to comply with a notice given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the city clerk shall forthwith secure and issue a summons for such person's arrest. (Code 1962, § 23-146; Code 1986, § 20-83) Sec. 86-51. - When warrants for arrest to be issued. When it shall be made to appear to the municipal court that any person has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in such court for trial and shall fail to appear at the time and place set forth in such copy of charges, it shall be the duty of the municipal judge to forthwith issue a warrant for the arrest of such person and deliver same to the chief of police. (Code 1962, § 23-150; Code 1986, § 20-86) Secs. 86-52—86-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE OPERATION
Sec. 86-76. - Maximum speed limits—Generally. Motor vehicles shall not be driven at a higher rate of speed than 30 miles per hour in the city, nor a higher rate of speed than ten miles per hour in any park or cemetery owned and maintained by the city. (Code 1962, § 23-28; Code 1986, § 20-31) State Law reference— Speed limits generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181. Sec. 86-77. - Same—In school zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle on streets adjoining school property during school days, in excess of 15 miles per hour. (Code 1962, § 23-31; Code 1986, § 20-32) Sec. 86-78. - Speed zones established. The following speed zones are established for vehicles upon the following streets within the corporate limits of the city, as follows: (1) On-system. Signs to be erected by the state department of transportation: a. No. O-04-11-24, 11-18-2004) State Law reference— Local alteration of speed limits, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-9, 40-6-183. Sec. 86-79. - Driving in a procession generally. Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the street or roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. (Code 1962, § 23-42; Code 1986, § 20-35) Sec. 86-80. - Vehicles comprising funeral procession. (a) Vehicles of a funeral procession shall have the right-of-way over all other vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, provided each shall identify itself by burning regular headlights, and by keeping in close formation. (b) When the lead vehicle in a funeral procession has entered an intersection on a green light, all other cars in the procession may proceed through the intersection, even though such signal may change to red. (Code 1962, § 23-34; Code 1986, § 20-36) Sec. 86-81. - Driving through funeral or other procession. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in section 86-80. (Code 1962, § 23-41; Code 1986, § 20-37) Sec. 86-82. - Signal to leave parking space. Whenever vehicles are parked parallel to the curbing, before the operator of a parked vehicle or a vehicle stopped or standing at the edge of the street or roadway as prescribed in this chapter, shall execute a movement into any portion of the street or roadway normally used for moving traffic, such person shall signal the intention to do so by first giving the signal as prescribed in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-123—40-6-125, and shall start such movement only when the operator can do so with reasonable safety and without creating a hazard to other traffic moving lawfully within the street or roadway. (Code 1962, § 23-38; Code 1986, § 20-39) State Law reference— Starting parked vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-122. Sec. 86-83. - Designated play streets. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the highest degree of care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof, and at no time shall such driver's speed exceed five miles per hour. (Code 1962, § 23-40; Code 1986, § 20-41) Sec. 86-84. - Towing. No vehicle shall tow more than one other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed 16 feet in length. (Code 1962, § 23-45; Code 1986, § 20-43) Sec. 86-85. - Vehicle colliding with object. No driver of any vehicle shall operate same, in such manner so as to collide with any object legally placed upon or adjacent to any street or highway. (Code 1962, § 23-47; Code 1986, § 20-44) Sec. 86-86. - Vehicle involved in collision with parked vehicle. No driver of any vehicle shall operate same, in such a manner so as to collide with any vehicle properly parked. (Code 1962, § 23-49; Code 1986, § 20-45) Sec. 86-87. - Vehicle leaving street or roadway. No driver of any vehicle shall operate same, in such a manner as to enter or leave any street or highway except at an intersection or at an alley or private drive. (Code 1962, § 23-48; Code 1986, § 20-46) Sec. 86-88. - One-way streets. (a) East and west. Traffic upon the streets designated shall move as follows in one direction only: (1) On Forsyth Street in a westerly direction from the Vienna Road to Highway 19. (2) On Lamar Street in an easterly direction from Highway 19 to the Vienna Road. (3) On East Peppermint Way in an easterly direction from its intersection with North Lee Street to its intersection with Montgomery Street. (b) North. (1) Between Forsyth Street to the north and Forsyth Street to the south, traffic upon the following street shall be one-way north: Windsor Avenue. (2) Jones Lane, from its intersection with Patterson Street to its intersection with Peppermint Way, shall be a one-way street in a northerly direction. (3) Oak Avenue from Glessner Street to Bell Street shall be a one-way street in a northerly direction on Friday nights when Americus High School is hosting home football games. (c) South.
