(1) On Harrold Avenue, traffic shall be one-way south from Bell Street to Glessner Street from 7:00 a.m. until 8:30 a.m. during the time that Americus High School is in session. (2) On Harrold Avenue, traffic shall be one-way south from Bell Street to Glessner Street from 3:00 p.m. until 4:30 p.m. during the times that Americus High School is in session. (d) West. (1) Peppermint Way between North Jackson Street and North Lee Street shall be a one-way street in a westerly direction. (2) Sheffield Street from Quincy Drive to Jackson Street shall be a one-way street in a westerly direction. (3) Glessner Street from Harrold Avenue to Oak Avenue shall be a one-way street in a westerly direction on Friday nights when Americus High School is hosting home football games. (e) Other streets. Traffic on all other streets, unless otherwise indicated, shall be two-way traveling in both directions. (Code 1962, § 23-58; Code 1986, § 20-48; Ord. No. O-96-08-33, 8-22-1996; Ord. No. O-02-02-07, 2-21-2002; Ord. No. O-03-09-26, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. O-04-07-13, 7-22-2004; O-2012-13, 5-24-2012) State Law reference— Authority to establish one-way streets, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(4); one-way streets, O.C.G.A. § 49-6-47. Sec. 86-89. - Stop when traffic obstructed. No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. (Code 1962, § 23-120; Code 1986, § 20-49) Sec. 86-90. - Criminal trespass by a motor vehicle. (a) A person commits the offense of criminal trespass by a motor vehicle when the person, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or by the owner or an authorized agent of the owner, parks or stands an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in, or repeatedly drives a motor vehicle through or within, a parking area which is located on privately owned property and is provided by a merchant, a group of merchants, or a shopping center or other similar facility for customers if: (1) The parking area identified by at least one sign as specified in this section, and if the parking area contains more than 150 parking spaces then by at least one such sign for every 150 parking spaces, each sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing: a. Notice of the elements of the crime of criminal trespass by motor vehicle; b. Identification of the property that is reserved for customers' use only; c. Identification of the merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; and d. Warning that violators will be prosecuted. (2) The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: a. Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign or signs in the parking area, or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; b. Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or other similar facility located in the parking area; c. Meeting the requirements of a situation in which it has unexpectedly become impossible or impractical for the motor vehicle to continue to travel on the public roads; or d. Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area of an authorized representative of the owner. (b) Any person violating this section shall be subject to a monetary fine as follows: (1) Not to exceed $50.00 for the first such violation; (2) Not to exceed $100.00 for the second such violation; (3) Not to exceed $150.00 for the third or subsequent such violation. (Code 1986, § 20-50; Ord. No. O-87-06-11, 6-22-1987) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252. Sec. 86-91. - Four-way stop intersections. There shall be established and enforced a four-way stop traffic regulation at the following intersections: (1) Oglethorpe Avenue and Jefferson Street. (2) Freida Lane and Jefferson Street. (3) Douglas Circle and Ridge Street. (4) Hancock Avenue and Bell Street. (5) Lorraine Avenue and Peggy Ann Drive. (6) Edgewood Avenue and Anthony Drive. (7) Hancock Street and Furlow Street. (8) Harrold Street and Furlow Street. (9) Hill Street and Jackson Street. (10) Hill Street and Harrold Avenue. (11) Hancock Street and Hill Street. (12) Douglas Drive and Pinecrest Drive. (13) Jackson Avenue and Furlow Street. (14) North Jackson Street with J. R. Campbell Drive. (15) Alice Street and John Street. (Code 1986, § 20-51; Ord. No. O-87-06-13, 6-22-1987; Ord. No. O-89-6-17, 6-26-1989; Ord. No. O-89-7-23, 7-24-1989; Ord. No. O-91-07-23(a), 7-29-1991; Ord. No. O-91-10-36, 10-28-1991; Ord. No. O-96-03-11, 3-21-1996; Ord. No. O-98-11-41, 11-19-1998; Ord. No. O-99-04-16, 4-22-1999; Ord. No. O-99-11-45, 11-18-1999; Ord. No. O-05-07-17, 7-21-2005; Ord. No. O-07-08-23, 8-23-2007; Ord. No. O-07-08-24, 8-23-2007; Ord. No. O-11-12-31, 12-15-2011) State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1). Sec. 86-92. - Three-way stop intersections. There shall be established and enforced a three-way stop traffic regulation at the following intersections: (1) Church Street and Brown Street. (2) East Jefferson Street and Oglethorpe Avenue. (3) GSW State University Drive and Wheatley Street. (4) Taylor Street and Barlow Street. (Code 1986, § 20-52; Ord. No. O-00-07-31, 7-20-2000; Ord. No. O-04-02-04, 2-19-2004; Ord. No. O-06-04-11, 4-20-2006; Ord. No. O-07-09-31, 9-20-2007) State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1). Sec. 86-93. - One-way stop intersections. There shall be established and enforced a one-way stop at the intersection of East Jefferson Street and Oglethorpe Street in the city. The existing stop signs requiring a stop on Oglethorpe Avenue shall be removed. The city shall be authorized to install signage preceding the new stop sign advising motorists that the traffic on Oglethorpe Avenue traveling both east and west shall not be required to stop at such intersection. (Ord. No. O-10-11-40, 11-18-2010) Sec. 86-94. - Two-way stop intersections. There shall be established and enforced a two-way stop traffic regulation at the following intersections: (1) North Jackson Street and Tom Hall Circle. (Ord. No. O-12-04-08, 4-19-2012) Secs. 86-95—86-112. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1).
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 86-113. - Park within markings. (a) It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any portion of the streets within the city that have been or are, at the time of such parking, marked in sections indicating by such marking where and how vehicles shall be parked, otherwise than in conformity to such markings, leaving all the wheels of such parked vehicle clearly within the space indicated by such marks for parking of vehicles. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to commercial vehicles over 25 feet in length delivering or receiving cargo from buildings not equipped with off-street loading and unloading capabilities, providing said vehicles park in such manner for no more than 15 minutes, block only one lane of traffic, and that such vehicle is moved upon demand of any motorist whose exit from parking may be blocked by the delivery vehicle. (Code 1962, § 23-79; Code 1986, § 20-60; Ord. No. O-92-06-18, 6-22-1992) Sec. 86-114. - Parking in alley. It shall be unlawful for any driver or operator of any vehicle to park the same in any public alley within the city except where such motor vehicles are being loaded or unloaded or are awaiting loading or unloading of wares, goods or merchandise from or to the buildings or adjacent property to be served by said alley. (Code 1962, § 23-82; Code 1986, § 20-61) Sec. 86-115. - Parking of certain tractor-trailer rigs on residential streets. No tractor-trailer rig or motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight of 21,000 pounds or more shall be parked on a public street within the city, which public street has adjoining property which is zoned R-1 district or R-2 district. (Code 1962, § 23-83; Code 1986, § 20-62) Sec. 86-116. - Parking spaces for disabled in downtown. (a) There is hereby established parking spaces in the downtown area of the city for use by persons with disabilities such parking spaces to be located as follows: (1) On the west side of Jackson Avenue in the space immediately north of the cross walk; (2) On the south side of Forsyth Street in the space immediately east of Windsor Avenue. (b) The police chief, or his designee, shall be authorized to acquire and install appropriate signage at such parking spaces to indicate that they are reserved for the use of disabled citizens in accord with this section. (Code 1986, § 20-63; Ord. No. O-92-08-26, 8-24-1992) Sec. 86-117. - Report of violation; fine. (a) In each violation of this article, it shall be the duty of the police officers to report to the chief of police: (1) The state license of such vehicle. (2) The time of day or night the officer detected such violation of the provisions of this article. (3) Any other facts, knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. (b) Each police officer shall also attach to such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this article and instructing such owner or operator to report at the office of the chief of police, in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator may, within 24 hours of the time such notice was attached to such vehicle, pay to the municipal court, as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of $1.00. The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment to the municipal court, within 24 hours, shall render such owner or operator subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8. (Code 1962, § 23-98; Code 1986, § 20-64) Sec. 86-118. - Successive violations, separate offenses. When any vehicle shall remain parked for one hour beyond the time of the original notice of violation attached to the vehicle, such person shall be guilty of a violation of this article. Each such violation shall be punishable in accordance with section 1-8. It is the intention of this section that each hour that any vehicle shall be parked without complying with the provisions of this article shall be a separate offense and that time is the gravamen of the offense insofar as the successive violations shall occur. (Code 1962, § 23-97; Code 1986, § 20-65) Sec. 86-119. - Parking prohibited at certain times; illegal parking. (a) No person employed by or operating a business or profession in that part of the city in the downtown area which is hereinafter more particularly designated shall park a privately owned or company-owned motor vehicle on any public right-of-way, whether it be an alley or a street, for the purpose of using such parking space while the owner or operator performs his duties at his regular place of employment in such downtown area. The provisions of this section shall be effective between 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday of each week. (b) Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, and notwithstanding the provisions of section 86-116, a disabled person who has a handicap parking permit, who is employed by or who operates a business or profession in that part of the city in the downtown area which is hereinafter more particularly designated, shall be authorized to park in a designated disabled parking space in said downtown area at any time. The location of such parking space shall be designated by the city police with appropriate signage and markings. (c) The parking area of the downtown area of the city wherein such parking by employees or operators of businesses or professions during said time periods shall be prohibited shall be as follows: (1) Along the northerly and southerly sides of West Lamar Street, from its intersection with South Hampton Street and North Hampton Street to its intersection with South Lee Street and North Lee Street. (2) Along the southerly side of East Lamar Street, from its intersection with South Lee Street to its intersection with South Price Street. (3) Along the northerly and southerly sides of West Forsyth Street, from its intersection with North Hampton Street to its intersection with North Lee Street. (4) Along the easterly and westerly sides of South Jackson Street, from its intersection with Church Street to its intersection with West Lamar Street. (5) Along the easterly and westerly sides of North Jackson Street, from its intersection with West Lamar Street to its intersection with West Jefferson Street. (6) Along the westerly side of Cotton Avenue, from its intersection with West Lamar Street to its intersection with West Forsyth Street. (7) Along the easterly and westerly sides of Cotton Avenue, from its intersection with West Forsyth Street to its intersection with West Jefferson Street. (8) Along the westerly side of Windsor Avenue, from its intersection with West Lamar Street to its intersection with West Forsyth Street. (9) Along the westerly side of North Lee Street, from its intersection with West Forsyth Street to its intersection with West Jefferson Street. (d) Upon conviction, a plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendere to a violation of the provisions of this section, the violator shall pay a fine of not less than $35.00 in addition to any other punishment or penalty which may be lawfully imposed by the municipal court of the city. (e) The provisions of this section shall apply to the parking of motor vehicles by persons residing in upper floor residential areas as authorized by chapter 94. (Code 1986, § 20-66; Ord. No. O-87-06-12, §§ A—C, 6-22-1987; Ord. No. O-89-10-29, 10-23-1989; Ord. No. O-89-12-43, 12-18-1989; Ord. No. O-97-08-31A, 8-21-1997) Sec. 86-120. - No parking zones. (a) There are hereby established the following no parking zones: (1) Harrold Avenue, east side, from its intersection with Dodson Street to its intersection with Virginia Avenue. (2) Harrold Avenue, west side, from its intersection with the driveway leading to the Americus High School Gymnasium south to its intersection with the northerly property line of the first residential house now located on the west side of Harrold Avenue. (3) Virginia Avenue, north and south sides, from its intersection with Harrold Avenue to its intersection with Turner Street. (4) Bell Street, from its intersection with Harrold Avenue to its intersection with South Jackson Street, on both sides of said Bell Street. (5) Reddick Drive on the south side for the entire length of said street. (6) Wild Street, south side, between Cotton Avenue and Jackson Street, with Wild Street, north side, to be designated for passenger pickup and dropoff. (7) Elmo Street, along the south side thereof, from its intersection with Mayo Street to its intersection with Reese Street. (8) Hampton Street, east and west sides, from its intersection with Church Street to its intersection with Lamar Street. (9) Habitat Street, east side, from its intersection with Church Street to its intersection with Spring Street. (10) North Jackson Street, east side, from its intersection with Rucker Street to its intersection with Hope Street. (11) West Church Street along the north curb of the street beginning at the northwest corner of West Church Street and South Lee Street and continuing west to the northeast corner of Church Street and Habitat Street. (12) East Church Street along the north curb of the street beginning at the northwest corner of East Church Street at its intersection with Reese Street and continuing to the northeast corner of Church Street and Brown Street. (13) Taylor Street beginning at the northwest corner of Taylor Street at its intersection with Jones Street and continuing west to a point 50 feet west of Elm Avenue. (14) Taylor Street on the northwest curb thereof beginning 30 feet east of Barlow Street and continuing west to its intersection with Brown Street, including the traffic island located at "Taylor's Place." (15) Taylor Street at the northeast corner of Taylor Street and South Lee Street extending 20 feet east on Taylor Street. (16) East Church Street, north side from its intersection with Prince Street to its intersection with the Harvey's Supermarket driveway that enters and exits from East Church Street. (17) Spring Street on the North side from the Northwest intersection of the curb on the north side of Spring Street with the west curb of the driveway entering into the west side of the Summer County Courthouse for a distance of 120 feet. (18) South Jackson Street, East side, on both sides of the southernmost access drive to the Public Safety Building for a distance of 40 feet south and 40 feet north, and on South Jackson Street, east side, on the south side of the northernmost access drive to the Public Safety Building for a distance of 40 feet south. (19) Felder Street, both sides, from its intersection with Bosworth Drive to its intersection with Hill Street. (20) Dodson Street, on both the North and South sides thereof, from its intersection with Harrold Avenue to its intersection with Hancock Drive during school hours from 7:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Monday through Friday while Americus-Sumter High School is in session. (21) The north and west sides of Tom Hall Circle from its intersection with North Jackson Street to its intersection with the north right-of-way of Harvey Lane and on the west and south sides of Tom Hall Circle from its intersection with the south right-of-way of Harvey Lane to its intersection with North Jackson Street. (22) Simmons Street, both sides, from its intersection with Felder Street to its intersection with Anthony Street. (23) Ashby Street from its intersection with North Lee Street to the intersection with the private driveway located at 112 Ashby Street. (24) South Lee Street from its intersection with Elm Avenue for a distance of 60 feet north along the east side of South Lee Street. (25) The eastern side of Elm Avenue where Rees Park abuts Elm Avenue at such locations as may be marked by yellow painted curbing at such locations as are authorized by the chief of police of the city. (26) The south side of Anthony Drive from Perimeter Road to GSW Drive at such locations as may be marked by yellow painted curbing at such locations as are authorized by the chief of police of the city. (b) The utilities director shall provide for notice of such no parking zones and the times of operation thereof by appropriate yellow markings and signs. (c) In the event of the establishment of no parking zones by the city council, the utilities director shall designate the same by appropriate yellow markings and signs, and any person violating such no parking zone shall be punishable and any person violating such no parking zone shall be guilty of an offense. (Code 1986, § 20-67; Ord. No. O-88-03-11, 3-28-1988; Ord. No. O-93-04-15, 4-26-1993; Ord. No. O-94-05-14, 5-19-1994; Ord. No. O-94-07-24, 7-21-1994; Ord. No. O-94-12-40, 12-22-1994; Ord. No. O-95-06-23, 6-22-1995; Ord. No. O-96-03-12, 3-21-1996; Ord. No. O-96-06-20, 6-20-1996; Ord. No. O-01-10-37, 10-18-2001; Ord. No. O-01-04-15, 4-19-2001; Ord. No. O-03-05-10, 5-22-2003; Ord. No. O-03-08-18, 8-21-2003; Ord. No. O-03-11-36, 11-20-2003; Ord. No. O-04-10-21, 10-21-2004; Ord. No. O-05-07-15, 7-21-2005; Ord. No. O-05-08-20, 8-19-2005; Ord. No. O-05-09-29, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. O-08-08-19, 8-21-2008; Ord. No. O-08-10-34, 10-23-2008; Ord. No. O-09-07-23, 7-23-2009) Sec. 86-121. - Parking zones on Windsor Avenue. There is hereby established along Windsor Avenue, from its intersection with Forsyth Street to its intersection with Lamar Street, a restricted parking zone such that there shall be no parking by any person along Windsor Avenue between 10:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. Monday through Friday of each week. Parking along said Windsor Avenue at times other than set out above shall not be restricted except as otherwise provided in this Code. (Code 1986, § 20-68; Ord. No. O-90-06-16, 6-28-1990) Sec. 86-122. - Fifteen-minute parking zones. There is hereby established a 15-minute parking zone for the two parking spaces on the north side of West Lamar Street, immediately in front of the Windsor Hotel property, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park any type of vehicle for a period longer than 15 minutes in either or both of said parking spaces. (Code 1986, § 20-69; Ord. No. O-91-10-35, 10-28-1991) Secs. 86-123—86-142. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LOADING ZONES
Sec. 86-143. - Authority of police chief. The police chief shall be authorized to designate, establish and maintain, by appropriate markings, loading zones for the purpose of loading and unloading commercial vehicles in the downtown area of the city; provided that there shall be no more than one loading zone per city block, that such loading zones shall be clearly delineated by appropriate markings and signs, and that such loading zones shall be located in such positions as will not interfere with the normal traffic flow. (Code 1986, § 20-91; Ord. No. O-88-03-13, 3-28-1988; Ord. No. O-92-03-15, 3-23-1992) Sec. 86-144. - Parking prohibited; exceptions. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a loading zone as designated by authority of the police chief, unless such vehicle is a commercial vehicle from which property or merchandise is being loaded or unloaded, and in no event shall such commercial vehicle park in said loading zone for a period of time longer than 30 minutes. For purposes of this article, the term "commercial vehicle" shall be defined as an automobile, truck, trailer, tractor, wagon or any other motor vehicle designed or used as a vehicle of conveyance in the furtherance of or as a part of any commercial activity or enterprise, whether or not such vehicle is used solely in such commercial activity or enterprise or is used only intermittently in such commercial activity or enterprise. (Code 1986, § 20-92; Ord. No. O-88-03-14, 3-28-1988; Ord. No. O-92-03-15, 3-23-1992) Secs. 86-145—86-171. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED VEHICLES
Sec. 86-172. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle, which has been parked or left standing on the public streets of the city for more than five days in a nonoperating state of repair. Abandonment means the act of the owner leaving the vehicle on the streets or sidewalks of the city for a period in excess of five days, when the owner of the vehicle does not own the property abutting the street or sidewalk upon which the vehicle is parked and does not reside, room, have a place of business, lease, rent, or otherwise exercise control and dominion over the abutting real estate. Hazard to normal flow of traffic means a vehicle parked on the public streets of the city in a nonoperational condition and is hereby defined to be a hazard to the normal flow of traffic on the streets of the city. Nonoperational vehicle means a vehicle that will not start, run and move under its own power in its existing condition. Vehicle means any automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, wagon, or other artificial contrivance used, or capable of being used, as a means of transportation on land. (Code 1962, § 23-106; Code 1986, § 20-70) State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1. Sec. 86-173. - Unlawful to abandon vehicle. It shall be unlawful to abandon any vehicle upon the streets or sidewalks of the city. (Code 1962, §§ 23-107, 23-108; Code 1986, § 20-71) Sec. 86-174. - Maximum parking time. No vehicle shall be parked upon the streets for a period of more than 24 hours unless such vehicle is owned by or in the custody, care and control of the property owner abutting said street or sidewalk where such vehicle is parked. (Code 1962, § 23-109; Code 1986, § 20-72) Sec. 86-175. - Abandoned vehicle to be moved within 24 hours following receipt of notice. All such abandoned or overparked vehicles shall be moved by the owner or person in charge thereof within 24 hours following receipt of notice from the police chief or designee or any member of the police force of the city requiring such vehicle to be removed. (Code 1962, § 23-109.1; Code 1986, § 20-73) Sec. 86-176. - Removal of abandoned vehicle or vehicle constituting a hazard authorized. Any vehicle which shall be abandoned, or parked so as to constitute a traffic hazard, on the streets of the city may be taken into the custody of the police department and towed or removed to a garage or parking lot either by the police chief or designee. (Code 1962, §§ 23-110, 23-112; Code 1986, § 20-74) State Law reference— When police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-206, 40-11-3. Sec. 86-177. - Impounding parked vehicles, removal of, authorized. Any vehicle parked on the streets of the city in such a manner that it is a traffic hazard may be moved by the police department or towed under the custody and control and the charge for towing made and collected as herein provided. (Code 1962, § 23-112; Code 1986, § 20-75) Secs. 86-178—86-207. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - WEIGHT AND LOAD LIMITS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Weight limits, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-20 et seq.
Sec. 86-208. - Motor trucks or trailers prohibited from traversing certain areas during designated hours. It shall be unlawful for any motor truck or motor-drawn trailer to traverse any street or part of the area of the city during periods hereafter specifically designated by the city council by resolution or ordinance. Whenever said streets or areas are designated, nothing in this section shall prevent any truck, when not accompanied by a trailer, from traversing any of the streets or areas solely for the purpose of making delivery or for the purpose of picking up or receiving goods, wares or merchandise for transportation; but this shall not include permission for trailers to enter, park or stand in such areas for any purpose whatsoever. (Code 1962, § 23-6; Code 1986, § 20-15) Sec. 86-209. - Limitations as to weight of vehicles on city streets. (a) The governing body of the city shall have the right to proclaim by ordinance or resolution the maximum weight of any vehicle, including tractors and trailers, which may be driven upon certain designated streets of the city. (b) There are hereby established certain truck routes in the city. Those trucks shall be located upon the following streets: Brady Road Carter Street Cotton Avenue East Furlow Street to Elm Avenue East Lester Street from McGarrah to Davis Elm Avenue Felder Street Forrest Street Glessner Street Industrial Boulevard Industrial Drive Jefferson Street (downtown) Lee Street to Carter Street Mathews Drive Mayo Street McGarrah Street North Dudley Street North Hampton (from Lamar north) North Jackson to Prince Street (but not between Lamar and Forsyth) Oak Avenue (from West Glessner north) Patterson Street from McGarrah to Davis Perimeter Road-Georgia Southwestern State University Prince Street Railroad Street Reese Street Simmons Street Southerfield Road Spring Street Swett Avenue Tripp Street Warren Avenue West Church Street (c) No truck, including tractor-trailer trucks, or other motor vehicles, which weigh over 36,000 pounds gross weight, shall travel any public street within the city except for those streets listed above, unless it is necessary for such truck, tractor-trailer, or other motor vehicle to pick up or deliver a cargo on streets other than those listed above. (d) The city shall post appropriate signs along the streets designated as truck routes. Any street not posted as a truck route shall not be considered a truck route for purposes of this section. (Code 1962, § 23-8; Code 1986, § 20-16; Ord. No. O-91-06-18, 6-20-1991; Ord. No. O-91-08-25, 8-26-1991; Ord. No. O-91-10-34, 10-28-1991; Ord. No. O-92-03-12, 3-23-1992; Ord. No. O-06-07-22, 7-20-2006; Ord. No. O-07-07-21, § 20-16, 7-19-2007; Ord. No. O-10-05-16, 5-20-2010; Ord. No. O-10-08-25, 8-19-2010) Sec. 86-210. - Use of engine brakes and compression brakes prohibited. (a) For purposes of this section the terms "engine brake" or "compression brake" shall mean a device used primarily on trucks for the conversion of the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheeled brakes, said devices being commonly referred to as "air brakes", "Jacob's brakes" or "jake brakes". (b) It shall be unlawful for any person in actual physical control of a motor vehicle, including, but not limited to; a truck or a tractor-trailer truck, to use an engine brake or compression brake while traveling along the streets of the city unless such engine brake or compression brake is used solely to effect an emergency stop of the motor vehicle. (c) Upon conviction, the penalty for a violation of this section shall be as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Ord. No. O-07-07-20, § 20-16.1, 7-19-2007)

div.head: Chapter 90 - UTILITIES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 90-1. - Discontinuance of city services when charges remain unpaid. Any person failing for any reason or refusing to pay timely the monthly water, gas, sewerage or refuse collection charges provided in this Code set by the city after having been duly billed for same by the city shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter, and all water service, gas service, sewerage service and refuse collection service provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due shall be terminated by the city; provided, however, should not more than one of the monthly water charges, gas charges, sewerage charges and refuse collection charges remain unpaid, any person may make application to the finance director to have the city services restored that are not in arrears provided such person submits a monthly repayment plan to the finance director to pay for the particular services that are in arrears within a three-month period of time from the date of such application; and provided that the person abides by each proposed monthly payment within said three-month time period. (Code 1962, § 10-22; Code 1986, § 13-1; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 90-2. - Refunds of utility payments. (a) In the event that a city utility customer claims that he has overpaid a utility bill or that he has been charged more than was legally due for the use of city utilities, then such customer may file a claim for a refund with the finance director at any time within three years after the date of the payment of the amount for which a refund is claimed. The claim for refund shall be in writing, and shall be in a form and contain the information required by the finance director. Such claim shall include a summary statement of the grounds upon which the customer relies in claiming the refund. The customer may be required to provide such additional information as may be requested by the finance director in order for the clerk to consider the claim. (b) Upon receipt of the claim, and any additional information required from the customer by the finance director, the finance director shall consider the claim and determine whether or not the customer is entitled to a refund, but in no event shall any refund be provided for any payments made more than three years prior to the date of filing the claim for refund. The finance director shall only grant the claim for refund if the finance director determines that the amount for which the refund is sought was billed to the customer erroneously or illegally. (c) The finance director shall notify the customer of the finance director's decision regarding the refund claim within 30 days from the date that the finance director receives all information necessary in order for the finance director to make a determination regarding the refund claim. (d) Any customer whose claim for refund is denied by the finance director may appeal such denial to the city council within 30 days of the date of the finance director's decision. The city council shall authorize such refund only in the event that it finds that the funds for which the refund is sought were billed to the customer either erroneously or illegally. The decision of the city council regarding the claim for refund shall be final. (Code 1986, § 13-2; Ord. No. O-97-11-36, 11-20-1997; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Secs. 90-3—90-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BACKFLOW CONTROL[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, adopted Nov. 17, 2011, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out, with the exception of § 90-32, which remains unchanged. Former art. II, §§ 90-23—90-32, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from: Code 1986, §§ 13-40—13-48; Ord. No. O-85-07-16, §§ 1—3, adopted June 27, 1985; and Ord. No. O-95-11-35, adopted Nov. 30, 1995.
Sec. 90-23. - Definitions. The definitions found in the city plumbing code for backflow, cross-connections, and backflow prevention devices shall be those used in this article. In addition, the following definitions shall apply: Air gap means a physical separation sufficient to prevent backflow between the free-flowing discharge end of the potable water system and any other system. Physically defined as a distance equal to twice the diameter of the supply side pipe diameter but never less than one inch. Approved means accepted by the director of public works as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this regulation, or as suitable for the proposed use. Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the premises other than the city's approved public water supply. These auxiliary waters may include water from another purveyor's public potable water supply or any natural sources such as a well, spring, river, stream, harbor, etc., or used waters or industrial fluids. These waters may be contaminated or polluted or they may be objectionable and constitute an unacceptable water source over which the city does not have sanitary control. Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances under positive or reduced pressure in the distribution pipes of a potable water supply from any source other than its intended source. Backflow preventer means a device or means designed to prevent backflow or backsiphonage. Most commonly categorized as air gap, reduced pressure principal assembly, double-check valve assembly, pressure vacuum breaker, atmospheric vacuum breaker, hose bibb vacuum breaker, residential dual check and barometric loop. Containment means a method of backflow prevention which requires a backflow preventer at the water service entrance. Contaminant means a substance that will impair the quality of the water to a degree that it creates a serious health hazard to the public, leading to poisoning or the spread of disease. Contamination means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease. Cross-connection means a connection or potential connection between any part of a potable water system and any other environment containing other substances in a manner that, under any circumstances, would allow such substances to enter the potable water system. Other substances may be gases, liquids or solids, such as chemicals, waste products, steam, water from other sources (potable or nonpotable), or any other matter that may change the color and/or add odor to the water. Cross-connection control by containment means the installation of an approved backflow prevention device at the water service connection to any customer's premises where it is physically and economically infeasible to find and permanently eliminate or control all actual or potential cross-connections within the customer's water system; or, it shall mean the installation of an approved backflow prevention device on the service line leading to and supplying a portion of a customer's water system where there are actual or potential cross-connections which cannot be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of the cross-connection. Cross-connection, controlled means a connection between a potable water system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow prevention device properly installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford the protection commensurate with the degree of hazard. Customer means a person or entity receiving water or sewer services from the City of Americus Public Works Department. Department means the City of Americus Public Works Department. Double-check backflow preventer means an assembly of two independently operating spring-loaded check valves with tightly-closing shut off valves on each side of the check valves and properly located test cocks allowing for the testing of each check valve on each line, specifically a double-check valve assembly (DCVA) or a double-check detector assembly (DCDA). Hazard assessment means a hazard determination conducted pursuant to Section 608 of the Georgia State Minimum Standard Plumbing Code. Hazard, degree of, means the term is derived from an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system. Hazard, health, means any condition, device, or practice in the water supply system and its operation which could create, or in the judgment of the building official, may create a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. Hazard, plumbing, means a plumbing-type cross-connection in a consumer's potable water system that has not been properly protected by an approved air gap or approved backflow prevention device. Hazard, pollutional, means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or to the potability of the public or the consumer's potable water system but which would constitute a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but would not be dangerous to health. Hazard, system, means an actual or potential threat of severe damage to the physical properties of the public potable water system or the consumer's potable water system or of a pollution or contamination which would have a protracted effect on the quality of the potable water in the system. Industrial fluids system means any system containing a fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would constitute a health, system, pollutional or plumbing hazard if introduced into an approved water supply. This may include, but is not limited to: Polluted or contaminated waters; all types of process waters and used waters originating from the public potable water system which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; chemicals in fluid form; plating acids and alkalies; circulating cooling water connected to an open cooling tower and/or cooling towers that are chemically or biologically treated or stabilized with toxic substances; contaminated natural waters such as from wells, springs, streams, rivers, bays, harbors, seas, irrigation canals or systems, etc.; oils, gases, glycerine, paraffins, caustic and acid solutions and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in industrial or other purposes or for firefighting purposes. Owner means any person who has legal title to, or license to operate or inhabit, a property upon which a cross-connection inspection is to be made or upon which a cross-connection is deemed likely by the City of Americus Public Works. Permit means a document issued by the department which allows the installation of a backflow preventer. Person means any individual, partnership, company, public or private corporation, political subdivision or agency of the state department, agency or instrumentality or the United States or any other legal entity. Pollutant means a foreign substance that, if permitted to get into the public water system, will degrade its quality so as to constitute a moderate hazard or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree that does not create an actual hazard to the public health, but which does adversely and unreasonably affect such water for domestic use. Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer means an assembly consisting of two independently operating approved check valves with an automatically operating differential relief valve located between the two check valves, tightly-closing shut-off valves on each side of the check valves and properly located test cocks allowing for the testing of the check valves and the relief valve on each line, specifically a reduced pressure principal assembly (RP) or a reduced pressure principal detector assembly (RPDA). Residential dual check means an assembly of two spring loaded, independently operating check valves without tightly closing shut-off valves or test cocks. Generally employed immediately downstream of the water meter to act as a containment device. Water service connection means the terminal end of a service connection from the public potable water system, i.e., where the water purveyor loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customer's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the term "service connection" shall mean the downstream end of the meter. There shall be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow prevention device located at the point of delivery to the customer's water system. Service connection shall also include water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the public potable water system. Water used means any water supplied by the city from the public potable water system to a consumer's water system after it has passed through the point of delivery and is no longer under the sanitary control of the city water department. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-24. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to: (1) Protect the public potable water supply of the city from the possibility of contamination or pollution by containing within the customer's internal distribution systems or the customer's private water systems such contaminates or pollutants which could backflow into the public water system through an undiscovered or uncontrolled cross-connection on said premises; (2) Promote the elimination or control of existing cross-connections, actual or potential, between the customer's in-plant potable water systems and nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and industrial piping systems; and (3) Provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross-connection control which will systematically attempt to prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-25. - Protection of system; fees and charges; installation of assemblies. (a) In accordance with the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974, and the Georgia Rules for Safe Drinking Water Section 391-3-5-.13, the Water Purveyor, City of Americus Public Works, has the primary responsibility for preventing water from unapproved sources, or any other substances, from entering the public potable water system. (b) The City of Americus is authorized to charge a nominal fee to water customers for the purpose of funding the cross-connection control program. The City of Americus is also authorized to charge an additional fee to businesses for funding the cross-connection control program and the associated inspections. Should a water customer fail to comply with the requirements set out herein, the City of Americus has the authority to install, test, and repair backflow prevention assemblies and pass on costs to the customer associated with the work, including, but not limited to, labor, parts and administration. The City of Americus Public Works Department has the authority to hire or designate an on-call or consulting engineer to offer support with tasks associated with upkeep of the cross-connection control program. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-25.1. - Obligations and responsibilities. The following obligations shall be undertaken and performed by the named persons or entities: (1) Purveyor. The Director of Public Works for the City of Americus, Georgia, or a designee on his or her behalf, as authorized through this article, is primarily responsible for preventing contamination and pollution of the public water supply by instituting the cross-connection control program, as approved by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division. Such responsibility begins at the point of origin for the public potable water supply, includes all of the distribution system, and terminates at the service connection for the customer's water system. In addition, the director shall exercise reasonable vigilance to ensure that the customer adheres to this policy and these procedures as stated and outlined herein. (2) Customer. The business and residential customers will be responsible for all work and costs related to installing, certifying and maintaining the required backflow assemblies. The required customer-supplied backflow prevention assembly at the service connection shall provide maximum protection for locations deemed "high hazard" (reduced pressure principal backflow preventer — RP, RPDA or air gap), or minimum protection for locations deemed "low hazard" (double-check backflow preventer — DCVA, DCDA) as directed by the department or an authorized representative thereof. (3) Building code official. The building inspection department is primarily responsible for enforcing the State of Georgia Plumbing Code to prevent contamination and pollution within the customer's water system in accordance with applicable plumbing and building codes requiring that all outlets terminate through an approved air gap or be controlled by an approved mechanical backflow prevention device. Such responsibility begins at the service connection to the premises and extends to the extremities of the customer's potable water supply. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011; Ord. No. O-12-04-09, 4-19-2012) Sec. 90-26. - Water system components. The water system shall be considered as made up of two parts: The utility system and the customer system. (1) Utility system. The utility system shall consist of the source facilities and the distribution system and shall include all those facilities of the water system under the complete control of the city, up to the point where the customer's system begins. a. Source facilities. The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water to the distribution system. b. Distribution system. The distribution system shall include the network of conduits used for the delivery of water from the source to the customer's system. (2) Customer's system. The customer's system shall include those parts of the facilities beyond the termination of the utility distribution system which are utilized in conveying utility-delivered domestic water to points of use. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-27. - Connection policy. (a) No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained by the city unless the water supply is protected as required by state law and regulations and this article. The City of Americus shall either discontinue service of water to any premises or take appropriate steps by installing, testing or maintaining a backflow prevention assembly if one is required by this article and state law and has not been tested and maintained, or if it is found that a required backflow prevention assembly has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises. In the event of disconnection, service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. Compliance with applicable requirements for backflow prevention shall be verified by the department before water service is reinstated. (b) The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to the department or authorized representatives of the department to determine whether cross-connections or other structural or sanitary hazards, including violations of these regulations, exist. When such a condition becomes known, the department shall either immediately discontinue service to the premises by providing for a physical break in the service line until the customer has corrected the conditions in conformance with state statutes and city ordinances relating to plumbing and water supplies, and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto, or take appropriate steps by installing, testing or maintaining the assembly to correct the conditions in conformance with state statutes and city ordinances relating to plumbing and water supplies, and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto. All costs incurred shall be passed directly to the customer. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-28. - Installation of assembly in service line. An approved backflow prevention assembly shall also be installed on each service line to a customer's water system at or near the property line or immediately inside the building being served; but, in all cases, before the first branch line leading off the service line wherever the following conditions exist: (1) Auxiliary water supply. In the case of premises having an auxiliary water supply which is not or may not be of safe bacteriological or chemical quality and which is not acceptable as an additional source by the building official, the public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by eliminating the connection between the two systems. (2) Industrial fluid or hazardous substances. In the case of premises on which any industrial fluid or any other objectionable substance is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or potential hazard to the public water system, the public system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow prevention assembly in the service line appropriate to the degree of hazard. This shall include the handling of process waters and waters originating from the utility system which have been subject to deterioration in quality. (3) Connection issues. In the case of premises having: a. Internal cross-connections that cannot be permanently corrected and controlled; b. Intricate plumbing and piping arrangements; or c. Where entry to all portions of the premises is not readily accessible for inspection purposes, making it impracticable or impossible to ascertain whether or not dangerous cross-connections exist. The public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow prevention assembly in the service line. (4) Water heating or pressure producing device. In the case of premises having any water heating device or any other pressure-producing device connected to the customer's system, a thermal protection device, either a thermal expansion tank or a calibrated pressure-relief valve set at 80 psi, will be required in order to protect against damage caused by thermal expansion of a system closed with backflow preventer. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-29. - Type of assembly. The type of protective assembly required under subsections 90-28(1)—(3) shall depend upon the degree of hazard which exists as follows: (1) Auxiliary water supply. In the case of any premises where there is an auxiliary water supply as stated in subsection 90-28(1) and it is not subject to any of the following rules, the public water system shall be protected by an approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly. (2) Objectionable substances. In the case of any premises where there is water or substance that would be objectionable, but not hazardous to health, if introducted into the public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved double-check valve assembly. (3) Hazardous substances. In the case of any premises where there is any material dangerous to health which is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or potential hazard to the public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved air gap separation or any approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly. Examples of premises where these conditions will exist include sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations, chemical manufacturing plants, hospitals, mortuaries and plating plants. (4) Connection issues. In the case of any premises where there are uncontrolled cross-connections, either actual or potential, the public water system shall be protected by an approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly at the service connection. (5) Other prohibitions or restrictions. In the case of any premises where, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete in-plant cross-connection survey, the public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by either an approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly on each service to the premises. (6) Unknown hazards. In the case of any premises where there is no known pollutional or contaminant hazard, as described or covered in subsections (1) through (5) of this section, the public water system shall be protected by an approved residential dual-check valve at the service connection. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-30. - Approved backflow prevention assembly. Any backflow prevention assembly device assembly required herein shall be a model and size approved by the building official. The term "approved backflow prevention assembly" shall mean an assembly that has been manufactured in full conformance with the standards established in the city and state plumbing codes. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-31. - Tests; repair of assemblies. (a) Periodic testing. Annual testing shall be performed by a tester certified by one of the approved programs. This testing will be coordinated by the owner and performed at the owner's expense. Assemblies shall also be tested immediately following installation, repair or relocation of an assembly. Test reports must be submitted within seven days from the date that the test is performed. Any backflow preventer that fails during a periodic test will be repaired or replaced. When repairs are necessary, upon completion of the repair, the assembly will be retested at the customer's expense to insure correct operation. In situations where the public water system is not deemed by the department to be immediately threatened by a health or pollutional hazard, a compliance date of not more than 30 days after the test date will be established. If a customer does not comply with installation, testing or repair within 60 days of notifications, the department may perform installation, testing or repair and bill the customer for the cost of the work, parts, and any associated administrative costs. (b) Backflow assembly testers. In accordance with the State of Georgia Environmental Protection Division requirements, backflow testers for the City of Americus must be certified by one of the State of Georgia approved agencies in order to test backflow assemblies. Certification is valid for up to three years or until such time as his or her certification expires, whichever comes first. In order to certify backflow prevention assemblies for the City of Americus, testers must complete an application, including, but not limited to, a copy of his or her current tester certificate from one of the approved agencies, a copy of the current calibration certificate of the approved backflow gauge to be used by the tester, and the business license under which he or she will be practicing. A list of testers will be published and made available to customers who require a backflow assembly test. (c) Backflow assembly repairs. All backflow assembly repairs shall be performed by a person or persons working under a current plumber's license. (d) Backflow assembly installation. In accordance with State of Georgia's Cross-Connection Control requirements, all installations of backflow assemblies shall be performed by a person or persons working under a current plumber's license. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-31.1. - Installation of residential dual-checks. Residential dual-checks shall be installed by the department or a designee thereof. (Ord. No. O-11-11-25, exh. A, 11-17-2011) Sec. 90-32. - Nonconforming devices. All presently installed backflow prevention devices which do not meet the requirements of this section, but were approved devices for the purposes described herein at the time of installation and which have been properly maintained, shall, except for the inspection and maintenance requirements under section 90-31, be excluded from the requirements of these rules so long as the building official is assured that they will satisfactorily protect the utility system. Whenever the existing device is moved from the present location or requires more than minimum maintenance or when the building official finds that the maintenance constitutes a hazard to health, the unit shall be replaced by an approved backflow prevention device meeting the requirements of this section. (Code 1986, § 13-49; Ord. No. O-85-07-16, § 3.2.7, 6-27-1985; Ord. No. O-95-11-35, 11-30-1995) Secs. 90-33—90-52. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWER LINE EXTENSIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 90-53—90-77. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COMMERCIAL AREAS
Sec. 90-78. - Authority to extend; service charges. (a) The city council shall be authorized to extend or cause to be extended water main lines and sewer main lines into commercial areas, both inside and outside the city limits where the city council deems it appropriate and in the best interest of the city to do so. (b) In considering the extension of such water mains and sewer mains, the city council shall take into consideration past commercial business growth patterns and anticipated commercial business growth patterns, both inside and outside the city limits. The city council shall also weigh the net cost to the city of such extensions against the potential increased revenues to the city realized or anticipated to result from such extensions due to increased economic development activity. (c) In the event that the city council determines that it is appropriate to extend water mains and sewer mains into commercial areas, either inside or outside the city limits, the city shall be authorized to charge to new water and sewer customers, in addition to tap charges, service deposits, meter costs and monthly water and sewer rates, an amount determined by the city which will reimburse the city for all reasonable costs of extending such water mains and sewer mains based upon the linear front footage of the property to be served by such water main and sewer main extensions. Such costs need not be paid by a property owner or owners until such time as the property owner or owners desire to purchase city water and city sewer services, and such charges may be paid as part of the initial tap charges otherwise authorized in this Code. In addition to the foregoing, the city shall be authorized to charge interest on such amounts from the date that such water and sewer service becomes available to the date that such charges are paid in an amount to be determined by the city. (d) The charges authorized hereunder shall be in addition to all other charges authorized to persons or businesses who utilize city water and city sewer services, whether inside or outside the city limits. (e) The commercial business shall be required to pay the full cost of installing water and sewer lines from the main line to a commercial business building or buildings located on the premises, and the city shall have no responsibility or liability therefor. (f) The provisions of this section shall not apply to residential subdivisions, or to the extension of water mains and sewer mains by the city to serve a single residence or a single commercial business. Under such circumstances, the city shall be authorized to undertake such extensions and shall be authorized to charge the full cost of such extensions to such residential or commercial customer. (Code 1986, § 13-150; Ord. No. O-96-04-15, 4-18-1996) Secs. 90-79—90-99. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RESIDENTIAL AREAS
Sec. 90-100. - Authority to extend. The city council shall be authorized to extend or cause to be extended water main lines and sewer main lines into residential areas, both inside and outside the city limits, where the city council deems it appropriate and in the best interest of the city to do so. For purposes of this division, the term "residential areas" shall include all areas inside and outside the city limits which are zoned for any type of residential development. (Code 1986, § 13-161; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 1, 1-21-1999) Sec. 90-101. - Investigation; survey; estimated costs. (a) In the event that the utilities director shall determine that there is an area within the city or outside the city limits which should have access to city water and city sewerage, the utilities director shall conduct a preliminary investigation of the area to determine the estimated cost, feasibility, and if appropriate, the time frame within which water mains and sewer mains could be installed to serve such area. The utilities director shall then make a written report of his findings to the city manager of the city, who shall review such findings and submit them to the city council for review. (b) Upon review of the findings, the city council shall be authorized to undertake one of the following three options: (1) The council can determine that the proposed installation of water and sewer lines in such area is not feasible, not cost effective, or is a project that the city should not undertake at the present time. (2) In the event that the area studied is an area where residential property has already been developed, then the city council shall be authorized to direct the city manager of the city to undertake a survey of the property owners in the area to determine whether or not they desire the construction of such improvements in the area. An estimated cost of such extension that would have to be paid by such property owners, if any, shall be submitted to said property owners as part of such survey. Unless the city council shall determine that public health and safety concerns exist so as to require such installation, in the discretion of the city council, no such extension shall be undertaken by the city unless at least 60 percent of the property owners in the subject area respond affirmatively to such survey. (3) In the event that the subject area has not been developed as a residential area, then the city council shall direct the city manager to conduct a survey, as referred to in subsection (b)(2) of this section, of the property owners in the subject area in the same manner. Unless the city council shall determine that public health and safety concerns exist so as to require such installation, in the discretion of the city council, no such extension shall be undertaken by the city unless 100 percent of the property owners in the subject area respond affirmatively to such survey. (Code 1986, § 13-162; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 2, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 90-102. - Completion of survey; determination of special or general benefits. (a) The survey shall be completed within 90 days after the city manager is directed to commence such survey. In the event that the required percentage approval from the property owners is met as a result of the survey, or in the event that the city council determines that public health and safety concerns exist so as to require the installation of the water and sewer improvements, the city council shall determine whether or not a special benefit will accrue to those property owners gaining access to the city's water and sewer system. In the event that such a special benefit will accrue as determined by the city council, the city council shall compare such special benefit with the general benefit derived by taxpayers of the city in general as a result of such improvements. If the comparison of the special benefit to the general benefit derived by taxpayers of the city in general results in a conclusion that the special benefit to the taxpayers of the subject area in expanding the water and sewer system to said area will outweigh the general benefit derived by taxpayers of the city in general, then in such event, the city council shall determine what portion of the cost of extending the city's water and sewer line to the subject area will be paid by the city, if any. If the city council determines that the general benefit to be derived by taxpayers of the city in general outweighs the special benefit to the property owners in the subject area, then the city shall pay the total cost of the extension of the water and sewer line. (b) In the event that the city determines there is a special benefit to the property owners in the subject area, the city shall determine what portion of such cost each property owner shall pay for such water and sewer extension. If finally approved, the portion of the cost of the water and sewer line extension payable by the property owners in the subject area shall be paid to the city in accord with the provisions of this division. (Code 1986, § 13-163; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 3, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 90-103. - Boundary of subject area; total costs; assessment. (a) At the next regular meeting of the city council after completion of the survey and the tabulations of the results thereof, or at such other time as the city council may determine. The city council may consider a resolution establishing the boundary of the subject area to be served by the water and sewer extensions and identifying all of the property or properties in the subject area which will benefit from access to such extension. Such resolution shall also provide the following: (1) The total cost of the proposed project; (2) The proposed method of assessment as to each property owner; (3) A good faith estimate of the proposed assessment against each property; and (4) A date, place, and time for a public hearing to be held on the merits of the project and on any objections thereto. (b) Such resolution, if approved by the city council, shall be deemed to conditionally approve the project under the terms and conditions as set out in the resolution, but such project shall not proceed until after the public hearing and after the city council has approved a final resolution approving the project in accord with the terms of such final resolution. (c) Notice of the public hearing, referred to in subsection (b) of this section, shall be given to every property owner identified in the preliminary resolution as potentially benefiting from access to the proposed water and sewer line improvements. Such notice shall be given in writing and mailed to such property owners by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address shown on the city tax digest for the mailing of tax notices. Such notices shall be mailed at least 15 days prior to the date of the public hearing and shall include a copy of the preliminary resolution as approved by the city council. Such notice shall also specify the date, time, and location of the hearing and advise such property owners of their right to attend said hearing and to testify at said hearing. Such notice shall also be published by the city manager or his designee at least once a week for two consecutive weeks in the legal organ of the city. The time fixed for the public hearing shall be not less than five nor more than ten days after the date of the last publication of such notice. (d) The city council shall hold the public hearing on the date, time, and place specified for the purpose of hearing supporting comments, complaints, objections that may be made by any interested persons concerning the project, including, but not limited to, the need for such water and sewer extension, the basis of apportioning costs between the city and the property owners, or the amount of the proposed assessment. The city council shall consider such comments and shall also be authorized to accept written comments from interested parties. (e) At the next regular meeting of the city council, or at such other time as the city council may direct, the city council shall be authorized to consider a final resolution authorizing the project. Such resolution shall not be approved at the meeting at which it is first read without unanimous consent of the members of the city council, but shall be voted upon by the city council at the time of the second reading of such resolution. Such resolution shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following determinations. (1) The boundary of the subject area to be served by the water and sewer extension; (2) The projected cost of the improvements; (3) The proposed method of assessment of such costs against the property owners; (4) A good faith estimate of the proposed assessment against each property owner; and (5) The date on which such assessments shall be due and payable to the city. (Code 1986, § 13-164; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 4, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 90-104. - Notice of assessment. (a) The city manager of the city, or his designee, shall, not less than 30 days before the date on which the payment of an assessment shall be due, cause written notice of such assessment to be sent to each affected property owner by certified mail, return receipt requested. The notice shall inform the property owner of the amount of the assessment, that the assessment is payable to the finance director of the city, that if paid on or before the due date, such assessment shall be without interest, and that if such assessment is not paid by the due date, the amount of such assessment shall be a lien against the lot or tracts of land subject to the assessment, and such lien shall continue in force until the assessment and all interest is fully paid. The interest to be charged on assessments not paid when due shall be determined by the city council in the final resolution in section 90-103. (b) In addition to the foregoing notice of the property owner's right to pay such assessment in installments, as provided in this division, shall also be contained in the notice required under this section. (Code 1986, § 13-165; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 5, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 90-105. - Action to enjoin or contest assessments. No action shall be authorized to set aside any assessment, to enjoin the collection of any assessment, to enjoin the issuance of any execution therefor, or to contest the validity of an assessment on any legal or equitable grounds, unless such action is commenced within 30 days after the receipt of the notice provided for in section 90-104. (Code 1986, § 13-166; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 6, 1-21-1999) Sec. 90-106. - Payment of assessment by installments. When an assessment is imposed against a property owner for the installation of water and sewer lines as set out in this division, and the property owner desires to pay the assessment in installments, the property owner shall be authorized to pay such assessment in installments if notice of such election shall be given by the property to the chief administrator officer of the city on or before the due date of the assessment, subject to the following terms: (1) The assessment may be amortized over such length of time as requested by the property owner, but no such assessment may be amortized over more than seven years. (2) The interest rate to be charged to a property owner shall be based upon the cost of funds to the city in connection with such project, plus administrative expenses and costs incurred by the city in administering the payments. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event that the water and sewer line extension project is paid for with cash funds from the city's water and sewer fund, the interest rate to be charged to property owners who amortize their assessment shall be the rate that the money expended for such extension would have earned if such money had been invested in one-year certificates of deposit, plus administrative expenses and costs incurred by the city in administering the payments. (3) Each assessment amortized, as provided in this section, shall be repaid in equal monthly installments of principal and interest according to an amortization schedule provided by the city manager. Such assessments shall be evidenced by a promissory note and such other documents as may be deemed necessary or appropriate to evidence such indebtedness and to secure the repayment thereof. In the event that the property owner is a utility customer of the city, the city shall be authorized to add the monthly installment to the monthly utility bill of the property owner. In the event the property owner is not a utility customer of the city, a monthly installment shall be billed to the property owner by the city. (4) The amount of the assessment shall be a lien against the property of the property owner subject to such assessment until such time as all principal and interest are fully paid. Such liens shall be levied, enforced, and collected in the same manner as provided for the collection of city taxes. (5) In the event that any installment is not paid in full when due, the finance director of the city shall be authorized to notify the property owner that the assessment is in default and such officer shall be further authorized to declare the entire unpaid balance, with interest, costs, and expenses, immediately due and payable. (6) Upon the sale, donation, gift, or other transfer by operation of law of any real property subject to such a lien, such assessment shall be due and payable in full at the time of such transfer; provided, however, that transfers of property solely for the purpose of securing a bona fide indebtedness of the property owner shall not require payment in full of such lien upon such transfer. (7) Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section regarding the repayment of such assessments amortized over a period of years, in the event that the subject area has no residential dwellings located on it at the time of the approval of the final resolution approving the project as provided in this division, then, in such event, the property owners shall be authorized to enter into an agreement with the city to provide that such assessment shall be paid, with interest as aforesaid, at the time that each lot in the proposed development is sold, provided that the entire assessment, whether or not all lots subject to such assessment have been sold, shall be paid no later than seven years from the initial due date of the assessment. All other provisions of this division relating to interest rates, liens for assessments, and default shall be applicable to such property owners. (Code 1986, § 13-167; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 7, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. O-2015-15, 7-23-2015) Sec. 90-107. - Special fund for assessments. All assessments levied and collected under this division shall be retained by the finance director of the city in a special fund to be used and applied for the payment of expenses incurred in installing and extending water and sewer lines for the project identified in the final resolution referred to in this division. No money in said special fund shall be used for any other purpose until such time as all costs of such project have been paid in full. In the event that any funds remain in the special fund after the project has been paid for in full, then such remaining funds shall be transferred to the city water and sewer fund. (Code 1986, § 13-168; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 8, 1-21-1999; Ord. No. O-04-12-33, 12-16-2004) Sec. 90-108. - Property required to connect and pay monthly usage cost. Upon approval of the final resolution referred to in this division authorizing the commencement of the project in the subject area, the city shall be authorized to require that each property in the subject area which is to benefit from the extension of the water and sewer lines as a result of such project shall be required to connect to such water and sewer lines and pay the monthly usage cost as established under this chapter, in addition to the payment of such assessments as may be levied under the terms of this division. (Code 1986, § 13-169; Ord. No. O-99-01-03, § 9, 1-21-1999) Sec. 90-109. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - ANNEXATION OF RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL AREAS
Sec. 90-110. - Annexation application; utility extensions. Upon any property owner submitting an application for annexation of such property owner's property into the city under any applicable method of annexation, if the property to be annexed is not being served by city water service or city sanitary sewer service at the time of the filing of such annexation petition, and if the property to be annexed has already been developed to the extent that it already has constructed on it residential or commercial buildings, then, as a part of the annexation process, the governing body of the city shall be authorized to consider proceeding in accord with the terms of this article with respect to the extension of water mains, sewer mains, water taps, and sewer taps to the property which is the subject of the annexation in accord with the terms of this division. (Ord. No. O-2013-24, 9-19-2013) Sec. 90-111. - Definitions. For the purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: "Annexation" means the annexation of real property into the incorporated limits of the City of Americus pursuant to any method authorized by Georgia law. "Project" means the construction of water line extensions, sewer line extensions, installation of water tap fees, or installation of sewer tap fees, or all of the above. "Property owner" means the person or entity which owns fee simple title to the subject property and is the annexation applicant with respect to the subject property.
